examples.examples: In ds93x18 "Distant Voices", we hear of how Dr. Bashir had once dreamed of becoming a professional tennis player, but had to give up that dream and settle for medical school instead.

theme_name: coming to terms with living in a new environment
description: A character's general living environment has suddenly changed in some way that they can do nothing about, and they must now come to accept it. They may for example be stranded in a foreign land, or have woken up in a distant future.

examples.examples: In voy2x25 "Resolutions", Janeway and Chakotay got stranded on an uninhabited planet. They were eventually resigned to the fact that they would live out the rest of their lives there.

theme_name: coming to terms with one's own death
description: A character is about to die, perhaps from a natural illness, comes to accept the fact and become at peace with themselves over it. In fantastic stories, a character may even have died and must now come to terms with the fact.

examples.examples: In tng5x24 "The Next Phase", Ro Laren and Geordi La Forge apparently perish in a freak engineering accident and become ghosts. Geordi implores Ro to accept the reality of their demise, but she will have none of it. As it transpires, they had merely been phase shifted and could be brought back later.

theme_name: coming to terms with one's own sexuality
description: A character learns to become comfortable with their sexuality.

theme_name: coming to terms with one's past
description: A character has harbored guilt, resentment or other bad feelings with respect to some event in their past, but then comes to peace with all of that.
A character must come to accept something specific that has happened, or some changes in their situation, because there is nothing they can do about it.
The relationship between a military type of leader and their formal subordinate is featured. The setting may be army, navy, air force or something comparable.

examples.examples: In tz1959e4x06 "Death Ship", we saw the Captain of a spaceship quarrel with two men under his command over the best course of action to take given a strange predicament they had found themselves in.

description: Commercialism is the application of both manufacturing and consumption towards personal usage, or the practices, methods, aims, and spirit of free enterprise geared toward generating profit. We are made to ponder whether or not a state of excessive commercialism has come about in society, to the detriment of other social concerns.
A stereotypical down-to-earth, poor and uneducated, "ordinary" character is compared and contrasted with a stereotypical refined and educated elitist character.

examples.examples: In "Stalker" (1979), Stalker is a pitiful and  poor man who has to illegally guide people through a banned zone for a living. The story shows him guiding two educated elite characters: an eminent physicist, Professor, and a professional writer, Writer. The three get into a violent argument, in which Stalker's experience and feelings finally prevail against the others' refined intellects. The story concludes with a disheveled Stalker complaining about those idiotic intellectuals.

description: The troubles a person who is deaf and one who is not, may have in communicating with each other are illustrated.

theme_name: communicating with someone who speaks a different language
description: Two characters neither of whom understands the other's language, try to communicate with each other.
The practice of communicating with the spirits of the dead and living human beings.

Featured is the philosophical, social, political, and economic ideology and movement whose ultimate goal is the establishment of the communist society, which is a socioeconomic order structured upon the common ownership of the means of production and the absence of social classes, money and the state.

We are shown a bleak image of a dysfunctional world resulting from the abolishment of private property and other collectivization efforts. Typically the individual is oppressed for the perceived good of the many.
Children are left without any adult supervision and are left to organize (or descend into chaos) by themselves.

examples.examples: A band of abandoned brats tried to "bonk bonk" Captain Kirk on the noggin in tos1x11 "Miri".

description: A workplace organizes some group activity with the aim of strengthening the bonds between people in a team and teach them to cooperate better.
Someone displays a notable degree of compassion toward the plight of another individual or group.
Someone must chose between risking danger to many other on one hand, or helping someone in need on the other.

examples.examples: In the movie "Alien (1979)", Ripley tries to follow standard quarantine procedures and denies the distressed landing party access to the ship after Kane has come in contact with alien life.

description: Someone is forced to choose between acting with compassion toward another, and saving his or her own skin.
Two nations knowingly vie against one another to achieve a goal that cannot be shared.

examples.examples: The Americans and Russians competed to be the first put a man on the Moon in "Countdown" (1968).

description: A character is conspicuously driven to outperform someone else or be victorious in a task where the goal can't be shared.

examples.examples: In tz1985e3x20 "A Game of Pool", Jesse and Fats were both extremely competitive pool players. Fats had returned from the afterlife, and Jesse staked his immortal soul simply for a chance to prove his mettle.

description: Interest is calculated on top on interest, in addition to the principal sum. When the compounding is done at relatively short intervals (or continuously) over a relatively long time, the result is an exponential growth of capital which can be ample food for the imagination.

examples.examples: In rd1988e1x06 "Me2", Holly explained that Lister now owned 98% of Earth's wealth thanks to compound interest accruing on the Â£17.50 he had in his bank account 3 million years ago.

description: Two characters disagree over some arrangement and both concede something to reach a workable compromise.

theme_name: compromising one's ethical principles for personal advantage
description: Someone must choose between what they believe is right on the one hand, and what would profit them personally on the other.

theme_name: compromising one's ethical principles vs. great need
description: Someone is torn up over doing something they feel they greatly need to do, but that is ethically unsavory to them.

examples.examples: In voy5x26 "Equinox, Part I" it is revealed that the Equinox crew choose to exploit and kill aliens in order to be able to get back to Earth, a voyage that would have taken more than a lifetime otherwise.

theme_name: compromising one's ethical principles vs. self-preservation
description: Someone must choose whether or not to commit unsavory acts in order to save their own skin.

parents.parents: compromising one's ethical principles vs. great need

ancestors.ancestors: compromising one's ethical principles vs. great need

examples.examples: In blackmirror1x01 "The National Anthem", the Prime minister had to decide whether to copulate with a pig on national television in order to save his political career, as well as the life of beloved Royal Family member Princess Susannah.

description: A character exhibits an obsession with shopping, and a buying behavior that leads to adverse consequences for her. In stories, typically this is due to excessive spending that leads to financial problems. However, it can also involve just spending inordinate amounts of time on shopping activities.

examples.examples: In tz1985e2x08a "The Card", we saw a woman, Linda, who had been rejected for every major credit card due to problems with late payments. She now applies for a rather special card with draconian penalties for late payment. When, again, she fails to make payments on schedule her family members start to disappear.

description: The practice of subverting computer security to break into computer systems is featured.

examples.examples: It was mentioned that Trinity had cracked the IRS database in "The Matrix" (1999).

description: A computer is used to simulate a complex system, for example the movement of planets in a solar system, the folding of a proteins, the trajectory of a vehicle etc.

examples.examples: Geordi and Leah Brahms used the holodeck to simulate the warp engine, and save the day in tng3x06 "Booby Trap".

description: There is a character who plays an elaborate confidence trick of some sort on another character.
There is material conflict because people have different moral codes and there is a specific situation in which the codes appear to be incompatible.

notes.notes: This theme applies if there is a conflict situation in which at least one side won't back off because of some cultural idiosyncrasy which is notably different from that of the other side.
The theme notably does not apply if the reasons both sides perpetuate the conflict because of such relatively universal values as: self-preservation, greed, etc.

examples.examples: In tng1x04 "Code of Honor", The Ligonian leader Lutan thought it quite reasonable to kidnap Tasha, a lowly woman as he saw it, for his intrigues and was then honor-bound to stand his ground. The Federation people, on the other hand, saw things differently and could not abandon an officer just because she was female. Thus a material conflict became inevitable.

description: A common category of tough decisions that involve choosing between ones "duty" to something (typically a job or a leader) on one hand, and some conflicting cause or impulse on the other.
Someone is made uncomfortable by things they consider to be more private but that are flaunted publicly by people from another culture. This often has to do with love and sex.
Mutually incompatible systems of justice have a claim to maintaining the rule of law within society. If a mutually acceptable compromise cannot be reached, brute force may have to arbiter.
The social problem of people sometimes having misaligned or conflicting interests to the roles they are serving in, is discussed.
The ramifications of conformism in society, the strong expectation (sometimes enforced) that everyone should adapt themselves to specific norms, are explored.

examples.examples: A band of space hippies refused to conform and scolded Captain Kirk for being a rigid old "Herbert" in tos3x20 "The Way to Eden".

description: There is a bleak society in which there is very little diversity because, one way or the other, people are prevented from developing their own distinctiveness. There may, for example, be an oppressive government that persecutes deviants, or there may be some other social institution that makes people conform. It may be that people must conform in appearance, way of acting, way of thinking, or all three.

examples.examples: In tz1959e5x17 "Number 12 Looks Just Like You", we saw a society wherein everyone upon reaching adulthood were required to undergo a surgical alteration to transform them into one of a limited preset of physically perfect models. The procedure clearly affects the mind as well, and is likely maintained by a remote government in order to maintain conformity and order.

description: Someone deals directly with a problem they had previously avoided or ignored.

examples.examples: Kodos the Executioner, a.k.a. Anton Karidian, was haunted by his decision to sentence some 4,000 colonists to death as governor of Tarsus IV in tos1x12 "The Conscience of the King".

description: An conservative philosophy of life is contrasted with a liberal philosophy of life. Conservative typically means an emphasis on traditions (as it is perceived) whereas liberal typically means an emphasis on social progress (as it is perceived).
The belief that there is a secret and nefarious conspiracy in an institution, often a government.

examples.examples: Neural parasites hatched a conspiratorial plot to infiltrate Starfleet Command in tng1x25 "Conspiracy".

description: There is a society in which human activity is geared towards acquisition of goods and services to absurd extents. Other values and things that give us meaning are mostly absent.
The social issue of there being pathogens that spread quickly from person to person and cause severe health conditions, is discussed.

examples.examples: In apuleius180tgab9 "The Golden Ass: Book 9", the danger of rabies was illustrated when people fearfully kept their distance from an apparently infected canine.

description: A character ponders whether their life is worth living.

examples.examples: Worf was by a hair talked out of committing suicide rather than to live with the shame of being paralyzed in tng5x16 "Ethics". Dr. Timicin was expected according to Kaelonian culture to commit suicide at the age of 65 in tng4x22 "Half a Life" and he had second thoughts before he caved to peer pressure.

description: A character regards another character with scorn or disdain and deems them beneath consideration.
This is the category of themes that contrast two or more reasonably well- defined political ideologies.

notes.notes: The goal of this project is in no way to provoke political controversy. When using a word that references a political stance it is advisable to consult, for example, Wikipedia and use the word only in ways that appear mainstream and are relatively uncontroversial.

examples.examples: "conservative vs. liberal" is a theme of this kind that is often featured in contemporary stories. We have a reasonably clear understanding of what conservative and liberal values are respectively, in a broad sense, even though we may disagree about many of the details.

description: A person in charge uses fear to keep his underlings under control.
One family member is excessively controlling of the life of another family member. For example, an older brother may be controlling who his younger sister dates.

parents.parents: coping with a problematic family member

ancestors.ancestors: coping with a problematic family member

description: One side in a romantic relationship is excessively controlling of their partner's activities.

ancestors.ancestors: coping with a problematic family member

description: A character is regularly engaged in preparing food for human consumption. Typically the character is either a professional cook, or sees cooking as a hobby.

examples.examples: Riker whipped up a batch of 'Owon egg omelets for a few selected members of the command crew in tng2x13 "Time Squared". Worf pronounced the omelets to be "delicious", but the others did not concur.

description: Various complications that can arise when two characters try to cooperate in an endeavour are featured.

We are made to ponder whether it is more important that society and it's laws are centered around (the perhaps utopian idea of) people cooperating for the common good or around (the perhaps realistic assumption of) people working for their own benefit.
Someone copes with a boss who makes their work or life at the workplace difficult.

examples.examples: Riker had a rough go of it working under the command of the no-nonsense Captain Jellico in tng6x10 "Chain of Command, Part I".

description: Someone experiences the effects of a bad hangover.

examples.examples: Scotty coped with the effects of a bad hangover after drinking the Kelvan Tomar under the table in tos2x21 "By Any Other Name". The engineer again struggled with a bad hangover in tas1x10 "Mudd's Passion" and later tng6x24 "Relics".

description: A character stayed in the sun too long and got roasted like a lamb, then had to live with the consequences.

theme_name: coping with a crisis of faith
description: Someone struggles with a loss of faith in religious beliefs that they once held dear.
Someone experiences life with a emotional or physical disability. A physical disability is any limitation on a person's physical functioning, mobility, dexterity or stamina.
A character who is nominally in charge has to deal with a person that is disinclined to obey.
A character suffers through being in the vicinity of an intoxicated person who is acting obnoxiously, for example at a party.
Family members struggle through a dysfunctional marriage.
Someone is troubled by the obligations and other troubles that stem from one's family connection, for example spending time taking care of children.

theme_name: coping with a grumpy old coot
description: Some less old and grumpy character is annoyed by the antics of a much older and grumpier character.
A character has to deal with the fact that their lover is inordinately jealous of perceived and potential rivals.
Someone must come to terms with the fact that an event has drastically changed their living conditions and future prospects.

examples.examples: Captain Picard resigned to living out the remainder of his life as an alien on an unknown planet in tng5x25 "The Inner Light".

description: Someone copes with having an unpredictable and uncontrollable person around who is likely to cause unintentional harm.

examples.examples: Captain Picard and Wesley found themselves stranded on a desert moon with the cantankerous mining shuttle captain Dirgo in tng4x09 "Final Mission".

theme_name: coping with a loved one being gravely ill
description: Someone experiences having a loved on who is on the brink of death because of some disease or injury.

theme_name: coping with a loved one being in peril
description: Someone must stand idly by while a loved one faces a perilous situation.

theme_name: coping with a loved one being mentally ill
description: Someone near and dear must persevere through the experience of having a loved one suffering from a severe mental disorder of one sort or another.

theme_name: coping with a loved one being missing
description: A character is upset because a loved one has disappeared and it is not known whether the loved one is dead or alive.
A subordinate must find ways to cope with a leader who is acting irrationally to a great extent.

theme_name: coping with a massive loss of comrades
description: A character in a military-like outfit looses a demoralizing number of their comrades in some disastrous event, and must come to terms with this.

parents.parents: coping with the death of someone

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: Commodore Matt Decker mourned the loss of his crew to the Planet Eater in tos2x06 "The Doomsday Machine".

description: The life of a child or adult whose parent or parents interfere more than is desired is explored.

examples.examples: Worf's adoptive, Human parents embarrassed the Klingon during their visit aboard the Enterprise-D in tng4x02 "Family".

description: A character is subjected to the prolonged company of a person that begs and takes advantage of them without offering much in return. Typically there is a social bond, such as blood ties or old friendship, that inhibits the first character from breaking off the acquaintanceship.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected4x04 "The Best of Everything", Arthur invited Charlie to stay with him for a share of the rent, a lease of smart looking clothes, and some tuition in the art of seduction. It quickly became apparent that Charlie only paid lip-service to the terms of this arrangement and had no intention to pay his due in full. The increasingly frustrated Arthur was eventually pushed to the point of committing manslaughter.

description: Someone makes efforts to endure an inordinate amount of verbal abuse and admonishment.

examples.examples: Harry Mudd was nagged nearly to death by an android replica of his wife Stella in tos2x12 "I, Mudd".

theme_name: coping with a pedantic authority figure
description: A subordinate is having trouble with their boss being overly critical of their work.

theme_name: coping with a problematic family member
description: A character struggles to get along with, control, or abide, a family member that, for one reason or another, causes them trouble.

examples.examples: "embarrassing family member" is an example of "coping with a problematic family member" as it implies the presence of someone who is struggling to abide a family member that they find embarrassing.

description: A character must put up with a person who they cannot avoid but find if difficult to deal with for whatever reason.

examples.examples: Examples of problematic people that others have coped with in stories include panicky relatives, practical jokers, jealous lovers, enamoured groupies, and obnoxious jerks.

description: A character is troubled because someone they are connected with frivolously spends too much money. A spouse might, for example, be troubled because their partner is shopping or gambling to an extent that it threatens the family's financial security.
Someone copes with a child, or childish person, who screams their heads off until they get what they want.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk struggled with the behavioural problems of Elaan in tos3x02 "Elaan of Troyius".

description: A character has to live with a person in their life carrying notions of suicide around.
A character must deal with another character who is excessively obsequious.
Someone experiences having a terminal illness.

examples.examples: McCoy diagnosed himself with xenopolycythemia, a rare blood disease that is always terminal, in tos3x10 "For the World is Hollow and I have Touched the Sky".

description: The proprietor of a business struggles to maintain cordial relations with a client who refuses to be content.
Someone copes with the inevitability of growing old.

examples.examples: Lwaxana coped with aging once in tng4x22 "Half a Life" and again in tng5x20 "Cost of Living".

description: Someone has to handle being around a conceited and condescending person.
A celebrity is accosted by a fan who is sexually attracted to him or her and none too shy about it.
A character questions whether their life has meaning, purpose, or value. This is often tied to depression or negative speculations on purpose in life.

examples.examples: In "Winter Light" (1963), Pastor Tomas Ericsson had a deep existential crisis related to the problems he saw in the world and his own apparent lack of faith. Fisherman Jonas Persson had a similar crisis, and ended up killing himself.

description: A character is burdened by an incompetent coworker.

examples.examples: The Delta Theta III landing party was generally bemused by the erratic actions of Ari bn Bem in tas2x02 "Bem".

description: A character copes with an inflexible person who is unwilling to compromise or see other peoples point of view.

examples.examples: Data struggled to convince Gosheven, the leader of a human colony on Tau Cygna V, to organize an evacuation in the face of a Sheliak invasion in tng3x02 "The Ensigns of Command".

description: Someone struggles to listen to a person who talks at length about frivolous matters.

examples.examples: Captain Picard was obligated to attend a social gathering hosted by the notorious chatterbox Calvin "Hutch" Hutchinson in tng6x18 "Starship Mine".

description: Someone struggles to deal with an annoying and inconsiderate person.

examples.examples: Berlinghoff Rasmusen played the role of obnoxious jerk aboard the Enterprise-D in tng5x09 "A Matter of Time" in order to distract the crew from his larceny.

description: Someone has to deal with a noisy, or otherwise troublesome, neighbor.
A famous person struggles with a much-more-than-usually devoted groupie, for example a stalker.
Someone struggles to deal with a domineering and inconsiderate person, i.e., an jerk.

examples.examples: Mr. Lurry, manager of Deep Space Station K-7, coped with verbal abuse at the hands of Captain Kirk after having issued an unnecessary Code One alert in tos2x13 "The Trouble with Tribbles".

theme_name: coping with an overly hard handshake
description: A character is subjected by another character to a grasping of hands that is uncomfortably firm. Typically this is done for the purpose of intimidation and to assert dominance.

theme_name: coping with an overly private individual
description: A character tries to be social with another character who is unusually taciturn.
An adolescent copes with the anxiety and depression that comes with having an overprotective guardian.

examples.examples: Salia was excessively protected by her appointed guardian Anya in tng2x10 "The Dauphin".

theme_name: coping with an unwelcome house guest
description: A reluctant host has to suffer through having a guest that they would rather not have.
A character is subjected to lousily prepared food.

theme_name: coping with being a danger to those around you
description: A character copes with being a danger to other people around them.

theme_name: coping with being a laughing stock
description: Someone is the perpetual laughing stock of a group.

A character, typically a child, who has been dependent on another character, typically a parent, for guidance and/or sustenance must come to terms with the situation when that aid is suddenly and deliberately withdrawn.

examples.examples: A mother drove her android boy to the forest and abandoned him there in "A.I. Artificial Intelligence" (2001).

description: Someone struggles with being rejected and isolated from a social group that is (financially, emotionally, or otherwise) important to them.
A character lives with a deformity or injury that has left them permanently disfigured to an appalling degree.

examples.examples: Vina was horribly disfigured in a crash landing on the planet Talos IV in tos0x01 "The Cage".

theme_name: coping with being eclipsed by a family member
description: A character feels diminished because of a family member's success at something in particular, and must come to terms with this.

aliases.aliases: coping with being surpassed by one's child

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected9x02 "The Colonels Lady", George, who had had a distinguished career in the military, resented his wife's sudden and smashing success as a poetry writer.

description: Someone deals with the various travails that may come with being famous, such as lack of privacy, creepy stalkers, greedy supplicants, etc. etc.

aliases.aliases: being famous is not all it's cracked up to be

theme_name: coping with being ill and indisposed
description: A character is unable to go about their normal daily life because of some affliction and this changes their social interactions in a disagreeable way. They may, for example, resent being treated like an invalid by their well- meaning friends.

theme_name: coping with being ill on the job
description: A character experiences symptoms of some illness while at work.

theme_name: coping with being in a heat wave
description: A character is sweating it through a period of excessively hot weather.
A character struggles with various such problems that may arise from being in debt to another.

Someone who is injured is featured as trying to cope with their situation.

Note: Since injuries are extremely common in fiction, the bar for using this theme ought to be high, i.e., the comment should cite something explicit that makes it clear why the coping was featured which is not necessarily the case just because there was an injury in passing and someone saying "ouch".

theme_name: coping with being lost in space
description: Someone (or some sentient thing) copes with being lost in the vast vastness of space.

examples.examples: The sentient space probe Nomad coped briefly with being lost in space, parted from its maker Jackson Roykirk, in tos2x08 "The Changeling".

theme_name: coping with being lost in the forest
description: A character is in mortal danger because they have gotten lost, typically in a forest, and can't find their way to safety.

examples.examples: In "The Blair Witch Project" (1999), we saw three young filmmakers get irrevocably lost in a large forest while making a documentary about the local legend. While trying to find their way out, they were chased by something supernatural and eventually perished.

theme_name: coping with being separated from one's family
description: A character struggles with being separated from their family for an extended duration of time.

examples.examples: Jono was separated from his adoptive father the Endar in tng4x04 "Suddenly Human".

theme_name: coping with being separated from someone you love
description: A character is struggling with relationship issues that come from being far away (or otherwise separated) from the object of their affection for an extended period of time.
A character is subjected to cruel, painful and deliberate mistreatment against their will.

examples.examples: Captain Picard coped with extreme physical and psychological torture in tng6x11 "Chain of Command, Part II".

description: A character deals with not having a job and the typical problems that come with it.
Someone copes with having once been successful at what they did but then failed to keep up with.
A character is struggling with second though about getting married as their wedding day draws near.

examples.examples: Keiko O'Brien, nÃ©e Ishikawa, experienced some last minute jitters over marrying Miles O'Brien in tng4x11 "Data's Day".

description: A character copes with being ordered by a superior to do something that they do not wish to do for personal reasons, for example pride. Note: This theme is not used when the orders cause a moral dilemma.

examples.examples: Ro Laren expressed her annoyance at Riker in the turbolift for making her write up flight handling assessment in his way in tng5x14 "Conundrum".

description: A pregnant woman (rarely a man except in fiction) has to deal with the various aches, pains and other annoyances that come with her condition.
A character must endure extreme levels of physical pain.

examples.examples: In nightgallery2x22a "The Caterpillar", the character Macy was in utter agony while an earwig burrowed its way through his brain from one ear to the other.

description: A character ate something bad and now has an upset stomach.
A former lovebird deals with the emotional fallout of having been dumped like a sack of potatoes.

theme_name: coping with having a bad day
description: A character copes with having one of those days when everything that seemingly can go wrong, does go wrong.

theme_name: coping with having a bad reputation
description: A character struggles with the feelings and social complications that can come with having a bad reputation with people around you.

theme_name: coping with having a chronic condition
description: A character has an intractable, constantly recurring disease or other medical condition that they just have to live with. This may involve regular visits to the doctor and onerous treatment procedures.

theme_name: coping with having a cuckold reputation
description: A male character has to handle the information that their female love partner has been physically unfaithful with another man, and that this is publicly known to some extent.

parents.parents: coping with having a bad reputation

ancestors.ancestors: coping with having a bad reputation

description: A character struggles to endure pain located internally inside the skull.

theme_name: coping with having a lousy dead-end job
description: Someone is stuck in a very low status job and must come to terms with it.

theme_name: coping with having a predetermined life
description: A character is burdened with their future role in this world being out of their own hands.

examples.examples: Salia was reluctant to be the predetermined ruler of Daled IV in tng2x10 "The Dauphin".

theme_name: coping with having a speech disorder
description: Someone experiences life with a speech impediment.

theme_name: coping with having a stigmatizing illness
description: Someone has a physical condition that makes them a pariah to the rest of their society. For example HIV/AIDS can be a stigmatizing disease in homophobic societies.
A character deals with the psychological problems that can come from being violated sexually, or in a comparable way.
Someone feels guilty at having been responsible for injuring another person.

examples.examples: Doctor McCoy unintentionally blinded Spock in tos1x29 "Operation -- Annihilate!".

theme_name: coping with having to destroy one's own creation
description: A character struggles with the tough decision of whether or not they should destroy something they have created, perhaps because it is causing some kind of mischief.

examples.examples: In voy2x13 "Prototype" B'Elanna found an alien robot and spent much time lovingly restoring and upgrading him. When it turned out that the robot and his kin where completely genocidal, B'Elanna very reluctantly took the decision to destroy the work she had done in order that it would not aid them.

description: A character believes themself to have been thoroughly embarrassed in the eyes of others.
A character struggles to come to term with the fact that they can't make babies of their own.
A character is unable to sleep.

examples.examples: Troi struggled with insomnia in tng4x17 "Night Terrors".

description: A character has to live through one or another of those adverse conditions that has been known to plague human life from time to time.

examples.examples: Puberty, financial ruin, unemployment, stress, and personal failure are examples of some things that humans occasionally have to live through and learn to cope with.

theme_name: coping with living in a foreign culture
description: A character copes with living in culture different from the one they are accustomed to.

examples.examples: Worf struggled to maintain his Klingon identity while serving aboard the Enterprise-D in tng2x14 "The Icarus Factor".

theme_name: coping with losing a special ability
description: A character had an ability that made them somewhat special but then looses that ability and must cope with the associated feelings and potential loss of status.

examples.examples: In tng4x10 "The Loss" Counselor Deanna Troi looses her emphatic/telepathic powers and can no longer sense minds and emotions. Frustrated by this comparative handicap in her work and with a feeling that she has become useless to her fellow crew-members, she becomes distraught and attempts to resign.

theme_name: coping with memories of a lost love
description: A character copes with heart-wrenching memories of a lover that they failed to entirely get over.

examples.examples: McCoy found himself in a "romantic haze" at the prospect of meeting his long- lost love Nancy on Planet M-113 In tos1x05 "The Man Trap".

description: A character struggles with the realization that they will one day die.

examples.examples: Q was stripped of his transcendental powers, including immortality, by the Q Continuum in tng3x13 "Deja Q".

description: A character is morally compelled to oppose and jeopardize their friendship with someone who is acting badly.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk coped with opposing his longtime friend Gary Mitchell, who became an imminent danger to the crew after acquiring super powers, in tos1x01 "Where No Man Has Gone Before".

description: A character copes with the aftermath of having experienced a personal failure in life.

examples.examples: Wesley needed some words of encouragement from Captain Picard after he failed the Starfleet Academy entrance exam in tng1x19 "Coming of Age".

description: A character copes with a mental disorder that can develop after a person is exposed to a traumatic event.

examples.examples: Super soldier Roga Danar suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder after having served in the Angosian military in tng3x11 "The Hunted".

description: An adolescent character struggles with the normal hallmarks of puberty, such as a variety of bodily changes and sexual urges.
A character experiences radiation sickness.

examples.examples: Little Willie Harding succumbed of radiation poisoning after spending a night in the hospital in "X the Unknown" (1956).

description: Someone copes with being rejected by a person they are romantically interested in.
A character is about to leave someone they care about behind forever and struggles with how to take their leave.
A character copes with a loss of their mental faculties that comes naturally with age, or one of the more severe conditions that is sometimes associated.

notes.notes: This theme is used for example when a character copes with Dementia, or Alzheimer's.

examples.examples: In tng3x23 "Sarek", Sarek coped with having Bendii Syndrome, which is a rare degenerative neurological disorder that sometimes affects Vulcans over the age of two hundred.

description: A character has trouble performing in the sack.

theme_name: coping with someone controlling your life
description: A character has to struggle with someone (or something) controlling their life.

examples.examples: Professor Kerry West got a new television set that began to regulate almost every aspect of his daily life in Twonky (1953).

theme_name: coping with someone having an addiction
description: Someone must watch as a near and (usually) dear person struggles with an addiction.

theme_name: coping with someone losing their mind
description: Someone is powerless to help a friend who is losing their mind and is left with no alternative but to stand idly by and watch the descent into madness.

theme_name: coping with someone who is overexerting themself
description: Someone experiences having to watch a person they care about overexert themself at work.

theme_name: coping with someone who is suffering from a health condition
description: A character must cope with the fact that someone they care about suffers from a, more or less, serious health complication.

theme_name: coping with someone who refuses to take care of their health
description: A character, usually a relative, is concerned about a person they care for risking their life by refusing to see the Doctor or not following medical advice, etc.
A character is deprived of food for a dangerous period of time.
A character struggles to deal with heavy pressure and stress at work.

examples.examples: Barclay retreated to a holodeck powered fantasy world to escape his on the job problems in tng3x21 "Hollow Pursuits".

description: A character experiences losing a near and dear one to suicide. Alternatively, in a creative sci-fi story, they could possibly cope with the ramifications of their own suicide.

parents.parents: coping with the death of someone

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: The crew was shocked and bereaved at the suicide of their fellow crewman Daniel Kwan in tng7x18 "Eye of the Beholder".

theme_name: coping with the death of a child
description: A character grieves over the loss of their child.

parents.parents: coping with the death of a family member

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of a family member
coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: Lwaxana mourned the death of her daughter Kestra in tng7x07 "Dark Page".

theme_name: coping with the death of a family member
description: A character must come to terms with having lost a family member.

parents.parents: coping with the death of someone

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of someone

theme_name: coping with the death of a friend
description: A character grieves over the death of a friend.

parents.parents: coping with the death of someone

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: McCoy mourned Captain Kirk after he was pulled into interspace in tos3x09 "The Tholian Web".

theme_name: coping with the death of a lover
description: A character grieves over the death of a lover.

parents.parents: coping with the death of someone

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: Captain Kirk cried on Spock's shoulder, after he had knowingly allowed his lover Edith Keeler to die, in tos1x28 "The City on the Edge of Forever".

theme_name: coping with the death of a parent
description: A character (typically a child) grieves over the loss of a parent.

parents.parents: coping with the death of a family member

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of a family member
coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: Jeremy Aster was racked with guilt in tng3x05 "The Bonding" for falsely thinking that he was responsible for the death of his parents.

theme_name: coping with the death of a pet
description: A character grieves over the loss of their pet.

parents.parents: coping with the death of someone

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: Spock mourned the loss of his pet sehlat in tas1x02 "Yesteryear".

theme_name: coping with the death of a spouse
description: A character grieves over the loss of their spouse.

parents.parents: coping with the death of a family member
coping with the death of a lover

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of a family member
coping with the death of a lover
coping with the death of someone
coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: Worf howled over the body of his murdered spouse K'Ehleyr in tng4x07 "Reunion".

theme_name: coping with the death of one's entire family
description: A character grieves over the death of their entire family.

parents.parents: coping with the death of someone

ancestors.ancestors: coping with the death of someone

examples.examples: In tng1x26 "The Neutral Zone", Clare Raymond woke up from cryogenic preservation aboard the Enterprise-C only to be confronted by the stark realisation that everyone in her entire family from the 20th century was dead.

theme_name: coping with the death of someone
description: A character is coming to grips with the death of a person or persons who he or she had a degree of attachment to in life.

theme_name: coping with the defeat of one's people
description: A character deals with the news that their people have been defeated.

theme_name: coping with the imprisonment of a family member
description: A character must stand idly by while a loved one rots away in prison.

theme_name: coping with the loss of one's livelihood
description: A character copes with having had to give up their livelihood for whatever reason.

theme_name: coping with the rigors of command
description: A commander struggles with the mental burden it is to be responsible for other people.

examples.examples: Captain Pike pondered going into business on Regulus or on the Orion colony in the aftermath of a hard fought battle on Rigel VII in tos0x01 "The Cage".

theme_name: coping with time passing you by
description: A character copes with not being able to keep up with an ever-changing world.

examples.examples: Scotty coped with time having passed him by after Geordi found him suspended in a transporter pattern-buffer in tng6x05 "Relics".

description: A character copes with unwelcome amorous advances.

examples.examples: Captain Picard was mortified to have his former lover Vash aboard the Enterprise-D in tng4x20 "Qpid".

description: A character finds themself subject to this most disagreeable circumstance: the wearing of boots that are not quite large enough.
The once accepted, but now usually proscribed, practice of letting authority figures correct the behavior of their subordinates by inflicting physical pain, is discussed.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected2x03 "Galloping Foxley", young Perkins was regularly caned by the older boy called Galloping Foxley, a prefect, (who would sometimes cane at a gallop) to whom he had been assigned as a slave.

description: There is a powerful corporation that to a notable extent uses its wealth to bribe or otherwise influence the government.

notes.notes: As a rule of thumb, this theme applies if a corporation interferes with or seriously challenges the whole of law enforcement.

examples.examples: In RoboCop 2 (1990), the OCP megacorporation plotted to bankrupt the city of Detroit then to step in to take it over.

description: We are shown a society in which one or more corporations has formal monopoly on political power.

notes.notes: This theme is not used in the many cases where powerful corporations merely control a more conventional government.

examples.examples: The film Parasite (1982) is set in a new future where instead of a government, America is run by an organization called the Merchants who exploit the remaining populace with ruthless ineptitude.

description: Discussed is the social problem that arises when officials or other people that have been entrusted with authority, to a wide extent abuses their position to acquire illicit benefits for themselves.
The idea that the universe somehow maintains an equilibrium between opposing, typically dualistic forces (e.g. good and evil, light and dark, male and female, etc.), is featured.
A hypothetical planet always on the other side of the Sun from Earth so that it remains hidden from us.
A character faces a perceived danger boldly.

theme_name: courage in the face of death
description: Someone shows bravery in the face of lethal danger.
Persons with political power in a royal court or suchlike setting, maneuver and scheme with various motives, usually to get more power, wealth, and influence.

examples.examples: In the play "Hamlet" (1602), the drama takes place in the royal court of Denmark where people were jostling for power, marriage, and prestige. Prince Hamlet's uncle had usurped the throne by murdering Hamlet's father, and was further maneuvering to rid himself of the troublesome, bereaved, and eponymous prince.

theme_name: covering up a crime to save a friend
description: A character struggles with whether to report a crime committed by a friend, or to help said friend evade the law.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected4x08 "Never Speak Ill of the Dead", Bob and Sim came to believe that their friend, Dr. David Rankin, had murdered his promiscuous young wife and buried her corpse in the basement. They decided to help him cover up the crime, had their help rejected and their hypothesis soundly refuted by the shovel.

description: Powerful aliens observe us in secret to see what we are like, perhaps conducting an experiment or two in the process.
A secret military project is featured. The project is notably kept secret from the public at large, and not just the enemy.
Someone exhibits a marked lack of courage when the situation demands it.

examples.examples: Marplon lost his nerve in the lead up to Captain Kirk confronting Landru in the Hall of Audiences in tos1x22 "The Return of the Archons".

description: Someone is put under so much stress that they can't handle it and, typically, start acting irrationally.

examples.examples: Dave Bailey was relieved of duty for snapping on the bridge in tos1x02 "The Corbomite Maneuver".

description: There is a theory that is presented as scientific, but does not in fact adhere to accepted scientific standards. Examples include ideas about the Bermuda Triangle, flying saucers, and Bigfoot.

examples.examples: It was revealed that the vampires of legend were in fact life force thirsty space aliens in "Lifeforce" (1985).

description: The killing and mutilation of cattle under unusual, usually bloodless, and anomalous circumstances is attributed to one or another fanciful notion, including secret government agencies, cryptid predators, and aliens.

examples.examples: In "Endangered Species" (1982), some people attributed a series of cattle mutilations to extraterrestrials, but the true source of the mischief turned out to be something closer to home.

description: The contemporary social issue of how to handle creationist teachings is discussed. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion, of course, but to what extent is it permissible to teach children such nonsense?

A writer is engaged in writing original and creative works of poetry, novels, plays, etc. This is contrasted with, for example, scientific and journalistic writing where creativity has to be constrained by objective facts to a much greater extent.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

description: Featured is a slippery-slope process by which a society becomes less democratic and more authoritarian. The population at large fails to take notice because although they'd prefer democracy, each step of the way appears normal and necessary, and quickly becomes a new normal.
The human tendency to form strong bonds to ships we are in command of or serve on for some time, is illustrated.

Cricket is a bat-and-ball game played between two teams of eleven players on a field at the centre of which is a 22-yard (20-metre) pitch with a wicket at each end, each comprising two bails balanced on three stumps. This game is featured.
This is the category of themes that relate to proscribed actions that are normally punishable by contemporary states.

notes.notes: Because of their notoriety, we consider that a "crime" theme is topical to the story when a character unambiguously commits such a crime. For example "murder" becomes topical if a murder is committed. Common sense is required here: For example, action movies frequently feature actions that would arguably be "crimes" to a thoughtful conscientious viewer, yet are not treated as such in the story for one reason or another (action heroes often appear to be above the law). It is not the purpose of this category to catalog such things.

description: Featured is a crime that prevents the justice system itself from operating as it is meant to. This may involve, for example, false accusations, tampering with evidence, and perjury.
Featured is a crime that involves private property, for example burglary, larceny, theft, motor vehicle theft, arson, shoplifting, and vandalism.
Featured is a crime that involves direct physical harm or force being applied to another person.

Featured is a crime where all of society is the aggrieved party, according to the law. This may include things like "drunk driving" which is criminal even if no one actually got hurt because anyone and everyone was put at risk.
What acts are to be criminal, how they should be punished and otherwise handled, and their impact on society in general are discussed.

examples.examples: In blackmirror2x02 "White Bear", the viewer is made to ponder several ethical dilemmas regarding the treatment of putative criminals. The woman did not remember her crime. Moreover, her punishment was turned into a public spectacle, if not for profit certainly for fame. Her punishment was certainly both cruel and unusual.

description: Featured is a violent crime, typically homicide, in which the perpetrator commits the act because of sudden strong impulse such as sudden rage rather than as a premeditated crime.
The crime of intentional deception to secure unfair or unlawful gain, or to deprive a victim of a legal right, is featured.

examples.examples: Ardra conned the gullible inhabitants of Ventax II by pretending to be their devil in tng4x13 "Devil's Due".

description: There is a criminal gang and their influence on society is featured.

examples.examples: Moses in "Attack the Block" (2011) headed a criminal youth gang in a rundown area of London.

description: This is the category of themes that in general terms illustrate what may happen when people of different cultural backgrounds encounter each other.

examples.examples: The theme "alien point of view" is used when we are shown what things might be like from the point of view of an alien species, and categorized under "cross cultural issue" is it illustrates how someone from a different culture may have a different outlook on things.

description: Two people with different cultural backgrounds engage in a romantic relationship, and face all the various misunderstandings and controversies that typically come with it. Will the respective families get along?
We are made to ponder what kinds of acts of punishments are so cruel and unusual that it would be preferable to prohibit them entirely.
A character is indifferent to, or delights in, pain and suffering that they inflict on someone else.

examples.examples: Gul Madred subjected Captain Picard to unspeakable tortures in tng6x11 "Chain of Command, Part II" and tried to make him see five lights where there were only four, four lights!

description: A being patterned after crustaceans.
Technology that can freeze, e.g., a human body and thus stop it from aging or changing in any major way for an extended amount of time.
An animal or plant that has been inferred from anecdotal or other evidence considered insufficient by mainstream science.

A technique for secure communication in the presence a third party is featured. A collection of more or less complicated algorithms for encryption. These are strategies for writing messages such that they can only be read by those who know the secret to decoding them.

examples.examples: Sherlock Holmes and Watson cracked a book cipher in sherlock1x02 "The Blind Banker".

description: A being with a body made out of crystal.

examples.examples: Data's evil twin brother Lore summoned the Crystalline Entity, the space snowflake, to feed on the lifeforms aboard the Enterprise-D in tng1x13 "Datalore".

description: There is an exchange, or someone is sent, to stay in a foreign culture with the purpose of fostering cross cultural understanding between peoples in general.

examples.examples: William Riker participated in an officer exchange program that involved serving aboard the Klingon vessel Pagh in tng2x08 "A Matter of Honor".

description: This is the category of themes that refer to cultural artifacts from actual human history. Notably, these are references to well known stories that have been occasionally and explicitly referenced within other stories.

examples.examples: For example "the Wizard of Oz", "Lord of the Rings", and "the legend of King Arthur" are stories (or categories of stories) that are sometimes unambiguously referenced within more modern stories.

description: The importance of preserving an imperiled culture is explored.

examples.examples: The aliens on Malcor III decided to protect their dogmatic we-are-the-centre- of-the-universe beliefs by shutting themselves off from the Federation and the outside world in tng4x15 "First Contact".

theme_name: cultural symbols as a unifying force in society
description: People unify around some object that is of shared cultural and historical significance to them, for example a religious relic.
A scientifically derived cure for Alzheimer's disease is featured.

parents.parents: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

ancestors.ancestors: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

theme_name: cure for an as yet uncurable disease
description: There is a scientific-based cure for a disease, such as cancer or the common cold, that is considered uncurable by modern medicine.
A scientifically derived cure for complete or nearly complete vision loss is featured.

parents.parents: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

ancestors.ancestors: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

examples.examples: In nightgallery0x01b "Eyes" (1969), a doctor temporarily restored a blind woman's vision by transplanting in her the optic nerves taken from a reluctant donor.

description: A scientifically derived cure for cancer is featured.

parents.parents: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

ancestors.ancestors: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

examples.examples: Dr. Bradshaw sought an electricity-based cure for cancer in the film Indestructible Man (1956).

description: A scientifically derived cure for the common cold is featured.

parents.parents: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

ancestors.ancestors: cure for an as yet uncurable disease

description: Someone performs ill-advised, unnecessary, dangerous investigations or experiments in order to satisfy their own personal curiosity.
Two or more people fight over the legal guardianship of a child.
A being whose body is part biological and part mechanical.

examples.examples: Q acquainted the Enterprise-D crew with that enigmatic race of cyborgs known as the Borg in tng2x16 "Q Who".

description: A theory in which the universe follows infinite, or indefinite, self- sustaining cycles is featured.
There is a flesh-and-blood being with only one eye.
There is a character who likes to wag about to the rhythms of music, either professionally or as a serious hobby.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

examples.examples: Beverly "the dancing doctor" got a kick out of teaching Data the art of tap dancing in tng4x11 "Data's Day".

description: The issue of people sometimes choosing to drive their vehicles in a way that poses an unacceptable danger to themselves and others, is discussed. Most typically, this happens when a character is caught speeding.
There is an embarrassing fact about something pertaining to a person's family or ancestry that is not widely known.

examples.examples: In ds96x17 "Wrongs Darker Than Death or Night" Kira found out that her mother, who she previously thought was a heroine, had quite willfully prostituted herself to the enemy and become a collaborator in order to protect Kira and her family.

description: The physics hypothesis of "dark matter", thought to make up 85% of the matter in the universe, is featured.

The question of appropriate balance between the public expectation of privacy on one hand and various social, legal and political issues on the other, are discussed. Is it, for example, acceptable for the government to snoop on innocent people's browsing habits in order to pick up on potential terrorist threats?
Two parties in a conflict, like the Cold War, try to gradually back down and defuse the situation.
There is a parent who does not adequately fulfill their responsibilities as such. This typically happens when someone neglects their child custody or support obligations as set out by law.

examples.examples: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadbeat_parent

description: A character is able to kill people (or living things) merely by touching them.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to another being

description: Someone literally strikes a bargain with the Christian devil, one of his minions, or a closely comparable mythological being from some other creed.

examples.examples: The Ventaxians had made a literal deal with the devil to provide a thousand years of paradise on their homeworld in return for future enslavement in tng4x13 "Devil's Due".

description: The many trials and tribulations involved in handling children are featured.

examples.examples: On Captain Picard Day, Picard had the onerous duty to feign interest, bestow awards and otherwise encourage youngsters in tng7x12 "The Pegasus".

description: There is a being of the Grim Reaper sort, that is somehow central to the transportation of expired souls from the Land of the Living to the Hereafter.

aliases.aliases: personification of death the Grim Reaper

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x17a "Welcome to Winfield", we see a modern agent of Death dressed in a shining white suit, on a mission to capture a young man who did not want to come quietly when it was his time.

description: A hypothetical directed energy weapon that induces instant death in its victims.

A character has the opportunity to "make a wish", i.e., choose a boon from a loosely defined and relatively unbounded set of options, and struggles with this potentially tough decision. For example, a genie may tell them they can wish for anything but more wishes, or an extremely wealthy character says they can ask for whatever they want.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x19a "The Leprechaun-Artist", we saw three young boys with a captive Leprechaun deliberate over what sort of boons to demand. The idea of asking for world peace was mooted but quickly discarded for more interesting things, like X-ray vision.

theme_name: deciding whether to be a parent
description: A character wrestles with themselves over whether or not they are ready and willing to axle the mantle of being a parent.

theme_name: decision making in the face of uncertainty
description: Someone must decide, in a given situation that involves significant uncertainty, which among various courses of action is the better.
Someone faces the dangers inherent to exploring unfamiliar parts of the deep sea.

theme_name: defamation of character vs. freedom of speech
description: We are made to ponder where the limits of free speech should be drawn. Should outright lies that hurt someone else's reputation be persecuted or is that a slippery slope towards totalitarianism?
A character escapes from their own side and goes over to the enemy, sometimes bringing valuable information with them.

We are made to ponder what treatments are so shameful and debasing that they should be prohibited. Such treatment have been used as early steps in stirring up ethnic hatred and may lead to repression and genocide.
Someone has the undesirable duty to deliver very bad news, i.e., to inform of the death of kin.

examples.examples: Captain Picard had the unpleasant duty of informing Jeremy Aster that his mother Marla had died on an away mission in tng3x05 "The Bonding".

theme_name: delusion of being someone one is not
description: A character is portrayed as having the crazy delusion that they are someone they are not. Typically this happens when a person believes themself to be someone famous, like Jesus or Napoleon.

notes.notes: This theme is typically not applicable in fantastical stories where magic or technology is used to alter a person's mind in such a way that it arguably has been transformed into the mind of that person they now think they are.

description: A character exhibits fantastical beliefs that they are famous, omnipotent, wealthy, or otherwise very powerful.

examples.examples: Navigator Riley suddenly thought he was the captain in tos1x06 "The Naked Time".

description: We are shown what things might be like from a mentally ill person's point of view.
Someone uses fine words, speeches, rhetorical tricks etc. to influence a group of people.
The workings of a democracy are featured.

examples.examples: Babylon 5, bbf1x01, involved an election on earth as well as voting on the station itself.

description: There is a pure evil spirit.
A demon or devil enters into a person and takes control of them.

examples.examples: Dana Barrett was possessed by the demon Zuul in "Ghostbusters" (1984).

description: A propaganda technique which promotes an idea about the enemy being threatening evil aggressor with only destructive objectives is featured.
Someone is faced with an uncomfortable fact but tries irrationally to deny the evidence.

theme_name: depletion of a vital natural resource
description: People over-exploit a vital resource on which they depend and civilization collapses.

examples.examples: The Salt Vampires of planet M-113 were on the road to extinction as their planet had run out of salt in tos1x05 "The Man Trap". Where exactly the salt went is unclear but perhaps they ate it all.

description: Someone exhibits a low, dark mood that at its extreme can lead to thoughts of suicide.
The way that someone can, step by step and without particular premeditation, get drawn into evermore serious crime is featured.

examples.examples: In voy3x13 "Fair Trade" Neelix did a favor for a friend who turned out to be involved in drug smuggling. After covering up some minor transgressions Neelix eventually found himself an accomplice to serious crime.

In voy5x26 "Equinox (1)" it is told that the Equinox crew accidentally killed an alien and discovered that its body made excellent fuel. Driven by exceptional need they procured another alien which they murdered for fuel, then another and so on.

description: The transition of a healthy mind into unhealthy mental disorder is featured.

examples.examples: Riker thought he was losing his mind in an alien insane asylum in tng6x21 "Frame of Mind".

description: There is a planet where nearly all land is arid, hot and sandy so that it resembles nothing more than one gigantic desert.
A character abandons a duty or post without permission and is done with the intention of not returning.
Someone is made to choose between what they desire for themselves on the one hand, and a cause of action they know to be morally the right on the other.
A character feels that all hope is gone.
Someone is at the brink of disaster, defeat, or personal failure and may try desperate actions to avoid the dreaded outcome.
There is a society which is ruled by a despot with more or less absolute power. This should not be confused with totalitarianism, which is more severe.
The idea that some or all of what will happen to us is predetermined and cannot be influenced by our decisions.

examples.examples: Data was destined to find his own severed head in tng5x26 "Time's Arrow".

theme_name: destroying one people to save another
description: The following type of ethical dilemma becomes topical: Can the destruction of one people be justified on account of it saving another? In particular, is a people justified in committing genocide if they think it is necessary for their own survival as a people?
A character seeks to improve their ability to interact socially with other people.
There is a container-like device that, defying the laws of nature as we presently know them, has a larger interior volume than its exterior volume.
The worship of Satan is featured.

A hypothetical process by which a creature can be transformed into some creature of an earlier stage in its evolutionary history. E.g., a human could become an ape-like "australopithecus", or a rat-like "repenomamus", etc.
A machine that can listen to human speech and put it down in writing. This was sci-fi in the 60s but is by-and-by and more becoming reality.

examples.examples: Roberta Lincoln had trouble coming to grips with her hands-off typewriter in tos2x26 "Assignment: Earth".

description: There is technology which can transfer the consciousness of a dying person into a simulated reality where they can live on after their body ceases to function.

notes.notes: This theme is not used when the portrayed transfer is featured as some sort of cloning process that creates an independent duplicate of a person.

description: A real person has been copied so that a facsimile of them now exists in a computer simulation.

This is the category of transnational social issues that centre on the peaceful interaction between sovereign factions in the form of discussion, trade, and posturing - as opposed to threats and brute force.

examples.examples: "peace process" and "diplomatic negotiating" are examples of "diplomacy" themes.

description: The question of when to use peaceful diplomacy and when to resort to brute force is featured.
A character is able to shoot energy beams, usually out of their hands or eyes, in a controlled manner.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to own body

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to own body

examples.examples: In X-men (2000), Cyclops emitted powerful beams of energy from his eyes that he could not control without the aid of special glasses.

description: A parent disapproves of the actions and decisions a child of theirs make, as so often happens.
A person in charge is confronted by insubordination and tries to do something about it.
The subtle question of how best to teach a child self-discipline, appropriate obedience, and how to punish transgressions.

examples.examples: Worf gave Alexander a stern talking to for having pocketed a lizard model on a school field trip in tng5x10 "New Ground".

description: Someone in a leadership position weighs what balance of flexibility and friendliness they should adopt vs. how much hard discipline to impose.
Someone realizes they are good at something they had not previously considered as a skill in their possession.
The ramifications of discrimination in society are explored.

examples.examples: The telekinetically endowed Platonians treated the dwarf Alexander as a second class citizen because he did not have any mental powers in tos3x12 "Plato's Stepchildren".

description: A severed head is kept alive, and perhaps placed inside a jar.
Someone realizes that something they had previously believed in is not so great after all.
A romantic relationship breaks down and becomes dysfunctional in one of the many ways such a thing can happen.
A chamber with the capability to make its contents, for all intents and purposes, vanish into thin air.

theme_name: displacement by a rising new species
description: A new species evolves, or otherwise appears, and overthrows the civilization of the current dominant species on a world. The new species is also native to that world.

parents.parents: force of nature existential risk to civilization

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

examples.examples: Dr. Otto Hasslein was convinced that apes were destined to become intelligent and supplant humankind as the dominant species on Earth in Escape from the Planet of the Apes (1971).

description: Someone is unassuming and declines attention for themselves.

examples.examples: Worf reluctantly participated in a surprise birthday party held in his honor in tng7x11 "Parallels".

description: Diversity in society is contrasted with unity in society. Social "diversity" is the quality of people being and thinking in many different ways while social "unity" is the exact opposite. Either can be a strength and either can be a weakness.

The well known strategy of gaining and maintaining power by breaking up larger concentrations of power into pieces that individually have less power than the one implementing the strategy, is demonstrated.

The attempt to gain insight into a question or situation by way of an occultic, standardized process or ritual, is featured. This may involve reading entrails, reading stars, using knuckle bones, tarot cards, ouija boards etc.
There is a mentally impaired character who is considered blessed or otherwise holy, by some religious doctrines.

examples.examples: In "Andrei Rublev" (1968), we heard that Durochka had nothing to fear from the rambunctious Tartars that carried her off because she would be considered a holy fool by them.

description: It is suggested that a misfortune befalling someone, a group, or a society, is in fact a punishment from God for something that was done.
A character is visited by a deity, for example in a dream or a vision, and receives some sort of revelation.
Two characters who were formally married go through a divorce.
The legal niceties required in order for a married couple to be formally divorced, are featured.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected7x13 "The Reconciliation", various complications involved in obtaining a divorce in the UK were explained to James by his lawyer.

description: The idea of using DNA, which encodes the genetic instructions used in the development of functioning of all known organisms, to encode a conventional message.

examples.examples: A secret message was found encoded in pieces in the DNA of numerous separate humanoid alien species in tng6x20 "The Chase".

description: The interpersonal relationship between a doctor and their patient is examined.

notes.notes: As doctors and patients are rather common occurrences in stories, this theme should only be used if the relationship in question has a notable and lasting quality. Usually, the doctor is expected to be self-conscious of the relationship.

description: A doctor and their patient engage in a romantic relationship, and the befuddling dilemmas that come with it. Can a besotted doctor still give good medical advice?
Discussed is whether it is ethically right sometimes for a doctor to assist life-weary patients in committing suicide.

examples.examples: Worf longed for somebody to pull the plug on him after he was paralyzed as the result of a freak accident in tng5x16 "Ethics".

description: It is discussed what should be done when there is disagreement between doctors and their patient's next of kin, in some important choice the patient is incapable of making.
We are asked to what extent a doctor must respect the wishes of the patient, their next of kin or guardians in case of a minor, when those wishes are seen as being against the good of the patient.
It is discussed when, if ever, a doctor is ethically obligated to divulge confidential information about their patient without the patient's consent.
A city protected by some manner of a dome-shaped barrier.

examples.examples: The Enterprise-D was diverted to save a doomed domed city of genetically engineered colonists in tng5x13 "The Masterpiece Society".

description: A crime involving violence or other abuse by one person against another in a domestic setting, such as in marriage or cohabitation, is featured.
A character murders a person to whom they are formally subordinate and ought in principle be loyal to.

examples.examples: In "Throne of Blood" (1957), Washizu and Asaji murdered their liege lord Tsuzuki in order to usurp his position.

theme_name: donating an organ to save a life
description: A character chooses to donate an organ of their own in order to save someone else's life.
There are two characters who are biologically unrelated yet carry such a remarkable resemblance that one could readily impersonate the other.

examples.examples: In ahp1x10 "The Case of Mr. Pelham", a twin double is gradually taking over Mr. Pelman's life.

description: The art of using relatively dry instruments such as pens and crayons (but not paint) to create images on a surface such as paper or a computer display.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

description: A device used to record and replay your dreams.

examples.examples: The holodeck was employed to monitor Data's dreams in tng7x06 "Phantasms".

description: A character is able to enter a dream world and consciously observe or interact with it. The dreamworld is shown as being more real than our conventional understanding of dreams. The dream world could be created by the character, another character, or exist independently of people.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to own mind

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to own mind

description: A character uses a chemical substance (e.g. alcohol, tobacco, hallucinogens, or narcotics) to such an extent and frequency that it becomes a problem for them and others.
There is a world in which stability is maintained thanks to one or more drugs that keep people under control, perhaps by making them feel perpetually happy.
The military supplies addictive drugs to their own fighters in order to make them pliant.

The offense of driving, operating, or being in control of a vehicle while impaired by alcohol or other drugs (including recreational drugs and those prescribed by physicians), to a level that renders the driver incapable of operating a motor vehicle safely, is featured.
There is a pretty, young woman is profoundly ignorant and shows no interest in intellectual pursuits.

examples.examples: Gary Seven's secretary, Roberta Lincoln, epitomized the ditsy blonde stereotype in tos2x26 "Assignment: Earth".

description: Someone is primarily interested in sports and sports culture, and does not take much interest in intellectual culture. This is the male equivalent of the ditzy blond blond stereotype.

examples.examples: The Ghostbusters' secretary Kevin Beckman exemplified the male equivalent of a stereotypical dumb blond in "Ghostbusters" (2016).

description: This franchise sprung from the 1974 tabletop role-playing game is directly featured or parodied.
The technology to duplicate a person, or at least a person's mind.
We are asked whether an excuse like "I was merely following orders" is acceptable in some scenario where something illegal or unethical has been perpetrated.

aliases.aliases: superior orders defense Nuremberg defense just following orders

description: The idea, found in some legal codes, that a person sometimes has a legal duty to come to the rescue of another person is discussed.

examples.examples: In "Vertigo" (1958), detective John Ferguson attends a hearing regarding Madeleine's death. The judge chastises John for the various ways in which John failed to intervene, and laments that the law unfortunately doesn't have much to say about actions never taken.

description: The idea, found in some law codes, that the finder of a piece of presumably lost property has a duty to do something in order to return it to the rightful owner, is featured.
Someone is forced to choose between following their duty on the one hand, and acting to help a fellow being out of compassion on the other.
Someone is forced to choose between acting in accord with their duty, and acting in accord with their conscience.
A character is forced to choose between following their duty, and acting to further some goal of their own.
Someone is forced to choose between opposing groups.
Someone is forced to choose between following their duty, and helping a friend.

examples.examples: In tos1x13 "The Galileo Seven", Captain Kirk was torn between his duty to the Federation to deliver medicine on the one hand, and his duty to continue his search for Spock on the other.

description: Someone is forced to choose between following their duty, and following their heart.

examples.examples: The allasomorph princess Salia chose the office of head of state of the planet Daled IV over Wesley in tng2x10 "The Dauphin".

description: Someone is forced to choose between following their duty, and saving their own skin.
The sun to a planet becomes colder and civilization collapses.

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

description: A character grows up in a family under conditions that professionals would probably describe as dysfunctional. This typically involves some amount of psychological problems.

examples.examples: Beverly in "It" (1990) had a physically abusive father and later in life find herself drawn to other abusive men against her better judgment.

description: A truly enormous, hollow sphere constructed around a star to capture its entire energy output.

examples.examples: Scotty was found to have crash landed on the outer shell of a Dyson sphere in tng6x04 "Relics".

description: There is a functioning society that is nevertheless for some reason depressing and horrifying to contemporary eyes.
The unscientific notion that the sensation that an event currently being experienced has happened in the past means it did in fact happen in the past.

examples.examples: Beverly and her poker buddies experienced dÃ©jÃ  vu when they got stuck in a time loop in tng5x18 "Cause and Effect".

description: A computer, i.e. a machine that is programmed to carry out sequences of arithmetic operations, of the sort that was used by large organizations and was around before PCs and The Internet began becoming commonplace in households, is featured.

notes.notes: As a general rule of thumb, this category includes machines made before the 1990s and excludes such machines that may be called "PCs".
