There is an otherwise ordinary painting which is surreptitiously inhabited by a supernatural being. Typically the being is the spirit of someone who has died.

examples.examples: Vigo the Carpathian haunted an eerie painting of himself in "Ghostbusters II" (1989).

description: There is a vehicle, for example a car, to which a ghost or suchlike spirit is attached.

examples.examples: In tz1985e2x09a "Joy Ride", a group of teenagers come across a car owned by a recently deceased neighbor. Alas, the car had been involved in a brutal police murder and its putative passengers are brought into a ghostly reenactment of that bloody drama.

theme_name: having a baby out of wedlock
description: Having a baby out of wedlock is featured in such a way that it is clear the practice is at odds with prevailing societal norms.
Someone is made to question beliefs they had previously taken for granted.

theme_name: having a skeleton in the closet
description: A character thinks about a dark and old, possibly incriminating, secret they are keeping from everyone else, or at least from the general public.
A surgical procedure to transplant a head from one person to another is featured.
A character is able to cause another person's injuries to heal with preternatural rapidity.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to another being

examples.examples: E.T. healed Elliot's finger after Elliot cut it on a saw blade in "E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" (1984).

description: The story discusses how societies come to terms (or not) with what has happened after a great social upheaval such as was World War 2.

The various ways people may receive medical attention when they need it, is discussed. Typically, the workings of an institution that provides such care is featured. For example, we may see a dysfunctional publicly run healthcare program, or substandard helathcare provided by greedy private doctors.

examples.examples: In "Red Beard" (1965), the eponymous doctor is in charge of an overloaded and underfunded rural medical clinic in 19th century Edo Japan. We see the plight of the various patients and, even though this is set over a century in the past, must reflect on how healthcare provision works or ought to work.

description: The ramifications of people receiving different quality of medical care depending on social status are explored.

A character hears, and perhaps talks back to, a voice of a separate entity which the character incorrectly thinks is real. In clinical terms the condition might be classified as auditory hallucinations, or schizophrenia.

notes.notes: The theme does not apply when a character merely has an internal dialog with their own id. Nor does it apply in fantastical situations where the origin of the voice is understood to be through telepathy, produced by spirits, or the like. There's a variety of stories where the question of whether the voice is real or not (and thus the sanity of the character) itself is a central topic: in this case the theme applies inasmuch the idea implied in the definition is entertained as a possibility.

examples.examples: tz1959e5x05 "The Last Night of a Jockey", Grady was being taunted the alter ego in his head which offered to fulfill his any wish. In the end we are left wondering whether the voice was a real entity, or Grady had gone mad.

description: A procedure to transplant a living, beating heart from one person to another is featured.

examples.examples: Zachary Wheeler was transplanted with a heart that was harvested from a clone produced from his own DNA in "The Resurrection of Zachary Wheeler" (1971).

description: A character is driven by the pursuit of physical pleasure.

examples.examples: The Edo were quickly revealed to be full-blown sexual hedonists in tng1x08 "Justice".

theme_name: hell hath no fury like a woman scorned
description: The Shakespearian observation that many women take extraordinarily badly to being rejected by someone they are romantically interested in, is put forth.
A character goes out of their way in order to help a stranger who appears to be in some need of help.
A church or religious organization clamps down on people who hold a belief or theory that is strongly at variance with established beliefs or customs.

examples.examples: The EMCOM mainframe computer master program coerced its programs to renounce their belief in the the existence "Users" (i.e. the humans software engineers who coded them) in "Tron" (1982).

description: The way in which groups can come to excessively admire certain individuals is featured.
A hero returns home to his community after a long and arduous adventure.
Good deeds are made at great personal risk or great personal sacrifice.
The idea that someone can be cursed with, for example, ill-fortune is featured.
Combatants have a military advantage by being at a greater elevation than their opponent. Typically the elevated side gain visibility and can use gravity to their advantage.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk was climbing a mountain in tos1x19 "Arena". Why was he climbing a mountain? To gain a high ground advantage over a Gorn captain against whom he was pitted in a fight to the death.

description: A member of a faction decides to take up the cause of an enemy faction against their own.

Some variant of the philosophical concept of determinism is discussed. Determinism is the idea that events can only unfold in a certain way given the preceding state of things; thus history (past, present and future) is fixed and "free will" is perhaps but an illusion.
A character from real human history is discussed or otherwise featured.

notes.notes: The story must clearly identify the character in question, but there is no requirement that it be otherwise "correct" in what it has to say.

description: Some group in society seek to rewrite history in a way that makes it more advantageous to them. This typically involves glossing over inconvenient truths as well as outright lying.

This is the category of themes that discuss the study of history, or historical events as they are commonly understood. For example, the themes may present a reasonable idea of how a historical event might have transpired, what a time and place in history might have been like for its inhabitants, or what a historical figure might have been like.
Someone or some institution propagates a falsehood deliberately fabricated to masquerade as the truth.

examples.examples: NASA faked a manned mission to Mars in "Capricorn One" (1978).

theme_name: holding someone captive to protect them
description: We are made to ponder whether and to what extent it is ethically justifiable to hold someone against their will if doing so is for the sake of their own safety.

examples.examples: In tz1985e2x05 "The Toys of Caliban", we saw an elderly married couple who were raising their intellectually disabled son Toby in seclusion because he had a dangerous magical ability but no self-restraint or sense to conduct himself safely with his power.

description: The discredited theory proposing that planets, like the Earth, are entirely hollow or contain substantial interior spaces is featured.
An asteroid has been turned into a living space suitable for humans.
There is technology that can create three-dimensional images in space.

notes.notes: Hologram-like special effects are frequently used in modern sci-fi movies. This theme should be used only if the holograms are explicitly discussed or are significant to the story.

examples.examples: In pkded1x10 "Kill All Others", Philbert is rather put off when he finds his wife sharing the sofa with a hologram of a sexy foreign man selling coffee.

description: A character is distressed on account that they are away from their home. The affected character may be taking a short trip to a nearby place, such as summer camp, or they may be taking a long trip or have even moved to a different country.
There is a young person who neglects doing their homework in favor of a more appealing activity.
A child must choose what is more important to them: boring homework or frivolous play.

examples.examples: Alexander was very much swayed by Lwaxana's arguments for choosing play over homework in tng5x20 "cost of Living".

description: Discussed is the evolutionary process that led to the emergence of anatomically modern humans.
We are asked to what extent, if any, homosexuality should be tolerated in society and how homosexual people ought to be treated.
A stereotypically truthful and sincere character is contrasted with a stereotypically mendacious and false character.

examples.examples: In "His Girl Friday" (1940), the blue eyed and sincere insurance salesman Bruce Baldwin is contrasted with his fiancÃ©e's ex-husband Walter Burns, who is a scrupulous, lying rogue working as news paper editor.

description: Someone displays notable truthfulness and lack of deceit.

A character steadfastly sticks to a traditional moral code in spite of temptation to do otherwise. It nearly always has to do with being honest and defending ones reputation. It very often involves Klingons.

examples.examples: Worf, being a true man of honor, implored the Klingon authorities to grant honorable deaths to three Klingon renegades whom he had come to respect in tng1x20 "Heart of Glory".

description: A character contemplates committing suicide because doing otherwise would lead to some form of dishonor for themself and possibly their family.
A character feels that events they wish for may come about.

Horse racing is an equestrian performance sport, typically involving two or more  horses ridden by jockeys (or sometimes driven without riders) over a set distance, for competition. This theme is used whenever this time-honored sport is notably featured in the story.
The excitement some of us experience by engaging in equestrian escapades is examined.

examples.examples: Captain Picard shared his passion for riding Arabian horses with Troi on the holodeck in tng2x15 "Pen Pals".

description: Someone is very hospitable towards their guests.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk held a banquet for Khan Singh to welcome the former dictator of Earth to the 23rd century in tos1x24 "Space Seed".

description: There is a skateboard-like device without wheels that hovers at a constant altitude of up to some feet above the ground and used for personal transportation.

examples.examples: Marty McFly got into a hoverboard chase in the year 2015 in "Back to the Future Part II" (1989).

theme_name: how to commit a crime and get away with it
description: We are made to ponder clever ways in which one might commit one crime or another, and avoid getting caught.

notes.notes: This theme is not used in extraordinary circumstances, such as in the wake of a general disaster, where the opportunity might present itself through mere chance.

description: We are shown how one may, credibly, gain access to the contents of a safe without having the key or combination required to legitimately open it.

parents.parents: how to commit a crime and get away with it

ancestors.ancestors: how to commit a crime and get away with it

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected5x03 "Operation Safecrack", the (in)famous safe-cracker Sam Morrissey takes on a PR stunt challenge by an advertising company to break into the latest model of their safe. Sam attempts to do so using a variety of strategies, heavy machines, and explosives.

theme_name: how to handle a hostage situation
description: Featured is the dilemma of whether and how to negotiate with hostage takers.

notes.notes: Hostage situations are typically when someone holds innocent people at gunpoint and threatens to execute them unless certain demands are met. Especially in fiction, hostage situations may also arise when terrorists have planted bombs or designed doomsday weapons that threaten buildings, cities, countries, or entire planets.

examples.examples: Captain Picard negotiated to free Beverly from the clutches of terrorists in tng3x12 "The High Ground", but ended up himself a hostage.

theme_name: how to murder someone and get away with it
description: We are made to ponder clever ways in which one might commit murder and avoid getting caught.

notes.notes: This theme is not used in extraordinary circumstances, such as on a battlefield, where the opportunity might present itself through mere chance.

parents.parents: how to commit a crime and get away with it

ancestors.ancestors: how to commit a crime and get away with it

theme_name: how to rob a bank and get away with it
description: We are made to ponder clever ways in which one may steal large amounts of money from a bank (or comparable venue) and avoid getting caught.

parents.parents: how to commit a crime and get away with it

ancestors.ancestors: how to commit a crime and get away with it

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected5x06 "The Moles", two old friends whose business faced financial ruin hatched a clever plan to tunnel their way into a certain bank vault from an antique shop adjacent to it.

theme_name: how to treat people that pose a risk to society through no fault of their own
description: Some people are innocent of any wrongdoing yet pose a danger to public safety for one reason or another; are we socially justified in killing these people in order to defend ourselves?
Pride is so excessive that a character deigns to put themself on par, or even above, the gods.

examples.examples: Riker was riding on his high horse after having been granted Q powers in tng1x10 "Hide and Q".

description: Despite adverse consequences to themself, a character compulsively engages in an activity that results in rewarding stimuli. In medical terms, addiction is disorder of the brain's reward system.

examples.examples: Typically "human addiction" is connected to substance abuse, such as the case with "alcoholism" and "drug addiction". Other forms of addiction include "video game addiction", or "workaholism", although these examples may not be addictions in the clinical sense.

description: A romantic relationship between a real person and an artificial person is featured.
A basic human hope, dream, or the question of what we want out of life is featured.
Industrially relevant amounts of electrical energy are somehow extracted from human beings.

examples.examples: Intelligent machines partially powered their machine civilization by extracting electrical energy from unconscious humans kept in pods in "The Matrix" (1999).

description: The scientific study of the morphology of the human body is featured.

Some aspect of the science of blood types is explained. Popularly, this is the classification system O-, O+, A-, A+, and so forth (eight categories) or simply O, A, B, AB (four categories). However, other systems are in use as well.
Someone is faced with a problem or adversity such as we might plausible face in the course of a typical human life.

examples.examples: "human challenge in life" often revolve around "facing death" or "facing adversity", but may also involve any of a mishmash of troubles categorized under "coping with life issues".

description: This is the category of themes that examine character types and personal character traits.

notes.notes: Character themes apply only if the behavior is explicitly discussed or made more-or-less pantomimically obvious.

examples.examples: "courage", "cowardice", "misanthropy", and "chivalry" are all "human character" themes because they refer to personal character traits such as we may variously admire or abhor in people.

description: There is a person whose character fits a recognizable, well-defined, stereotype to a remarkable degree.
This is the category of themes that illustrate and contrast two or more different personalities.

examples.examples: "extrovert vs. introvert" is a theme that compares and contrasts outgoing characters with inwards looking characters.

description: Featured is one of the various problems someone may face during the early parts of their life, i.e., childhood and adolescence.

examples.examples: "sibling rivalry" and "teenage angst" are two "human childhood" themes that most people experience as they grow up. "orphanhood" is a "human childhood" theme that only a few people are unfortunate to experience in real life.

description: The technology to create new individuals that have the same DNA as an original, but not necessarily have anything else in common.
We are asked to what extent, if any, the cloning of human beings is acceptable.
This is the category of themes that present a human reflecting on what was, what could have been, what might be, what could never be, and so on and so forth.

examples.examples: "human dreaming" themes tend to involve fantasies or reminiscence. An illustrative example is "thinking about one's accomplishments in life" when a character reflects on their achievements (or lack thereof).

description: Someone experiences, intensely, one of those conscious inner mental states that we call emotions.

examples.examples: "hope" and "jealousy" are illustrative examples of "human emotion" themes.

description: A character struggles with undesirable emotional consequences stemming from some practicality of living, such as any of us might experience during the course of our duration on Earth.

notes.notes: Themes in this category generally apply when the emotions are more central to the story than is whatever may have caused the emotions.

examples.examples: "coping with having a bad day" is a "human emotional issue" as the character in question is generally concerned with their own state of mind and may have little expection that they can do much about whatever situation made the day bad.

description: The way humans tend to feel particular empathy for babies is noted.
A novel technology is used to enhance (or diminish depending on one's point of view) a person's physical ability.
This is the category of themes that deal with the interpersonal relationship between two somewhat closely related characters, i.e., "family".

notes.notes: Any defined character relationship can be familial if it is clearly considered as such in a story and if it is sufficiently relevant to the plot. It may be noted that while there are many stories in which parental, sibling, half- sibling, step-parent, sibling-in-law, or even adoptive relationships are important, there are few stories in which consanguinity relations beyond first cousinage is relevant to the plot.

examples.examples: "guardian and child" is a "human familial relationship" because the guardian is typically expected to take on the role of a parent even if they are not related to the child by blood.

description: This is the category of themes that discuss human mental and physiological well-being. It is usually done with respect to some factor, such as disease or infirmity, that is seen as detrimental to a human's well-being.

examples.examples: Disease, illness, and injury are disagreeable but prominent components of human lives and frequently featured in fiction. For example "coping with a terminal illness" and "coping with aging" are found in this category.

description: This is the category of themes that seek to illustrate some generality about what human life may be like. For example, the themes may be practical advice on how one ought to lead ones life. Many of these themes are tidbits of folksy wisdom summed up in readily recognizable pithy aphorisms.

examples.examples: "appearances can be deceiving", "beauty is in the eye of the beholder", and "fortune favors the bold" are examples of general ideas about life expressed as well known aphorisms.

description: This is the category of themes that relate to what it is like for a human to find themselves in a dangerous situation of one sort or another.

examples.examples: "coping with being injured" is a "human in danger" theme as it describes what it is like for someone to be in a certain risky situation.

description: This is the category of themes that relate to the relationship between two or (occasionally) more people at a time.

examples.examples: "romantic relationship", "friendship", "neighbor and noeighbor", and "human familial relationship" are all examples of "human interpersonal relationship" themes.

description: A character is made to reflect on a tough decision that involve choices that are hard, not because of ethical issues or uncertainty regarding the outcome, but because the decision that will have a major impact on the course of their life. A typical example is "career choice".

examples.examples: "human life choice" themes include "adopting a child", "choosing between love and family", "deciding whether to be a parent", "figuring out what to do with one's life", and "to settle down vs. to keep on trekking".

description:
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in the world between the beginning of recorded history (with the emergence of writing) and the middle ages.

Typical characteristics include polytheism.

notes.notes: This is roughly taken as 3000 BC until 500 CE but varies slightly depending on location.

theme_name: human life in early modern times
description:
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in the world around the Age of Discovery and the Renaissance in Europe but before the the Industrial revolution.

Typical characteristics include long distance sea faring in wooden vessels relying on the winds for locomotion.

notes.notes: This is roughly taken as 1450 CE to 1750 CE but varies slightly depending on location.

aliases.aliases: life in the Age of Sail

description: We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in Africa in the past.
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in Asia in the past.
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in Australia in the past.
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in Britain in the past.
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in Europe in the past.

theme_name: human life in historical North America
description: We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in North America in the past.

theme_name: human life in historical South America
description: We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in South America in the past.
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in the world in the past.

notes.notes: If there is conflict between the nature of civilization in a story and the time/location the story itself professes to take place, the nature of civilization in the story should be used to determine which history theme is relevant. The precise dating of these time periods is therefore of lesser importance to the categorization of stories.
If the story is still ambiguous, do not expend energy debating the point but include all seemingly applicable themes.

It is suggested to use these themes as Major only when the story clearly depicts something that can be considered a reasonable image of normal life for some relatively normal category of people. If the focus of the story is, for example, a heroic figure doing something heroic then the social setting in which it takes place may likely be a Minor theme, if a theme at all.

theme_name: human life in late modern times
description:
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in the world from around the Industrial Revolution until the end of the Second World War.

Typical characteristics include seafaring vessels made of metal and using combustion rather than wind for propulsion.

notes.notes: This is roughly taken as 1750 CE to 1945 CE but varies slightly depending on location.

description:
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in the world around the times known as the Middle Ages.

Typical characteristics include an emphasis on monotheistic religious authority and a lack of speedy long distance travel such as became possible first in the Age of Discovery.

notes.notes: This is roughly taken as 500 BC to 1450 CE but varies slightly depending on location. The European Middle Ages have been defined as starting with the fall of the Roman Empire in the 5th century and ending with the fall of Constantinople in 1453.

description:
We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in the world after the Second World War, i.e., after 1945.

Typical characteristics include references to World War II as being in the past.

We see a reasonable idea of what ordinary human life might have been like for some category of people somewhere in the world prior to the invention of writing systems.

Typical characteristics include tools made of stone and a lack of metals.

notes.notes: This is roughly taken as being before 3000 BC but varies slightly depending on location.

aliases.aliases: human life in the stone age

description: This is the subcategory of "human health condition" themes that relate to the mind.

examples.examples: "depression", "despair", "persecution complex", "schizophrenia", and "suppressed emotion" are all "human mental condition" themes that are featured in stories from time to time.

description: The distinguishing characteristics - including ways of thinking, feeling, and acting - which humans tend to have naturally.
The things we humans tend to need in order to consider ourselves healthy, content, and fulfilled in life.
A character is notably engaged in their chosen occupation.
The social and environmental ramifications of an ever increasing human population are discussed. Perhaps we will multiply beyond Earth's capability to sustain our present way of life.
A problem or situation that may arise in the interaction between parents and their progeny is featured.
A character displays a persistent and excessive fear to a specific object or situation.

examples.examples: "arachnophobia", the fear of spiders, and "fear of doctors" are both "human phobia" themes that may be used when a character portrays an excessive and persistent fear of the subject in question.

description: This is the category of themes that relate to a person's physiological needs. I.e., the need for things like food, water, sleep, and (in some sense) sex.

examples.examples: "the need for rest and recreation" is a "human physiological need" because a character who is sufficiently overworked and tired becomes incapable of considering higher order needs such as staying out of harm's way.

description: A character takes marked pleasure in an activity such as a hobby.
This is the category of themes that contain various purposeful regular activities that humans may be engaged in. Such activities are typically occupations or hobbies.

This is the category of themes that discusses issues that relate to whatever people typically like to label as human rights. It may, for example, involve practical concerns around safeguarding such rights, discuss ethical questions around what counts as a right, or weight two conflicting human rights considerations in a particular situation.

Examples of rights and freedoms which are often thought of as human rights include civil and political rights, such as the right to life, liberty, and property, freedom of expression, pursuit of happiness and equality before the law; and social, cultural and economic rights, including the right to participate in science and culture, the right to work, and the right to education.

examples.examples: "homosexuality in society" is a "human rights issue" because an overwhelming number of people now believe that systematically discriminated against someone on account of their sexuality would be an infringement on that person's rights.

description: A character must make a choice regarding whether and whom to devote themself romantically to.

examples.examples: "human romantic relationship choice" themes include "love vs. career", "monogamy vs. single life", and "choosing between lovers".

description: The act of killing humans, usually as an offering to a deity, as part of a ritual is featured.
This is the category of themes that relate to human's need to feel safe from danger of all kinds, including physical, financial, and health risks.

examples.examples: "attachment to one's livelihood" is a "human safety need" because loosing one's job may (at least historically) lead to poverty, then starvation and death. "the need for privacy" is also a "human safety need" because a lack of privacy could lead to the publication of facts about us that jeopardize our social standing which might (historically) lead to ostracization, then death in any number of ways.

description: A character in the story contemplates their own person and some way in which they can better themself.

examples.examples: "lesson in humility" is a "human self improvement" theme because it implies that a previously arrogant character has been forced to reconsider their attitude. "questioning one's loyalties" is of the same category because a character has come to see that what they are doing is perhaps not right, and that they should change.

description: This is the category of themes about human needs that specifically deal with an individual's desire to grow as a person and to realize their full potential.

examples.examples: "the need for a challenge in life" is a "human self-actualization need" theme because the reason people seek out things that challenge them is, generally, that through challenges we learn and grow as people.

description: This is the category of themes that examine a person's ego needs, i.e., the need for things like recognition, status, importance, and respect from others.

examples.examples: "the desire for fame" and "the need to feel useful to society" are "human self-esteem need" themes as they express a human's need or desire for some form of recognition from others.

description: A character helps another character, or cause, at a significant cost or risk to themself.
Someone goes significantly out of their way in order to help another person who is need of something.

notes.notes: Typically, this situation occurs when a character risks life and limb in order to save another character from the same sort of dangers.

examples.examples: "donating an organ to save a life" is a typical "human self-sacrifice for another" theme since giving up an organ is quite risky but will likely save the life of the other character.

description: The idea that human men and/or women emit chemicals that attract the opposite sex is featured. Despite numerous studies there is no evidence for anything that does so to any significant extent.
The mating urges and rituals of homo sapient are discussed in a philosophical manner.

Armed forces are deliberately using civilians (whether their own, their enemy's, or otherwise) to make it hard for their opponent to strike at a military target without causing casualties among said civilians.
This is the category themes that relate to a persons need to have good connections with other people, i.e., belonging to a social group, having friends, family, etc.

examples.examples: "the desire to be liked", "the need for cultural heritage", and "the need to belong" are concrete examples of "human social needs". The category also contains relate more indirectly to these themes, for example "the desire for justice".

description: This is the category of themes that examine a character's status within a society of which they are part.

examples.examples: "coping with being a laughing stock" is a "human social position" theme because it deals with an event of which the main feature is that a character's status in a group is lowered.

description: This is the category of themes that deal with introspection, i.e., a character pondering their own person.

examples.examples: "human self improvement" is the main sub-category of "human thinking about self" because most often when a character is considering themself it seems they do so with a desire to improve on themself.

description: There is an "information" virus that can invade the thought processes of a human and transmit itself to other humans by means of communication. It is thus more like a computer virus than a biological virus, except in that it infects biological information systems rather than machines.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x21a "Need to Know", we saw how people in a little village started going insane one after the other because of a confounding and viral idea about the meaning of life, that was whispered by an infected person to someone who would become the next victim in turn.

description: A character struggles with a decision that must made.

examples.examples: This category of themes, so common in fiction, is further subdivided into: "human life choice" (a character struggles with a decision regarding how to live their life), "human self-sacrifice" (a character must choose or not to risk themselfs for the sake of another), "personal ethical dilemma" (a struggle with morals), and "personal practical dilemma " (the choice is hard more because of uncertainty than for moral or personal considerations).

description: A character struggles to overcome an affliction, like a disease, a disorder, or something else that causes pain and suffering.
A struggle between human and animal is featured.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk was mauled by a Mugato tos2x16 "A Private Little War".

description: A struggle between captive and captor is featured.

examples.examples: Butthead aliens held Captain Pike captive with the intention to use him as breeding stock in tos0x01 "The Cage".

description: This is the category of themes that describe a conflict situation between a person and other people.

examples.examples: "facing a mortal enemy", "facing organized pursuit", and "human vs. captivity" is a selection of themes that describe a situation wherein a person is in conflict with other people.

description: A character is confronted with problematic happenings that seem to defy explanation or categorization in any meaningful way.

notes.notes: This theme does notably not apply in the case of events for which the character can perceive reasonable sounding possible explanations. It is meant to capture things that just don't any make sense. However, if mysterious events are cause by spirits or the like, the theme "human vs. the occult" is normally used instead.

examples.examples: In tz1959e1x34 "The After Hours", Marsha grew increasingly puzzled after she purchased a gold thimble on the 9th floor of a department that had only eight floors.

description: A character experiences what it is like to face an entire institution, like the secret police, that is out to get them.
A character encounters a labyrinthine and overpowering bureaucracy so extreme that it beggars belief.

examples.examples: Eponymous Franz Kafka describes such a bureaucracy in "The Trial" (1925), wherein Josef K struggles to descry what crime he has been charged with, and to meet the various impossible demands made on him by a remote and faceless judiciary.

description: A struggle between human an monster is featured. Monster, in this case, means a grotesque version of man or animal of a sort typically only exists in stories.

notes.notes: Use man vs. animal if the struggle is with a relatively ordinary animal.

description: A human struggle to survive the elements is featured. This could be about surviving in blistering cold, scorching heat, raging wind, etc.

examples.examples: Sulu nearly froze to death of Alfa 177 during a geological survey gone wrong in tos1x04 "The Enemy Within".

description: A character must overcome an internal struggle within themself.
There is a struggle between a human and a (more or less) sentient machine.

notes.notes: There is no clear definition for what machines are to be considered sentient. As a rule of thumb, this theme applies if the machine takes complex actions with high-level motivations such as self-preservation, or vengeance. It certainly applies if the machine exhibits any sort of human-like personality.

examples.examples: The Enterprise-D crew members were almost overwhelmed by the autonomous planetary defense system of Minosian design in tng1x21 "The Arsenal of Freedom".

description: A character struggles to survive contact with a space anomaly of some kind.

examples.examples: Beverly became trapped in a collapsing warp bubble universe in tng4x05 "Remember Me".

description: A conflict between a person and technology is featured.
A human fights supernatural forces, e.g., ghosts.

examples.examples: All manner of hocus-pocus abounded in tos2x01 "Catspaw".

description: A struggle between a human and an animal equipped with poison dangerous to said human, is featured.
There is a struggle between man and zombie.
This is the category of themes that deal with the various ideas people may have about how they want to lead their lives.

notes.notes: Sometimes a person's idea about how they should lead their life involves ideas about how other people ought to lead their lives as well. This category may overlap with that of political ideologies.

examples.examples: "carpe diem", "pacifism", and "vegetarianism" are all "human way of life" themes because they imply lifestyles such as we may choose to lead for one reason or another.

description: This is the category of themes that deal with the various concerns a person may have when thinking about their own condition.

examples.examples: "second guessing one's self" and "beating one's self up " are "human worrying about self" type themes because they imply that a person is being dissatisfied with their own decisions in some way.

description: There is a part human, part alien being.
There is a being that incorporates elements from both humans and at least one non-human animal.
There being that is part human and part insect or creature that resembles an insect.
There is a part human, part dog being.
There is a part human, part fish being.

examples.examples: Fallout from a nuclear holocaust caused a man to develop some fish features, including a dorsal fin and tuna-blue skin, in "Endgame" (1983).

description: People create a dangerous pathogen, typically for the purpose of war, but it gets out of control and kills everyone.

examples.examples: The inhabitants of Earth Two sought to increase their lifespan but instead released an infectious virus that quickly killed off all adults in tos1x11 "Miri".

description: There is a part human, part plant being.

examples.examples: Professor Nolter crossed a human being with a plant in "The Mutations" (1974).

description: There is a part human, part reptile being.

examples.examples: Dr. Curt Connors transformed himself into a lizard-man with super regenerative capabilities in "The Amazing Spider-Man" (2012).

description: The idea is featured that mankind must, needs, deserves, or can (etc. etc.) somehow be the arbiter of its own fate as opposed to being steered by a deity or some such more-or-less external monolith.

examples.examples: In tas2x05 "How Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth", Captain Kirk convinced Kukulkan that humankind was ready to stand on its own two feet and that Kukulkan's help in cultivating civilization was henceforth neither requested nor required.

description: An originally humanoid being has been rendered grotesque relative to the norm of its species owing to genetic mutation.
This is the category of themes that describe the experience of people as they seek to collaborate in a workplace.

examples.examples: "office politics", about intrigues in workplaces, is an oft featured theme of the "humans at work" sort.

description: This is the category of themes that examine human group dynamics, or some experience simultaneously applicable to each member of a group of people.

notes.notes: We distinguish between "individual human experience", "humans in pairs", and "humans in groups" with reference to whose experiences are relevant to the thematic idea that is being expressed. For example "coping with problematic people" clearly implies the presence of two or more people but the theme is only concerned with the experiences of a single observer at a time. "romantic relationship", on the other hand, is a category of themes that most often examine the interaction between two people and discuss both their experiences simultanously. Likewise "humans in group" imply themes that examine the constitution of a whole group of people, for example the idea that "lack of trust can lead to group dysfunction."

examples.examples: "insubordination" is considered a "humans in group" theme because even though it implies the actions of only a single person the ideas featured are typically related to how hierarchies of humans function when insubordination is either tolerated or prescribed to some extent.

description: This is the category of "humans in group" themes that relate to a hierarchical structure wherein some characters are put above and in charge of other characters.

examples.examples: "leadership" is a typical "humans in hierarchy" as a leader by definition is someone who is in charge of others, formally or informally.

description: This is the category of themes that examine the respective interactions and attitudes of two people vis-Ã -vis each other.

notes.notes: We distinguish between "individual human experience", "humans in pairs", and "humans in groups" with reference to whose experiences are relevant to the thematic idea that is being expressed. For example "coping with problematic people" clearly implies the presence of two or more people but the theme is only concerned with the experiences of a single observer at a time. "romantic relationship", on the other hand, is a category of themes that most often examine the interaction between two people and discuss both their experiences simultanously. Likewise "humans in group" imply themes that examine the constitution of a whole group of people, for example the idea that "lack of trust can lead to group dysfunction."

description: This is the category of themes that illustrate the interactions between two or more humans.

examples.examples: "clash of wills" is a "humans interacting" theme used when two characters are locked in a heated argument over some joint course of action. By contrast, "clash of Wills" is used whenever two characters who are both named Will, get locked in a heated argument over some joint course of action.

description: Someone downplays their own abilities or receives a lesson in humility that appears effective.
A character is notably and regularly engaged with the chasing down and dispatching wild animals. Typically the character is either a professional hunter, or sees hunting as a hobby.
There is an organized sport-like activity that resembles game hunting except that the targeted prey are people.

notes.notes: This theme does not normally apply when warriors hunt down and kill their enemies as part of a military campaign.

description: The relationship between husband and wife is featured.

examples.examples: Harry Mudd bickered with an android replica of his wife, Stella, in tos2x11 "I, Mudd".

description: There is a being that incorporates elements from both humans and non-humans.
Someone exhibits an abnormal anxiety about the state of their own health.
There is a character who does the opposite of what they themself preaches, to a notable degree.

examples.examples: In "Measure for Measure" (1604), Angelo has condemned Claudio to death for the offense of extramarital fornication, even though it was with a woman he loved, that loved him, and whom he intended to marry. When petitioned for leniency, Angelo orated at length about the importance of enforcing the law. Simultaneously, he used his office to pressure a young nun for extramarital sex himself.

description: A female character exhibits a stereotypical prolonged outburst of excessive emotionality, typically by screaming.
A planet becomes so cold that glaciers advance and civilization collapses.

parents.parents: force of nature existential risk to civilization

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

examples.examples: The Eymorg civilization had collapsed when they entered an ice age in tos3x06 "Spock's Brain".

description: Ice hockey is a contact team sport played on ice, usually in an indoor or outdoor rink, in which two teams of skaters use their sticks to shoot a vulcanized rubber puck into their opponent's net to score goals. This game is featured.
There is a planet that is more or less entirely covered in ice so that the whole of it resembles nothing so much as an arctic wasteland.

theme_name: if it ain't broke don't fix it
description: A character learns to avoid attempting to correct, fix, or improve what is already sufficient (often with an implication that the attempted improvement is risky and might backfire).

theme_name: if it sounds too good to be true it probably isn't true
description: The age-old adage is illustrated: If circumstances that are extremely advantageous too you manifest against the odds, you should seriously consider that someone (possibly your self) is simply deceiving you.
The old wisdom that one may be happier not knowing certain things is featured.
The ramifications of drugs and drug trade in society are explored.

examples.examples: The Brekkians found that trading a certain narcotic to the Ornarans was such a lucrative enterprise that they needed no other industry whatsoever in tng1x22 "Symbiosis".

description: The ability or inability of categories of people in a society to read and write is discussed.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected9x04 "The Verger", we saw briefly featured an adult literacy program at the local university.

description: The role culture plays in determining whether a certain condition is considered to be a disease is explored.

examples.examples: In "X-Men: The Last Stand" (2006), many mutants were horrified when a "cure" for mutancy was announced since they didn't consider mutancy as a disease to be cured, but rather a normal way of being.

description: We are asked how much immigration, if any, it is appropriate for a society to permit. One extreme is to disband all borders and the other is to build walls.
A character who doesn't age and who has lived an impossibly long time lives secretly among us run-of-the-mill mortals.

examples.examples: Flint is revealed to be an immortal human who had lived on Earth under various aliases for thousands of years in tos3x21 "Requiem for Methuselah".

description: A character is able to go on living even when other characters would have died. They typically do not age (beyond a point) or if they do, death is not inevitably at the end of that process.

notes.notes: The theme "immortality" is considered topical simply if the idea that a character may go on living indefinitely is there. Stories are surprisingly full of nominally immortal characters that nevertheless perish, one way or another.

parents.parents: what if I were not subject to the normal process of aging

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were not subject to the normal process of aging
speculative ability related to own body

examples.examples: Mr. Flynn of tos3x21 "Requiem for Methuselah", a.k.a. Methuselah, was born with that most coveted mixed blessing of all: immortality.

description: The problem of ensuring impartiality in the legal system is highlighted. We all suffer from various preconceptions and judges are no exception.
A faction systematically uses the military in order to subjugate their neighbours and expand their own power.
A character is able to withstand extreme physical effects, such as impacts or heat. They may, for example, be able to walk through flames or stand in the way of oncoming bullets, unscathed.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to own body

description: A fictional type of criminal correction that involves putting unpleasant memories into the brain of the convict, for example to let them experience what their victim may have felt.
A character has has a weapon of some sort grafted into their body by means of hitherto undeveloped cybernetic technology.
Two characters fall in love but it appears more-or-less impossible for the relationship to progress because of straightforward physical circumstances.

notes.notes: This theme is contrasted with "forbidden love", where the relationship is impeded by social circumstances.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x06b "A Message from Charity", two lonely teenagers separated by three centuries of time found themselves telepathically linked, and fell in love. Alas, as they would never be able to meet in person, the young girl from the 17th century took the tough decision to terminate their disagreeably platonic relationship.

In tz1985e3x09 "The Call", Norman fell in love with a mysterious woman he spoke to only on the phone. The sentiment was reciprocated. Unfortunately, he came to find that the woman was the spirit of a successfully suicidal artist, now inhabiting her own self-portraying statue. That would normally have spelled the end of their courtship. But fate intervened and Norman was turned into a statue of his own, dotingly contraposed with the other for eternity.

description: There is a community of people in which one seeming member is in fact not of the community, and lives within it under notably false pretenses.

examples.examples: In tz2002e1x31 "The Monsters Are on Maple Street", order in a little neighbored along the eponymous street broke down when several of the inhabitants became convinced that one of their secluded neighbors was, in fact, a foreign terrorist living there under false pretense.

theme_name: in for a penny in for a pound
description: This popular idiom is explicitly invoked or pointedly illustrated: Having started something, one must see it through to its end, rather than stopping short.

Featured is the relationship between two people who are not biologically related but who are considered kin as the result of someone's marriage. Most often this is a spouse together with one of their partner's near relatives.
Someone has no good options but must choose between doing nothing, or waste effort doing something that is most certainly pointless.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk and Commissioner Ferris debated whether to keep up the search for the Galileo shuttlecraft in tos1x13 "The Galileo Seven", even though it was almost certainly hopeless.

description: An ordinarily inanimate object moves and acts like a living being.
A male character in a relationship is inattentive to their partner's emotional needs.
Whether and to what extent people who are closely related should be allowed to have sex and procreate together is discussed.
There is a sexual relationship between two near relatives.
The trouble two intelligent beings who use entirely different approaches to communication may face in understanding each other is illustrated.
There is a being that doesn't have material a body. It may be electromagnetic patterns, or something entirely beyond our science.

examples.examples: The alien Sargon no longer needed a body at the end of tos2x22 "Return to Tomorrow".

description: There is a being that is deceased but interacts with the world in the form of a bodiless spirit.

The deliberate public exposure by a person of a portion of their body in a manner contrary to local standards of appropriate behavior is featured in a way that it is understood to be a crime in the sociocultural context of the story.
The ramifications of allowing governments to detain people indefinitely are discussed.

examples.examples: The Romulans had kept Klingon war prisoners from the Khitomer Massacre in a prison camp for many years in tng6x17 "Birthright, Part II".

description: A character is an activist for the cause of independence or autonomy of a region that is part of a political entity.
The putative rights of groups and individual claiming to belong to groups that claim to represent indigenous population in a country settled from elsewhere, are discussed.
This is the category of themes that center around an individual's personal thoughts, emotions, urges, ambitions, and other such experiences.

notes.notes: We distinguish between "individual human experience", "humans in pairs", and "humans in groups" with reference to whose experiences are relevant to the thematic idea that is being expressed. For example "coping with problematic people" clearly implies the presence of two or more people but the theme is only concerned with the experiences of a single observer at a time. "romantic relationship", on the other hand, is a category of themes that most often examine the interaction between two people and discuss both their experiences simultanously. Likewise "humans in group" imply themes that examine the constitution of a whole group of people, for example the idea that "lack of trust can lead to group dysfunction."

description: An institution (for example the government, the church, or the military) uses its powers to indoctrinate individuals into a way of thinking. For "indoctrination" to apply a certain amount of coercion and intolerance towards contrarian views is required.
The ramifications of instilling the people in a society with a biased, one- sided or uncritical ideology are explored.

examples.examples: The Cardassian military indoctrinated the Cardassian people in the virtues of the Cardassian military in tng6x11 "Chain of Command, Part II".

description: The ramification of indoctrinating a group of young people are explored.

examples.examples: Spock was unsettled to have stumbled on the fugitive Lokai indoctrinating some younger members of the crew in tos3x15 "Let That Be Your Last Battlefield".

description: A character is inebriated in a social setting.

People of different classes are treated differently in the legal system when they commit the same type of crimes. For example, a rich man may get away with murder while a poor man of an ethnic minority is sent to the gallows.
A character murders a defenseless little baby, and it is featured as being a crime.

examples.examples: In "The Winter's Tale" (1611), King Leontes ordered the newborn child he thought was his wife's bastard to be slain. Although it appeared was legally in his right to do so, being the King and slighted husband, it was also featured as being morally reprehensible and therefore a crime against the customs of society. We also know that, in the historical context, Christianity proscribed infanticide.

description: An intense but (typically) short-lived passion that may peter out or settle into more enduring romantic love.

examples.examples: Riker and Minuet enjoyed a short, but memorable, infatuation on the holodeck in tng1x15 "11001001".

description: A character experiences a lack of self-worth and possibly feelings of not measuring up to expectations.
The education system is held up as rigid and intolerable of creative thinking, something that might be an important problem for society.
The influence of the Internet, its precursors, or related technology on society is discussed.
The idea in medical ethics that to the extent possible, a patient should not be subjected to a treatment unless they have consented to it with a clear understanding of its implications.
Putative beneficiaries (usually family members) of a departed person's estate squabble over how to divide the inheritance.

notes.notes: Stories often feature such squabbling beginning well before the benefactor of the heirs apparent has had the decency to depart. This theme is applicable, for example, when children argue with their parents over how their future bequest is to be allotted.

description: We are asked to what extent descendants are answerable for the actions of their ancestors.

examples.examples: For Javier Maribona Picard's role in the reconquest of New Mexico in the 1690's, all of Captain Picard's family was deemed to wear a stain of blood until this day in tng7x20 "Journey's End".

description: A being that thrives in environments that would be startlingly inhospitable to us humans. In scorching fire, for example, or in bedrock.
There is a being that is novel by virtue of having a non-carbon-based biochemistry, e.g., crystalline beings, gaseous beings, electromagnetic beings, etc.
A being patterned after common earth insects and arachnids.
People rely on a particular way of organizing their civilization but they are either trapper in it or it has unforeseen consequences and civilization collapses.
There is a broad practice of human blood sports in society, like the gladiatorial games in Ancient Rome.
A character is wrestling with the decision of whether or not to let a near and dear person be committed to, for example, an asylum for the mentally ill.
A character fakes or deliberately causes an injury or loss of property in order to illicitly get compensation from an insurance company.

examples.examples: In "Double Indemnity" (1944), Walter and Phyllis hatch an elaborate plot to kill Phyllis' husband and claim his life insurance, which they first take out in his name but without his knowledge. They must then make the murder look like an accident, in order to trigger the indemnity clause and double the payout.

description: A character is able pass through material objects, such as walls.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to own body

examples.examples: In X2 (2003), the mutant Kitty Pride manifested an innate ability to pass through walls.

description: There is a device which confers upon its target the ability to pass unscathed through solid matter.

examples.examples: Captain Archer was able to walk through walls using a handheld device in "Star Trek: Enterprise" Cold Front (ent1x11).

description: When a character sticks to their moral principles in spite of temptation to do otherwise.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk unhesitatingly refused Korob's offers of tasty foods and sparkling gemstones in exchange for his cooperation in tos2x01 "Catspaw".

description: The subtle question of how a child's intellect develops and what should be done to aid this process is discussed.

examples.examples: The Aldeans had an enlightened approach to raising children they kidnap in tng1x17 "When The Bough Breaks".

description: The treatment of intangible creations of the human intellect as property by law is discussed. Copyrights, patents, trademarks, and trade secrets are notable examples of such things. Questions that arise are typically about whether something deserves the legal protection it is afforded, or vice versa.

examples.examples: In tz1959e5x34 "Come Wander with Me", "Rock-A-Billy Kid" Floyd Burney expresses the opinion that he isn't obligated to pay any money for Mary Rachel's song because it is in the public domain.

description: There is technology, perhaps wearable, by which an ordinary person can be transformed into a genius.
A conventional Earth animal is discovered to be truly intelligent or to have an intelligent (but as yet unknown) offshoot.
The theory that some dinosaurs had intelligence comparable to that of modern humans is featured.
The human predilection for engaging with old curios is illustrated.

examples.examples: Geordi was keen to take a look at some Ktarian antiques on the Deep Space 9 Promenade in tng6x16 "Birthright, Part I". He had heard there was a twenty- first century plasma coil in perfect condition for sale.

description: Someone acts as a helpful intermediary between two factions that have trouble negotiating effectively on their own, perhaps because they can't stand the sight of one another.

theme_name: interfering in the internal affairs of other powers for humanitarian reasons
description: The ethical justifications for intervening in the affairs of another nation when doing so could arguably stop or prevent great human suffering, is explored.

parents.parents: the ethics of interfering in the internal affairs of other powers

ancestors.ancestors: the ethics of interfering in the internal affairs of other powers

description: Featured is spaceflight between galaxies.

Social problems that arise because of conflict between age groups are explored. For example, when the young feel they are unemployed and poor because previous generations have run up national debt and extract juicy pensions there can be some resentment.
This is the category of themes that examine how sovereign states interact. For example, this is where themes about war, peace, diplomacy, international trade, and globalization belong.

examples.examples: "transnational institution for peace" is an "international issue" theme as it is used when an organization like the UN, a forum for sovereign states to discuss common concerns, is featured.

description: The intricacies of politics when multiple sovereign factions and ethnic identities are involved is features.
One or more states seek to punish another state by by preventing activities such and trade and travel.
One of the various types of Internet related crime known as "cybercrime" is featured, for example "cyberfraud" or "cyberextortion".
Featured is spaceflight between planets or other bodies withing the same star system.
There is warfare between combatants from different planets in a stellar system.

examples.examples: In "The Moon is a Harsh Mistress" (1966), a full-scale war erupted between the Federated Nations of Earth and their colony on the Moon.

description: Two people with of different socially-defined races engage in a romantic relationship, and face some of the obstacles that come along with it.
A way of communicating in some kind of real-time across the vast distances of space that lies between star systems, is featured.

A people travels outside its original solar system. Note: As space travel is present as the backdrop in every Star Trek episode, the theme is used only when a particular point is made about it in the story line.

examples.examples: Captain Picard explained the Federation's mission in detail in tng1x01 "Encounter at Farpoint".

description: There is warfare between combatants from different planetary systems.

notes.notes: This theme does not apply in the asymmetrical scenario where only one party can take the fight to the other party's planetary system.

description: A character tries to browbeat another by threat and intimidation.

One character does something to another character that would be offensive and considered a violation of the other character's reasonable expectation of privacy, if found out. Typical this happens when one character spies on another.

theme_name: invasive life form from outer space
description: The ecosystem, or a vital resource (food), on your planet is destroyed by an invasive life form from outer space and you all die.

examples.examples: The grain supply designated for Sherman's Planet was entirely consumed by Tribbles in tos2x13 "The Trouble with Tribbles".

description: A character is able to go unseen because their body is not visible to normal human sight.

notes.notes: This condition is often described as a semi-permanent feature that the benefiting character can't control, per se. It is, nevertheless, an ability in the sense that it allows someone to go places unseen. Typically, they can still make themselves seen by donning clothes or otherwise manipulating the physical world.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to own body

description: There is a technology that renders someone or something invisible.
Technology that renders a spaceship invisible.
A spaceship propulsion technology the idea of which is to create thrust by using electricity to accelerate ionized particles.

examples.examples: An ion-powered starship from Sigma Draconis VI was encountered in tos3x06 "Spock's Brain".

description: Fate subjects a character to circumstances that are notably ironic in the context of that same character's own designs and past actions.

notes.notes: This theme does not apply if the irony is achieved through the considered designs of another character, for example as vengeance. It must also be reasonably clear that irony is a considered component of the story.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected3x06 "Parson's Pleasure", Cyril Boggis purchased a priceless commode for a pittance by telling the seller he needed only the legs and would use the rest as kindling. Upon appearing to collect it he found, in an ironic twist of fate, that the exuberant seller had decided to do him the favor of detaching the legs and chopping the body up into an easily transportable kindling pile.

description: Someone shows flagrant disregard toward people and things that generally expected to be taken seriously.

examples.examples: Thadiun Okona comported himself with a attitude of flagrant disregard toward authority aboard the Enterprise-C in tng2x04 "The Outrageous Okona".

description: Any of a number of technologies developed over the ages to supply controlled amounts of water to crops at regular intervals.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk, while suffering from amnesia, had plans to irrigate Amerind in tos3x03 "The Paradise Syndrome".

description: The question is posed: Is there a cosmic principle or eternal omnipotent entity at work in the universe?

examples.examples: Captain Picard soliloquized on the possible existence of a higher power at work in the cosmos in tng2x02 "Where Silence Has Lease".

theme_name: is there a purpose to life
description: The abstract, possibly nonsensical, question of whether life has some sort of meaning and purpose is featured.
There is a geographical region, or location of significant size, which is remote and isolated to such an extent that many features from prehistoric times are still extant in present time.

notes.notes: "Prehistoric" indicates time from before there were written records. These fictional lands may for example contain cave men form the Stone Age, Neanderthals, woolly mammoths, and dinosaurs.

examples.examples: In futurama7x08 "Fun on a Bun", Fry falls through a hole in a glacier into a land filled with mammoths and Neanderthals. This land had been shut off from the rest of the world by the ice since around the time Homo sapiens first emerged and replaced Neanderthals.

description: A society endeavors to cut all ties to the outside world and avoid strangers to the extreme.

theme_name: it's the future that matters not the past
description: Featured is the idea that a preoccupation with the past is bad if it comes at the expense of concern for the future.

examples.examples: In tz1959e4x10 "No Time Like the Past", we saw a disillusioned scientist in a bleak future try vainly to change the past in various ways. After many failures, he comes to the realization that his fixation with history is wrong, and that he must instead work for the betterment of the future in the world from whence he came.

theme_name: it's what's on the inside that counts
description: The idea that one's character is more important than one's external appearance is put forth.
Elements of folkly Japanese traditions are explicitly and unambiguously featured. There may, for example, be nature spirits or deities with Japanese names.

examples.examples: In "Spirited Away" (2001), the young Japanese girl Chihiro found her self in a peculiar land of legends, to which Japanese gods and spirits came each night to visit a sorceress's magical bathhouse.

description: A character is desirous of an advantage perceived to be held by another, whether it be material (fancy hat) or intangible (love, friends, power, ability, fame, etc.).

examples.examples: Janice Lester went insane with jealousy over the achievements of her one time lover Captain Kirk in tos3x24 "Turnabout Intruder".

description: A being resembling a jellyfish.

examples.examples: An enormous spaceborne jellyfish-like creature was imprisoned and exploited by the Bandi in tng1x01 "Encounter at Farpoint", but its mate showed up to rescue it.

description: A device worn on the back which uses jets of gas or liquid to propel the wearer through the air.
A character working with journalism is engaged in their chosen occupation. This may include traveling investigative journalists as well as editors, columnists, and the like.
Someone travels into a dark and dreary world of the dead.
A native inhabitant of either the planet Jupiter or else one of its moons is featured.

examples.examples: In "Night Caller from Outer Space" (1965), aliens from Jupiter's moon Ganymede came to Earth seeking human females for breeding stock.

description: The religion of the Jewish people is featured.

Featured is the social issue of there being an overabundance of cheap and unhealthy food that is nevertheless so delicious that many people eat excessively, which may turn them overweight and unhealthy.
The wisdom of the old motto "be yourself" is featured: one should strive to act in a way that feels natural.

examples.examples: In tz1959e1x33 "Mr. Bevis", we saw how Mr. Bevis first resolved to better himself by conforming to society, as the guardian angel wanted, but realized that he'd rather remain destitute but carefree, as he had always been.
Mudd's women were trying to act attractive but arguably became more attractive when they stopped acting in tos1x03 "Mudd's Women".

description: The following kind of dilemma is illustrated: Can it be morally justified to use torture, for example, if it is the only way to protect your country? What if you have only weak evidence that it can protect your country? Rumors?

theme_name: keeping a promise when circumstances have changed
description: A character struggles with whether or not they are honor bound to keep a pledge in a situation when circumstances have changed so much that it is unclear whether the spirit of the pledge still applies.

examples.examples: In ds92x19 "Blood Oath" Jadzia Dax has to decide whether she should keep her blood oath to go on a murderous quest of vengeance, even though the oath was made by her antecedent Curzon Dax whose memories she retains but whose personality is long departed.

description: Someone tries to keep something a secret from others around them.
A young person is introduced to the job aspect of adult life, for example by means of a summer job.
A young person is made to perform a science project of some sort in school, or some equivalent scenario.
Society is made perfect by the removal of its one failing component: human.

notes.notes: This  may not seem like a utopia since the destructions of all humans is usually not in the best interest of said humans. Nevertheless, in some stories there are individuals (sometimes human, sometimes robot) who seem to imagine a society bereft of humans as an idyllic one.

examples.examples: Lore and his loyal Borg minions wanted to wipe out the human scourge and make the universe a perfect place in tng7x01 "Descent, Part II".

description: A small autonomous aerial vehicle designed specifically to kill.
We are made to ponder whether killing a sentient but artificial human-like being would be as bad as killing a normal human being.

examples.examples: Sarek and the good guys debated the morality of killing artificial villains in tos3x22 "The Savage Curtain".

description: Someone struggles with the decision of whether or not to kill another in a situation where what's at stake for the potential killer is wealth or status etc. This theme is not used in "kill or be killed" situations, or when the killing is otherwise primarily done to save lives.
A character must choose whether to kill another person in order to save their own hide.

parents.parents: compromising one's ethical principles vs. great need

ancestors.ancestors: compromising one's ethical principles vs. great need

examples.examples: In tng3x03 "The Survivors", we heard that the immensely powerful alien being Kevin refused to kill even the murderous Husnock when they arrived to eradicate Kevin, Kevin's family, friends and entire community.

theme_name: killing to save a loved one
description: Someone struggles between whether to commit murder if that is required to save a loved one from death.
A character struggles with whether or not it is acceptable in a certain situation to take another's life in order to save their own.

parents.parents: compromising one's ethical principles vs. great need

ancestors.ancestors: compromising one's ethical principles vs. great need

description: We are made to ponder whether and to what extent the extrajudicial killing of patently wicked people can be morally sanctionable.

examples.examples: In tz2019e1x01 "The Comedian", we must consider, as Samir no doubt did, whether it was alright to eradicate various maleficents that he knew from his past and that Internet confirmed as bad eggs.

description: Someone feels deeply for the plight of another and offers kindness and compassion rather than material aid.
A character persistently exhibits the irresistible urge to steal items, typically for reasons other than personal use or financial gain.
The age old wisdom that having knowledge that others' lack can be a source of power to influence the actions of others, is featured.

examples.examples: In bbf1x03, "Born to the Purple" (1994), one character sought knowledge to gain power in society, at two characters pointedly used their secret knowledge for good and one character obtained private knowledge but refrained from taking advantage from it out of compassion.

description: Society is seemingly paradisical because everyone just stops being a jerk.

parents.parents: utopia based on a view of human nature

ancestors.ancestors: utopia based on a view of human nature

examples.examples: The tiny alternate universe time continuum Elysia was a veritable utopia where everyone simply got along in tas1x12 "The Time Trap".

description: Featured is a period civil unrest characterized by strong labor militancy and strike activity.
The feature of strike action among organized worker groups in society is discussed.

notes.notes: Not to be confused with "bowling strikes", which rarely appear as social issues in stories.

description: Someone faces the dangers inherent to exploring relatively unknown and unfamiliar inland regions.

notes.notes: A land inhabited by natives may still be unknown to the explorer and their people.

description: Language change is variation over time in a language's features. This process is discussed or pointedly illustrated.

examples.examples: An Abraham Lincoln replica asked forgiveness for calling Uhura "a charming negress" in tos3x22 "The Savage Curtain" upon recalling that the term was used by some in his time as a description of property.

description: The (very real) idea of a language composed of musical sounds is illustrated.

examples.examples: The myseterious space obelisk on Amerind featured such a language in tos3x03 "The Paradise Syndrome".

description: This is the category of national social issues that relate to behaviours that are broadly considered to be against the law in civilized societies. These are themes about crimes and the measures we take to punish, deter, and prevent crime.

notes.notes: Discussions about what ought or oughtn't be law belong elsewhere. For example, torny constitutional law controversies may be better described as political issues.

examples.examples: "price rigging in society" and "theft in society" are both about undesirable activities that we seek to proscribe, and are thus "law and order issue" themes.

description: A character working in some department of law enforcement is engaged in their chosen occupation.
There is a dysfunctional society without laws or order. Typically the strong and powerful do as they wish, and violence abounds.
A character is very lazy, either physically (too lazy to work or move about) or mentally (too lazy to bother attending to their duties).

examples.examples: Spock abandoned his duties in favor of frolicking in a tree while under the influence of space spores in tos1x25 "This Side of Paradise".

description: Someone does a good or bad job of leading a group of people.
Someone seeks to learn about a culture different to their own.
The difficulties involved in learning a new language are illustrated.
A character must choose between staying put in a familiar old role on one hand or grab a fresh new (but unknown and risky) opportunity on the other.
A juvenile reaches that stage in life when it is time to take leave of mom and dad and face the world.

examples.examples: Wesley wrestled with leaving the comfortable confines of the Enterprise-D to enter Starfleet Academy in tng3x24 "MÃ©nage Ã  Troi".

description: Featured is a codified duty in the sens of criminal law, i.e., an obligation to act under which failure to act (omission) results in criminal liability.
Discussed is a type of punishment that is considered legitimate by virtue of being set out in a law code by a recognized government.
There is a fictitious being from Earth mythology.
There is a human or human-like being with an innate ability to use magic of one sort or another. This may include wizards, sorcerers, witches, etc.
A fictional realm from Earth mythology, is featured. Examples include Atlantis, El Dorado, and the Garden of Eden.
This diminutive mischief-maker from Irish folklore is featured.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x14b "The Little People of Killany Woods", an Irish town drunkard's tall tales about "little people" turned out to be true after all. Alas, in this case the Leprachauns were from outer space.

description: We are asked to what extent, if any, lesbianism should be tolerated in our society and how lesbians ought to be treated.

examples.examples: Beverly was propositioned by Kareel Odan in tng4x23 "The Host", alas declined.

description: Someone who was previously proud or arrogant is humbled and becomes more conscious of their own limitations.
A species of beings for which, like the preying mantis, the practice of mating is a lethal affair.
Someone painfully comes to terms with a relationship that has ended and moves on.

A character struggles with accepting and adjusting to their new reality after something adverse and irreversible has happened to it. Typically this theme is used when someone has trouble moving on after a, to them, important person has passed away.

examples.examples: In tz1985e3x05 "Dream Me a Life", both Roger and Laurel were miserable because they had difficulty letting go of their late lovers and moving on. In the end they finally did so and became acquainted with each other, possibly as intimates.

description: The statement of a liar who states that they are lying: for instance, declaring that "I am lying" or "everything I say is false". If they are indeed lying, they are telling the truth, which means they are lying and so on ad infinitum.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk bested the android Norman by skillfully wielding this dangerous piece of otherwise abstract mathematics in tos2x12 "I, Mudd".
