description: There is a character whose job it is to tend to the books in a library, or the like.

examples.examples: In tz1959e2x29 "The Obsolete Man", Mr. Wordsworth was a dedicated librarian and therefore considered obsolete by the totalitarian state in which he had the misfortune to live.

description: A gadget that can detect whether or not someone is lying. Such machines exist but their reliability is debated.

examples.examples: The Enterprise computer doubled as a lie detector in tos2x07 "Wolf in the Fold".

description: There is a technology that enables a person to live long beyond the current maximum life span.
The idea that people have some sort of vital energy that can (usually) be used and depleted much like a liquid.
A life form that somehow derives nourishment from the "life force" of other beings.
Seen is a process, perhaps aided by technology or magic, in which "life force" (spiritual energy, part of the soul, or the like) is transfered form one person to another.

examples.examples: Taurean women put life force draining headbands on men in tas1x04 "The Lorelei Signal", in order to extend their own lives, until Captain Kirk and his crew put a stop to such shenanigans.

description: It is shown what life might have been like in world of Ancient Rome.

parents.parents: life in the ancient Greco-Roman world

ancestors.ancestors: life in the ancient Greco-Roman world

description: We are shown a reasonably sincere idea of what life might have been like for some category of people living on the Indian subcontinent under British colonial rule between the years 1612 and 1947.

parents.parents: human life in early modern times
human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in early modern times
human life in late modern times

examples.examples: In "Aparajito" (1956), we followed the everyday life of young Apu and his family living in the Bengali city Varanasi around 1920.

theme_name: life in Crow law era America
description: We are shown a reasonable idea of what life might have been like for ordinary people in American (especially the South) during the time when Jim Crow laws mandated various kinds of racial segregation, i.e., roughly 1877 to 1954.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times
human life in historical North America

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times
human life in historical North America

examples.examples: In "Daughters of the Dust" (1991), we saw the lives of an extended black family on a former slave plantation island off the coast of Georgia in 1902.

description: It is described what life might have been in Ireland during around 1500-1800, i.e., before industrialization.

parents.parents: human life in early modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in early modern times

description: We are shown an idea of what ordinary life might have been for some category of people living in lower-income residential districts in the downtown or city center of a large city in and around the United States of America.

parents.parents: human life in historical North America

ancestors.ancestors: human life in historical North America

examples.examples: In "Do the Right Thing" (1989), we saw everyday life for a motley collection of mostly poor people in the borough of Brooklyn, New York City.

description: It is described what life might have been in the area of the world controlled by the Ming, or Qing dynasty of China in or around the years 1368 to 1912 AD.

parents.parents: human life in early modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in early modern times

description: It is described what life might have been in Britain around 1750-1945, i.e., during the Industrial Age.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times

description: It is described what life might have been in France in and around 1800 to 1945.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times

description: It is described what life might have been in Germany in and around 1800 to 1945.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times

description: The everyday life of people in this era and region of the world are depicted.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times

description: We are shown a reasonably sincere idea of what life might have been like for some category of people living in Europe between years AD 500 and AD 1500.

examples.examples: In "The Seventh Seal" (1957), we saw a Swedish crusader return from Palestine to find his homeland ravaged by plague.

description: We are shown an idea of what life might have been like in Russia during or around its Medieval era, ca. 980â1584.

examples.examples: In "Andrei Rublev" (1966), we followed the lives of three monks, some peasants, and other low birth characters around the year 1400.

description: We are shown what life might have been like for various people in USA after World War II.

parents.parents: human life in historical North America

ancestors.ancestors: human life in historical North America

description: We are shown what life might have been like for various people somewhere in Europe after World War II.
We are shown what life might have been like for people in USA in and around the time when they declared independence from England, i.e., 1765 to 1783.

parents.parents: human life in early modern times
human life in historical North America

ancestors.ancestors: human life in early modern times
human life in historical North America

theme_name: life in the American Wild West
description: It is shown what life might have been like in America during its post- revolutionary frontier expansion, roughly 1783-1912, the times popularly associated with Cowboys and Indians.

parents.parents: human life in historical North America
human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in historical North America
human life in late modern times

theme_name: life in the ancient Greco-Roman world
description: It is described what life might have been like in the area of the world controlled by Rome or Greece in or around the centuries 8 BC to 5 AD.
We are shown an idea of what life might have been like in Western Europe during or around the days of Napoleon Bonaparte, 1799-1815.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times

examples.examples: In "Barry Lyndon" (1975), we saw images of life military, aristocratic, and common in various places in Western Europe during the Napoleonic wars.

description: We are shown an idea of what more-or-less normal life might have been like in the USSR while it existed, i.e., between 1922 and 1991.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x21b "Red Snow", we saw some people living in a dreary arctic Gulag-like settlement of Soviet design.

description: We are shown a reasonable idea of what life might have been like for some category of people living in Britain (or in areas suffused with British culture) in or around the reign of queen Victoria, i.e., 1837 to 1901.

parents.parents: human life in late modern times

ancestors.ancestors: human life in late modern times

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x22b "Devil's Alphabet", we followed the lives of a friend group of Cambridge students for a few years after their graduation, some time in Victorian England.

theme_name: life with a handicap vs. death
description: Someone must decide whether or not to accept a permanent physical or mental impairment, for example the loss of a limb, in order to survive.
Humanoids that are just unusually small for some reason, like the Lilliputians in "Gulliver's Travels" by Jonathan Swift.

examples.examples: Spiroid epsilon waves had turned human scientists into tiny humanoids that were about one sixteenth of an inch tall in tas1x11 "The Terratin Incident".

description: A literary thematic entity, or literary theme for short, is a topic that is explored in a work of fiction or an opinion that is conveyed about a topic in a work of fiction.
How best to appreciate litterature is discussed.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

examples.examples: Spock was most impressed with Mr. Flint's taste in literature in tos3x21 "Requiem for Methuselah".

theme_name: live by the sword die by the sword
description: The idea is held forth that people who choose to live lives of violence are likely to die violent deaths.
There is a corpse that has been re-animated by some or another means.

examples.examples: Dr. Juan Munos used refrigeration to keep his dead body somehow alive in "Night Gallery" tale "Cool Air" (1971).

description: The theory that non-avian dinosaurs have survived the CretaceousâPaleogene (KâPg) extinction event is entertained.
A character or small community chooses the hermit's life of isolation from most of the rest of society.
There is an organism that exists on a planetary-scale.
A life form that exists as an expansive, gaseous cloud in outer space.
Someone struggles with the pressure of meeting the expectations of others.

examples.examples: Wesley, the wunderkind, failed to meet expectations that he would pass the Starfleet Academy entrance exam in in tng1x19 "Coming of Age".

description: We are asked when, if ever, it is acceptable to prescribe lobotomization, the surgical destruction of part of someone's brain, typically in the context of ameliorating a mental disorder. Concrete lobotomization is no longer done but surgery on the brain is sometimes necessary and there are many tough decision to wrangle.
A machine capable of modifying and controlling weather in its immediate vicinity is featured.

examples.examples: A team of scientists tested a system to control the weather on and around a remote Pacific island in "Son of Godzilla" (1967).

description: There is a being that is novel by virtue of where it comes from, e.g., underground, outer space, an ethereal realm, etc.
This creature from Scottish folklore is featured explicitly.
A scale of measurement that displays the value of a quantity using intervals corresponding to orders of magnitude, like the Richter scale for earthquakes.

examples.examples: Data and Geordi used a logarithmic scale in tng5x04 "Silicon Avatar" to improve image resolution.

description: Someone must decide, in a given situation, which course of action is the better: the one dictated by their gut instinct or the one dictated by their head (logic).

Logic is the systematic study of valid rules of inference, i.e. the relations that lead to the acceptance of one proposition (the conclusion) on the basis of a set of other propositions (premises). More broadly, logic is the analysis and appraisal of arguments.

notes.notes: As almost any human conversation can be said to involve logic, this theme is used only when the topic of logic itself is explicitly discussed in a somewhat academic way.

aliases.aliases: deductive reasoning inductive reasoning abductive reasoning

description: Someone feels bad because they lack friends and meaningful companionship.
Someone deliberately shuns contact with others and prefers to live alone as much as they can.
Two lovers try to remain romantically involved in spite of being miles or lightyears apart, perhaps even without access to real-time communication. Can they keep the spark alive?

examples.examples: Captain Picard recalled that he and Miranda Vrgo had broken up because their long distance relationship didn't work out in tng7x22 "Bloodlines".

description: Someone is actively seeking a romantic partner.
The issue of people being too obsessed with looks and appearances, their own and others, is discussed.

ancestors.ancestors: relations between social groups in society

description: Featured is the crime of stealing, or the taking of goods by force, in the midst of a military, political, or other social crisis, such as war, natural disasters (where law and civil enforcement are temporarily ineffective), or rioting. The proceeds of all these activities can be described as booty, loot, plunder, spoils, or pillage.
A relationship between a ruler and a person who is feudally bound to them is featured.
There is a stereotypical loser-like character with attributes like a dead-end job, no useful education, poor social relations etc.
A character acts impulsively due to extreme emotion and (normally) against better judgment.

The far-fetched notion that a continent, once located in the Pacific Ocean and inhabited by a technologically advanced civilization in pre-history, has since disappeared as a result of catastrophic geological phenomena.
This category of themes concern that feeling of deep affection and attachment toward someone or (occasionally) something. Sexuality may or may not be involved.
The kind of love a person feels who becomes instantly infatuated upon first seeing someone.

examples.examples: It was love at first sight for Troi and  Devinoni Ral in tng3x08 "The Price".

description: Two lovers have such strong feelings for each other that prove to survive surprisingly difficult obstacles, e.g., years of separation.

examples.examples: Anne Nored remained as deeply in love as ever with Carter Winston even after it came to light that he was a betentacled alien spy in tas1x06 "The Survivor".

description: The idea that a shared danger can kindle peoples' passions for each other is illustrated.
The love of a master for their pet is featured.
There is a liquid concoction with the property that it can make one person love another.

Three people (sometimes more) are connected via multiple romantic relationships or unrequited romantic aspirations in a so called "love triangle" ("love mesh" more generally). For example: A loves B loves C loves A, or A and B are friends and both lovers of C, etc.

notes.notes: To be applicable, some sort of interpersonal relationship should be present for all pairs of people in the triangle. In particular, the theme is not applicable when a spouse takes a lover unless the other spouse is also well acquainted, for example friends, with the lover in question.

description: A character must decide what is more important to them: love or career.
Someone is forced to choose between adhering to their faith (for example the doctrines of a church they belong to), or pursuing a romantic interest.
Someone has to choose between pursuing a romantic relationship on one hand, and maintaining a friendship on the other.
A character must choose between someone they love on one hand, and profiting materially (for example by money) on the other.

examples.examples: In tz1959e2x21 "The Prime Mover", Kitty gave her lover Ace this ultimatum: Quit his crooked gambling, or she'd leave. Ace kept gambling a bit longer.

description: A character must choose between the love one on one hand, and a general good, such as a cure for cancer, on the other.

examples.examples: If time traveler Peter Standish had married his love Helen Petigrew, then the timeline would have been irreparably altered in "I'll Never Forget You" (1951).

description: Two characters simultaneously or alternatingly adore each other and despise each other in a very chaotic relationship.
Two characters in a romantic relationship have an argument over something relatively petty, in a way that stereotypically belongs to such relationships.
The category of themes that deal with loyalty, e.g., between friends, from a subordinate to a superior, etc..
Someone shows constant support to a movement they feel strongly about.
Someone shows constant support to a friend.
Someone shows constant support to a group to which they belong.
A subordinate shows constant support to their leader.

examples.examples: Kirk's senior officers remained loyal to their captain at his court martial in tos1x24 "Court Martial".

description: A leader shows constant support to a subordinate.
Someone shows constant support to a family member.
Someone shows constant support to their species.
The way we can sometimes dream with full awareness and control of our dream is featured.
Someone believes a certain object gives them good luck.
A character perpetrates a falsehood in an outright effort to deceive others with whom they are intimately acquainted.

examples.examples: David tells an unconvincing lie to cover up that he'd accidentally shot dead a mule while playing with his new pistol in "Almos' a Man" (1976).

description: Society is supposedly ideal thanks to being controlled by machines that go about optimizing everybody's well-being in the best way possible.
A machine impersonating a human is living secretly among normal people.

examples.examples: In "Terminator: Dark Fate" (2019), the T-101 Model Terminator Carl lives with a wife and stepson in Laredo, Texas, where he works as a common draper.

description: The role of machines in society is explored. Examples include the ramifications of people being replaced by machines at work and the use of AI technology in daily life.
There is a character that fits the stereotype of a mad scientist. This typically involves lab coats and crazy experiments.
There is a bag from which one can procure far more items, possibly an unlimited number, than the bag by its external appearance could possibly hold.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x13a "Night of the Meek", Henry suddenly found that his garbage bag was filled with Christmas presents and continued to be so however many were removed, near enough.

description: There is an object which can be used to heal a person of their ailments, with supernatural efficacy.
There is an object akin to Aladdin's magic oil lamp that hosts a genie who, if one rubs the lamp, is obligated to grant some wishes.
There is an object with some fantastical property that cannot be explained by science.
There is an opening, usually framed in a portal, mirror, or suchlike object, through which objects and people may pass and appear instantaneously in remote places.
There is a liquid concoction with supernatural properties. For example, the potion might turn someone into an animal, or make them fall madly in love.
A character is able to do at will some fantastical things that involves speculative supernatural forces that can be described as "magic".

notes.notes: This theme applies when a character uses spells, incantation, and other classically magic invocations. Unlike, for example, telekinesis it is clear that the world is manipulated first through the manipulation of some "magical" force or principle. In essence, the character is not directly manipulating real things (as we know them) but manipulates magic. Thus this becomes a category apart from other "speculative ability" themes.

description: The use of spoken words to invoke magical energies is featured. Note: A stage magician uttering "Abracadabra" before performing a trick does not count.
There is a land, a kingdom perhaps, above the clouds.

notes.notes: This kind of theme is common fare for fairy tales and religions, and the exact details are generally left vague.

description: Someone is forgiving to a rival they have bested.

examples.examples: Riker graciously declined Portal 6-3's offer to destroy a party of conniving Ferengi in tng1x05 "The Last Outpost".

description: Boots that are magnetic, which allows them to attach to the ferrous floor or hulls of a spacecraft during weightlessness, and presumably would allow someone to walk around the cabin of a spacecraft, are featured.
The relationship between a maker of a (more or less intelligent) machine and that machine is featured.
The relationship between a maker and a monster of their own creation is featured.
Two mature adult males strengthen their friendship by engaging in stereotypically male bonding activities such as William T. Riker fighting an Anbo-jyutsu match.

examples.examples: Geordi and Bochra, a Romulan centurion and sworn enemy of the Federation, engaged in some serious male bonding while stranded together on the planet Galorndon Core in tng3x07 "The Enemy".

description: The sexist attitude that males are blunt and violent is illustrated as such.
The idea that men are inherently competitive is expressed.
We are asked to what extent, if any, homosexuality should be tolerated in our society and how homosexual people ought to be treated.

examples.examples: The J'naii's gender identities were rather fuzzy in tng5x17 "The Outcast"; Riker's fling with Soren may have been as close as we ever got to seeing male homosexuality in TNG.

description: A male character is stereotypically licentious, i.e., makes offensive comments of a sexual nature or otherwise expresses an offensive preoccupation with sex.
The sterotypical idea of a male midlife crisis is featured. It might, for example, make the male in question buy fast cars and hookers, revert to teenage attitudes, or do some other silly things.

notes.notes: A midlife crisis is a transition of identity and self-confidence that can occur in middle-aged individuals, typically 45-64 years old.

description: The tendency of some males to prance and posture, particularly in front of females, is demonstrated.
There is a male character that is excessively preoccupied with trying to have sex with many different partners to such an extent that this sexist stereotype is apparent.
The tendency of some males to be protective of females is illustrated.

examples.examples: Scotty had a crush on Carolyn Palamas and tried awkwardly to be her knight in shining armor in tos2x04 "Who Mourns for Adonais?".

description: The category of themes that (correctly or incorrectly) highlight attributes that are believed to be typical of contemporary men. Many of these may be considered sexist today.

Two mature adult characters of the opposite sex strengthen their friendship through some sort of bonding activity or shared hardship etc. Note: This theme is not used if the nature of the relationship is predominantly romantic.

examples.examples: In ent1x15 "Shadows of P'Jem", Archer and T'Pol are held hostage together, a tribulation during which they come to much better understand each other.

description: Two or more male characters compete with each other in a stereotypically male way, for example through posturing or by trying to intimidate each other.

There is a man and a woman who are in a stable romantic relationship in such a way that she can be readily described as his "mistress". This expression is usually applied when the man is married to someone else, or when there is at least a hint of secrecy about the arrangement. The interpersonal relationship between the two characters is featured.
There is conflict between a male character and a female character, featured in such a way that the gender difference is significant to the situation.
We are asked when in life it is right and proper for a person to retire.

examples.examples: The Federation decided to review the mandatory retirement age of 75 in the case of Commodore April after his heroic actions in tas2x06 "The Counter-Clock Incident".

description: The legend that humanoid-shaped Mandrake root is produced by the semen of hanged men under the gallows.

theme_name: manipulation of evolution on a planet
description: A species influences the development of life on other planets by interceding early in the evolutionary process (possibly before biological molecules first appeared) and then letting nature take its course.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x15b "A Small Talent for War", an alien told some United Nations delegates that his people had seeded Earth, along with millions of other worlds, with life.

description: The importance of, for example, not telling fools they are fools straight to their face is featured.
There is a wedding.
The human rights issue that same-sex marriage and opposite-sex marriage be recognized as equal by the law, is discussed.
Featured is a native inhabitant of the planet Mars.
What it means to be a real man is at stake.
We are made to ponder the pros and cons of a society in which happiness is linked to the acquisition of goods and services in ever-increasing amounts.
Allusions of a threat spread through a group causing panic, each person's fear reinforcing that of the next and in a vicious circle.

examples.examples: The people of Maple Street gradually transform into an hysterical mob when they thought an alien monster was masquerading amongst them in "The Twilight Zone" (1959) story "The Monsters Are Due on Maple Street" (tz1959e1x22).

description: For one reason or another people become infertile and civilization gradually die out.

parents.parents: force of nature existential risk to civilization

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

description: The various ways in which mass media affect society is explored.
The technology to, more or less directly and with some degree of precision, control the minds and actions of entire populations of people.

examples.examples: Landru mind controlled a entire population with the help of an absorption chamber or two in tos1x22 "The Return of the Archons".

description: The crime of murdering a number of people, typically simultaneously or over a relatively short period of time and in close geographic proximity is featured.

examples.examples: A New York police detective investigates a series of mass murders in "God Told Me To" (1976).

description: Radiation from some unspecified source wipes out life on a planet.

parents.parents: force of nature existential risk to civilization

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

examples.examples: The Scalosians were nearly wiped out by radiation in tos3x13 "Wink of an Eye".

description: The question of whether and to what extent we should have large scale surveillance systems in place is discussed.
The relationship between a master and their pet is featured.

examples.examples: Data replicated feline supplement 74 for his beloved pet Spot the cat in tng4x11 "Data's Day".

description: The relationship between a master and their servant is featured.
The relationship between a master (or mistress) and their slave is featured.
The problem of criminals rigging games and sports matches by various means in order to profit from betting and spectator revenues, is discussed.
There is technology with the putative capability to pair love seekers off in some sort of optimal way.
The idea is put forth that we ought to see material possessions as less important in favor of other considerations, for example relationships.
The love of a mother for her child is featured.

examples.examples: Beverly expressed her love for Wesley in tng1x03 "The Naked Now" by slapping him clear across the face.

description: Featured is some aspect of number theory, algebra, geometry, or other type of study which is popularly categorized under the rubric of "mathematics".
The ways in which animals behave with regard to mating is studied.
There is a social system in which exclusively women have political power.
A son or daughter murders their own mother.

examples.examples: In "Psycho" (1960), we learn that young Norman Bates had murdered his widowed mother and her new fiancÃ©e out of jealousy when Mrs. Bates planned to remarry.

description: The love between two married people is featured.
A machine that can exactly duplicate physical objects.
There is technology that enables the changing or rearranging of particles of matter at a level of precision beyond our current capabilities.
A device used to synthesize all sorts of material objects merely out of energy.

examples.examples: L.Q. "Sonny" Clemonds replicated a straight up martini with two olives (for the vitamins) using the Enterprise-D matter replicator in tng1x26 "The Neutral Zone".

description: A device used to transform material objects into other material objects or into energy.
There is a mechanical device that is shaped like an insect and that acts like an insect in some ways.

examples.examples: In blackmirror3x06 "Hated in the Nation" enormous swarms of mechanical bees had been created to pollinate plants, because real bees had died out.

description: An automaton that resembles a human being is featured.
A medical professional ponders whether and to what extent they should expend effort to treat a wounded enemy.
This is the important subcategory of "social ethical issue" themes that relate to how doctor's and other health care workers ought to behave in various situation.

examples.examples: "medical triage" involves choosing which patient to treat first and involves various ethical considerations that, perhaps, should not be left to individual whim.

description: It is discussed how one can weight one set of risks and benefits against another in planning medical treatments.
A practitioner of medicine has to choose which patient to prioritize base on factors such as likelihood of survival, age, and expected quality of remaining life.
Medicine is the science and practice of establishing the diagnosis, prognosis, treatment, and prevention of disease. This theme is used whenever an aspect of this science is featured in the story.
A paramour meets the parents of their lover for the first time.
A character is able to recall experiences from another lifetime. This implies some sort of reincarnation, or variation thereof.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to own mind

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to own mind

description: The technology to remove (some or all) segments of someone's memories is featured.
There is technology by which memories may be implanted into someone's brain.
A device used to record and replay someone's memories.

examples.examples: Professor Quatermass used a device to record a young lady's buried memory of a ritual slaughter and then played it back to an audience in "Quatermass and the Pit" (1967).

description: Featured is the theory that there are men dressed in black suits who claim to be quasi-government agents who harass, threaten or assassinate UFO witnesses to keep them quiet about what they have seen.
A character, typically a woman aged 45-50, experiences menopausal symptoms.

examples.examples: Lwaxana coped with a characteristically Betazoid form of menopause in tng2x19 "Man Hunt".

description: A character exhibits general mental illness.

There is a person who suffers from a neurodevelopmental disorder so severe that they have a significantly lower IQ (technically below 70) and problems with adaptive behavior that make their everyday living problematic.

notes.notes: This theme may be included in stories that clearly explore actual as well as borderline intellectual disability even if it is not clear that the technical definition of that condition are fulfilled. It may also be included in stories that parody or mischaracterize the condition.

examples.examples: In tz1985e2x05 "The Toys of Caliban", we saw an elderly married couple who were raising their intellectually disabled son Toby in seclusion because he had a dangerous magical ability but no self-restraint or sense to conduct himself safely with his power.

description: There is a being that is novel by virtue of its mental abilities, e.g., it is telepathic, super intelligent, or collectively linked in a hive mind, and so on.
The relationship between a mentor and the person they are mentoring is featured.

examples.examples: The Traveler played the role of mentor to Wesley in tng1x06 "Where No One Has Gone Before".

description: Someone displays forgiveness, pity, or compassion toward another who is under their authority, i.e., is at their mercy.
We are made to ponder when and to what extent we think laws should be enforced to the letter, and when, if ever, there might be reason to stay enforcement for reasons of mercy.

examples.examples: In "The Merchant of Venice" (1598), by the letter of the law Shylock had the right to extract a literal pound of flesh from Antonio who had broken his bond. A legal expert implored Shylock to be merciful yet acknowledged that the law must be upheld and that mercy could not be enforced by the state. Later Shylock was himself brought low by the law, and various characters made a point of being merciful even when the law would have awarded them ruthless satisfaction.

description: There is a race of mermaids and mermen, i.e., beings that share fish-like characteristics and that live under water.
A religious savior or liberator of a group of believers, similar to a holy prophet but usually a notch higher in the divine pecking order.

examples.examples: Kahless the Unforgettable, the Klingon messiah, was resurrected by cloning by Klingon monks in tng6x23 "Rightful Heir".

description: A character believes themselves to be a divinely chosen leader and savior of their people.
The branch of philosophy concerned with the fundamental nature of reality and such basic concepts as existence, matter, space, time and causation.
A macroscopic single celled being.
There is a being that is too small to see with the naked eye.
A life form that is microscopic in size, yet (astonishingly when compared to a common brain) is considered sentient.

examples.examples: The "Microbrains" of Velara III were tiny, yet somehow sentient, crystals in tng1x18 "Home Soil".

description: Featured is the placement and development of weaponry and military technology in outer space around a world.
A state's government is overthrown by a group of people from within the state's own armed forces.

examples.examples: In "Akira" (1988), Colonel Shikishima led a coup d'Ã©tat against the Neo Tokyo government and directed all of its military forces to destroy a young man who had acquired near god-like telekinetic abilities.

description: Society is ruled by a military group that maintain power by means of violence and repression.

The military uses its powers to indoctrinate individuals into a way of thinking. For example, a militia may be indoctrinated with the idea that the enemy is evil. For "indoctrination" to apply a certain amount of coercion (possibly clandestine) is required.
This is the category of themes that relate to how a society organizes its armed forces.

examples.examples: "desertion" and "treason" are "military issue" themes as they deal with how discipline is maintained within the military or military-like groups.

description: The following kind of dilemma is illustrated: Is it right to retaliate after an offence in order to dissuade an enemy from further violence? Or will that just lead to a vicious circle of vendetta?

examples.examples: Captain Kirk chased down Gorn marauders to discourage them from further aggression in tos1x19 "Arena". It had nothing to do with vengeance, nothing!

description: The practice of keeping sensitive military information secret is featured.
It is discussed how one should act and maneuver in battle to gain an advantage.
The peculiar human habit of occasionally wanting something only because we became cognizant of someone else wanting the same thing, is explicitly featured.

notes.notes: The story must make it clear that the desire arose primarily for mimetic reasons, if this theme is to be used.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected7x13 "The Reconciliation", we learn that James' interest in his estranged wife was rekindled only because he came to believe someone else had taken her as a lover.

description: A novel technology is used to alter (enhance or diminish perhaps) a person's mental ability. These are themes that posit technology to manipulate the human mind by cloning it, wiping it, moving it, controlling it, etc.

A character is able to attack another's mind, soul, or spirit (etc.) and inflict harm. They can sometimes also defend against such attacks, and the story world may contain the idea of invisible mind battles.

notes.notes: If a character struggles to control another person, rather than inflicting direct spiritual harm, then "mind control ability" is the more appropriate theme.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to another being

description: A character, by simply using their mind, is able to control other people's thoughts and actions.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to another being

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x19a "The Leprechaun-Artist", a Leprechaun granted three young boys the power of command over their own parents. This was fun at first, but proved problematic as the parents showed no initiative whatsoever and had to be micromanaged.

description: Technology that can be employed to shape someone's mental states, thoughts, and opinions.
Society is supposedly ideal thanks to the use of mass mind control.
Technology that links two or more people's minds so that they can sense each other's emotions and perhaps even hear each other's thoughts.

examples.examples: Captain Picard and Beverly shared their most intimate thoughts while mind linked in tng7x08 "Attached".

description: A character is able to telepathically read the minds of other people.

notes.notes: This theme is used when one person can merely "hear the thoughts" of another. If a person transmits their thoughts or otherwise affects people's minds at a distance, the more general theme "telepathy" is used.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to another being

description: Technology that can be employed by one person to read another person's mind.
A character is able to interact with another mind, simply by concentrating.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to another being

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to another being

description: Technology used to transfer someone's mind from one body to another, or to a computer or some sort of artificial brain.
There is a technology used to transfer someone's mind to a computer or some sort of artificial brain.

examples.examples: The mind of pop singer Ashley O was transfer into the AI doll Ashley Too in the Black Mirror story "Rachel, Jack and Ashley Too" (2019).

description: Technology that provides a low-latency interface between a brain and a computer, thus blurring the boundaries between man and machine.

examples.examples: Barclay got tired of the slow old interfaces and connected his brain directly to the Enterprise-D computer when he developed super-intelligence in tng4x19 "The Nth Degree".

description: As a punishment for crime, someone has their mind and memories, or significant parts thereof, erased.
One faction in a conflict uses hidden proximity activated explosive devices (mines) in order to booby trap an area and make it more or less impassable for the enemy.
Technology by which material objects (such as people) can be made smaller in size compared to their surrounding without changing their characteristics otherwise.
There is a professional whose jobs involve excavation perilously deep underground.
There is a supernatural event, beneficial for the faithful, that is attributed to divine agency.

examples.examples: A blind boy miraculously regained his sight upon visiting a Mexican shrine in the "Night Gallery" story "The Miracle at Camafeo" (1972).

description: Someone exhibits prejudice, dislike, or even hatred, of men.

examples.examples: Janice Lester was deeply resentful of Captain Kirk and other men who got ahead because of their sex in tos3x24 "Turnabout Intruder".

description: Someone exhibits prejudice, dislike, or even hatred, of humans and humanity.
A character is convicted and punished for a crime that he or she did not actually commit.
There is a character who is notably and excessively reluctant to spend money, in particular to help others.

notes.notes: In particular, this theme becomes topical when a notably well-off character is contrasted with a notably poor character and the former offer less help to the latter than the situation appears to warrant.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected6x11 "The Tribute", we see three former colonial ladies who are notorious for being penny-pinching. Before they fell on bad times themselves, they had treated their servants with remarkable meanness, or so we are told.
Charles Dickens' "A Christmas Carol" is perhaps one of the most obvious examples of a story about miserliness.

description: The embarrassingly human tendency for unhappy people to want other people to be unhappy as well, is featured.
It is observed that a shared spat of adversity can work to bring people closer together.
Someone exhibits prejudice, dislike, or even hatred, of women.

examples.examples: Scotty took shore leave on Argelius II in an effort to overcome his "total resentment towards women" in tos20x7 "Wolf in the Fold". He was then accused of brutally murdering a number of women on the planet, but was ultimately found to be innocent.

description: The way in which mistrust can lead to a group of people not getting along is noted.
We are asked when, if ever, marriage between people of different ethnicities ought to be tolerated.
Social concerns relating to people engaging with "massively multiplayer online role-playing games" are discussed.
There is a device (possibly bewheeled and box-like) that keeps you alive and mobile even after the most crippling of catastrophic accidents.

examples.examples: Captain Pike was confined to just such a device in tos1x15 "The Menagerie, Part I" and tos1x16  "The Menagerie, Part II".

description: We are made to contemplate the widespread of hand-held communication devices that some people think is excessive. In particular the impact of this on children tends to be controversial.
More or less explicitly featured is the philosophy that one should not do anything too much, nor too little.
Creatures that live entirely under the Earth, or more generally underground in a planet, in caves or hollowed out regions.
A "holy" order of monks or nuns practicing religion is featured.
This old adage is illustrated. The idea is that no amount of money or other external things can guarantee a person's happiness.

aliases.aliases: material things don't make you happy

examples.examples: In "Citizen Kane" (1941), we see how the exceedingly rich and powerful Mr. Kane dies miserable without friends while reminiscing on the last time, perhaps, that he was truly happy: when he was eight and had a sled named "Rosebud".

description: This age old adage is demonstrated, refuted, or otherwise discussed.

theme_name: money is the root of all evil
description: The idea is put forth that money is the source of many, most, or even all, social ills or individual shortcoming.
The idea is put forth that we ought to see money as less important in favor of other considerations, for example relationships.
There is an implant that lets someone else monitor the wearer's activities and experiences to a significant extent.
A character contemplates whether to enter into a presumed monogamous relationship or whether to stay single.
The ramifications of economic monopolistic forces at work in society are explored.
There is a type of grotesque creature, whose appearance frightens and whose powers of destruction threaten the human world's social or moral order.
Monsters or beasts of some kind ravage a world and put an end to civilized life.

parents.parents: force of nature existential risk to civilization

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

description: A native inhabitant of the the Moon is featured.

theme_name: moon slowly spiraling into a planet
description: The moon to a planet drops out of its normal orbit for some reason and starts on a slow, spiraling collision course with the planet.

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

examples.examples: The Enterprise-D saved the Natives of Bre'el IV from this fate in tng3x13 "Deja Q".

description: An historically important method of encoding the alphabet into binary sequences of long and short signals, often audible beeps.

The practice of atonement for sin through the infliction of pain and suffering is explored. Traditional forms of mortification include fasting, abstinence from sexual intercourse, the wearing of sackcloth, and flagellation.
The relationship between a mother and her daughter is featured.
The relationship between a mother and her son is featured.
The notion that an expecting mother should have the sole right to decide whether or not she will carry a pregnancy to term is featured.

examples.examples: The senior officers discussed what to do about Troi's mysterious pregnancy and Worf suggested an abortion in tng2x01 "The Child", but Troi would have none of it.

description: The relationship between a mother-in-law and her daughter-in-law is featured.
The interpersonal relationship between a married man and his wife's mother is featured.

examples.examples: In "A Woman Under the Influence" (1974), Nick handled Mabel's hapless mother with remarkable ease and affection.

description: A son is not all that his mother wishes him to be.

examples.examples: Beverly was disappointed in Wesley for covering up the now infamous Nova Squadron Incident in tng5x18 "The First Duty".

description: There is a sport which notably involves the use of motorized vehicles.
A character is enthusiastic about the set of outdoor activities that involves ascending tall mountains.

theme_name: move fast or take it slow in a romantic relationship
description: Someone embarking on a romance is trying to decide how strongly they should come on.
Two lovers contemplate whether or not to start living together in the same home.
The crime of robbing people in public places, particularly on streets, is featured.
There is a species of beings that have more than the customary two genders. Three or more individuals have to contribute genetic material in order to procreate.
A spaceship built for voyages longer than an individual's lifespan and with a view to let the crew procreate and live out their lives on-board.
There are multiple sentient, species that all live there together in one society.
People of different cultures are trying to live together. There  may or may not be a specific issue, but intolerance hangs in the air. Problems are not far off.
A kid is brought up being part of two or more cultures, perhaps because mom and dad have different heritages.

examples.examples: Worf and his mate K'Ehleyr discussed the troubles of growing up with a foot each in two different cultures in tng2x20 "The Emissary".

description: There is a society in which sizable groups of people with different ethnicities seek to live together under a common law.
A mental disorder characterized by at least two distinct and relatively enduring identities or dissociated personality states.
A rocket that uses two or more stages, each of which contains its own engines and propellant is featured.
The crime of unlawful and intentional homicide is featured.
Music is notably featured in the story. Typically, this is because there is a musician, other music professional, or someone else who is very interested in music.

notes.notes: As music is rather common in modern society, it is often present in unremarkable ways in the background of stories. It is generally not considered a theme just because a normal person briefly listens to music, or a radio is heard in the background. Nor is music automatically a theme when the story is told through song, such as in opera.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

examples.examples: Captain Picard and Nella Daren made beautiful music together aboard the Enterprise-D in tng6x19 "Lessons".

description: The practice found in some law codes of prescribing amputation of limbs and other mutilations (such as blinding or tongue slitting) for crimes, is featured.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected9x08 "The Finger of Suspicion", we learned that Stephen had had his right hand cut off as punishment for theft in the Arab country where he lived.

description: Two characters come to respect each other.
Two characters come to trust each other.
A long gone alien race that left behind a creation of some significance, for example a grand technological construction.

examples.examples: A mysterious maker alien race left an asteroid deflecting obelisk on the planet Amerind in tos3x03 "The Paradise Syndrome".

description: The paranormal notion that a human body (or any animal or object for that matter) is enclosed by a mysterious, sometimes colorful energy is featured.

examples.examples: It was speculated that a suicided environmental activist was able to return from the dead owing to his unusually strong aura in "2.0" (2018).

description: There is a short and possibly ugly human-shaped entity that dwells in mountains and in the earth, and is variously associated with wisdom, smithing, mining, and crafting.
The sirens are dangerous creatures from Greek mythology, that lure unwary sailors to their doom. Such or similar creatures are featured.
There is a character that, like Narcisuss in the ancient Greek story, has an excessive, lasting, and obsessive admiration their own self-image and/or other attributes.

notes.notes: "Pride" themes like "attitude of superiority" involve a character comparing themselves to others. Such themes do not necessarily mean that narcissism is implied. It is possible for a character, rightly or wrongly, to believe themselves superior and take pride in that supposed fact, without them obsessively and lastingly admiring themselves.

To judge whether we describe a character as "narcissistic" we inspect the character's self-admiring behavior and gauge whether we think that they, like Narcissus did, could have behaved the same way when alone.
If a character admires themselves habitually but in a way that is not describable as "obsessive" then the theme "vanity" is applicable.

examples.examples: Garth of Izar suffered from delusions of grandeur in tos3x16 "Whom Gods Destroy".

description: This is the category of themes that relate to a single state's internal organization.

examples.examples: "national social issue" themes are plenty and come in a wide variety. It is convenient to further divide it into categories such as "political issue", "economical issue", "law and order issue", etc.

description: There is a political movement characterized by the promotion of the interests of a nation.
A naturally occurring biological agent or pathogen wipes out civilization on a world.

parents.parents: force of nature existential risk to civilization

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

description: The importance of managing natural resources in a manner that safeguards their availability to future generations is explored.

examples.examples: Mark the merman wondered aloud about what humans would do once they used up all the raw materials that could be obtained from mining the sea floor in "Man from Atlantis IV: The Disappearances" (1977). The feasibility of undersea mining was being researched on account that humans were quickly using up all the materials on the surface.

description: Someone works to protect the environment, or a unique aspect of nature, against threatening changes brought on by human activity.
Discussed is whether human behavior is determined more by the environment, either prenatal or during a person's life, or more by a person's genes.
Nature somehow runs amok and takes vengeance on its abusers.

examples.examples: Nuclear weapons tests in the Pacific stirred up a prehistoric dinosaur-like monster that make a B-line for Tokyo in "Godzilla" (1954),
A green brain arises from nature's resistance to human efforts eradicate all insect life on Earth in "The Green Brain" (1966).
An unspecified cosmic event results in ant colonies evolving collective intelligence and challenging humans for dominion over the Earth in "Phase IV" (1974).

description: The ideology and set of practices associated with the 20th-century German Nazi Party are discussed.
There is a character who is sexually attracted to a corpse, or to corpses in general.

examples.examples: A Scottish widow had a thing for her deceased husband in the "Night Gallery" story "The Ghost of Sorworth Place" (1972).

description: A parent neglects to spend time with their child to a conspicuous extent.
Two or more people are in a process of negotiating but neither will budge from their entrenched position.
Two or more characters seek to reach a mutually acceptable arrangement of some sort.
The relationship between two people who live next to each other is featured.
Society goes back to the perfect state it was once in, after the root of all evil has been made away with: machinery.
The ramifications of someone favoring relatives or personal friends because of their relationship rather than because of their abilities are explored.
There is an alien race that is native to the planet Neptune in our solar system.
There is a whole other universe somehow contained within a portion of our normal (or some other) universe. For example, there might be a universe contained in an atom, every atom, a box, or a marble.
A life form that dominates other species by attaching themselves to the others' neural systems.

examples.examples: Patch-like flying aliens attached themselves to people's nervous system in tos1x29 "Operation -- Annihilate!".

description: There is a husband and wife whose interactions are notably colored by the fact that they were recently married. This usually involves exceptional romanticism, tenderness, talk about the honeymoon, and planning for a future together.

examples.examples: In tz1959e2x07 "Nick of Time", we saw that William Shatner (as Don) with his loving bride Pat honeymooning across the Ohio countryside. When Don revealed his excessive superstitiousness, Pat insisted that she did not regret her decision to marry him, and they spoke of their future together.

description: A philosophical doctrine that suggests the lack of belief in one or more reputedly meaningful aspects of life. Most commonly, nihilism is presented in the form of existential nihilism, which argues that life is without objective meaning, purpose, or intrinsic value.
A character exhibits an irrational fear of nothingness.

Can a myth or untruth (often, but not invariably, of a religious nature) knowingly propagated by an elite to maintain social harmony or to advance an agenda ever be justified as benefiting society more than it harms it in the long run?
Society is bliss because it is made up of noble savages who live as one with nature etc., never mind antibiotics and such pointless luxeries.
Space as it would be if the rules and axioms of geometry were suddenly different from what we know.

examples.examples: The Enterprise flew at warp speed in a straight line only to find itself back where it began in tng2x02 "Where Silence Has Lease", just as would someone who traveled in a straight line on the surface of Earth. Perhaps Nagilum's realm was a hypersphere.

description: Voyeurism is the sexual interest in or practice of spying on people engaged in intimate behaviours, such as undressing, sexual activity, or other actions usually considered to be of a private nature. Discussed is the perceived social issue associated with the prevalence of this often criminal activity.
A character exhibits a feeling of sentimentality, longing for the days of yore, etc.

examples.examples: Scotty drunkenly relived his glory days in a holodeck simulation of the original Enterprise bridge in tng6x04 "Relics".

description: The kind of love a person feels springing from the memory of a bygone passion.
The idea is explicitly mentioned that if one takes no risks, one will not gain any benefits.

The harnessing of nuclear fission reactions as a power source for technology is explored. This theme does not apply in the case when energy from nuclear fission reactions is released in an uncontrolled manner, such as with a fission bomb.

examples.examples: A crew of pioneering astronauts commandeered an atomic powered rocketship to the Moon in "Destination Moon" (1950).

description: Nuclear weapons are widely employed to an extent that destruction and radioactive fallout causes the collapse of civilization.
The social problem of whether and to what extent nuclear power generation can be made safe is discussed.
There is a spacecraft that relies on some form of nuclear energy (e.g. nuclear fission or nuclear fusion) for propulsion.
We are made to think about the perils of the spread of nuclear technology and information.
The use of nuclear technology for war is featured.
Someone dislikes clothes to such an extent that they prefer to be naked in public.
Someone struggles with being grossly over-weight.
Someone is fixated with a particular idea or objective to the extent that they notably neglect other concerns.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk became obsessed with stalking down a vampiric cloud entity in tos2x18 "Obsession".

description: Someone is fixated with a project that they have dedicated their life to, to the extent that they notably neglect other concerns.

examples.examples: Dr. Richard Daystrom made it his life's work to build a computer so powerful that it could replace Kirk as the captain aboard the Enterprise in tos2x24 "The Ultimate Computer".

description: An infatuation that is so intense and obsessive that one's self-control and judgement becomes impaired.

examples.examples: Lwaxana chased Captain Picard like a rabbit from one end of the ship to another in tng2x19 "Manhunt" and was only narrowly diverted from her objective when she encountered an attractive bartender on the holodeck.

description: A character has a pathological need to need to check things repeatedly, perform certain routines repeatedly, etc. Often featured as repeated cleaning.

Featured is a crime that consists of obstructing prosecutors, investigators, or other government officials. This may involve, for example, perjury, making false statements to officials, witness tampering, jury tampering, destruction of evidence, etc.
A hypothetical type of exoplanet wherein the surface is completely covered by water.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk and Spock were transformed into fish-like humanoids on the water- world Argo in tas1x13 "The Ambergris Element".

description: A character is notably seen to exhibit repressed sexual desire for the opposite-sex parent and hatred for the same-sex parent, to some extent.

notes.notes: This should be distinguished from cases where a parent pursues a sexual relationship with their child.

examples.examples: In "Hamlet" (1602), until the revelations at the end, is seems plausible that Hamlet is indeed mad and has invented the poisoning because he (as Sigmund Freud held) hates his step-father being married to his mother, who Hamlet unconsciously desires sexually. The scene where he is wrestling with his mother in her bed is suggestive.

description: There is a prison somewhere away from any inhabited planet. Typically it is on a moon, asteroid, spaceship or the like.
There is scheming, maneuvering, and intrigue in the workplace.

examples.examples: Younglings on the Enterprise pondered how to get ahead in their careers in tng7x15 "Lower Decks".

description: Two (or more) workplace colleagues embark on a romantic relationship.
Someone in officialdom tries to divert public attention from, for example, themselves or a social problem by blaming or otherwise denigrating a different group of people.
An oil spill is the release of a liquid petroleum hydrocarbon into the environment, especially the marine ecosystem, due to human activity, and is a form of pollution.
Someone ponders a past love or encounters their former lover again.

examples.examples: McCoy met whom he assumed to be his old flame Nancy Crater on planet M-113 in tos1x05 "The Man Trap", but she turned out to be a ravenous salt vampire.

theme_name: old woman as a witch stereotype
description: There is a character that fits the Western folklore stereotype of a witch. This may, for example, involve pointy black hats, foul concoctions, or a knowledge of herbs, etc.
The love between two aged people that have been together a long time and are well familiar with each other's kinks and flaws.
Two elderly people embark on a romantic relationship in spite of their considerable life experience.
The idea that we are given mysterious signs that, if only noticed and interpreted, tell us something important about the future.

examples.examples: Worf used the Boraalan people's belief in omens to his advantage in tng7x13 "Homeward".

description: The many trials and tribulations involved in rearing a child while frequently moving from one place to another, as opposed to being settled down, is featured.

examples.examples: The Sutter family found it so hard to raise a child while on assignments in space that they required counseling in tng5x22 "Imaginary Friend".

description: Featured is a technology which is now real though it was near enough sci-fi at the time of the making.
The conviction that the future events of one's live are written in the stars, so to speak, and cannot be changed.
A consummated but short lived romantic involvement is featured.

examples.examples: Helen Noel reminded Captain Kirk about what happened between them when he dropped in at the science lab Christmas party in tos1x10 "Dagger of the Mind".

description: When purchasing purchasing and services customers are sometimes asked to sign or tacitly agree to lengthy licensing agreements that few of us will read carefully. We are made to contemplate this situation and ponder whether and to what extent we should accept the practice as a social good.

examples.examples: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-user_license_agreement

description: Two or more people engage in an intimate relationship that is sexually non- monogamous.
We are asked to what extent, if any, it is acceptable or wise for people to have multiple sex partners.

examples.examples: Argelian culture in tos2x07 "Wolf in the Fold" was sexually permissive to put it nicely.

description: This intersection between theater and singing is featured with focus on its production or artistic qualities.

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities
the fine arts and the humanities

description: There is a hypothetical world (maybe a parallel universe or a fantasy land) where some or several laws of nature (or suchlike aspects of reality) are reversed.

examples.examples: The Enterprise got sucked into just such a universe in tas2x06 "The Counter- Clock Incident".

description: We are shown that sometimes people that are very much unlike in some respects can be attracted to each other.
A character is defiant towards authority and authority figures to a notable degree.

examples.examples: In "The Matrix" (1999), Neo's boss at the software company inside the Matrix complains that Neo thought the rules somehow didn't apply to him.

description: The general attitude of having an optimistic outlook on life is compared with the general attitude of having a pessimistic outlook on life.
A spaceflight in which a spacecraft is placed on a trajectory where it could remain in space for at least one orbit.
Weapons are strategically placed in space, in orbit around a planet, from where they can easily be deployed against any desired target.

examples.examples: The Enterprise visited the 20th century and found that Earth was about to go down the path of self-obliteration by putting nukes in orbit in tos2x26 "Assignment: Earth".

description: Civilization on a planet is threatened when asteroids are directed on a collision course with the planet.

The typically desirable quality of order in society is contraposed with the typically desirable quality of individual freedom. Should we limit how people can move about in order to avoid potential chaos?
The forcible removal of a person's organs to be used as transplants and sold on the black market is featured as a crime.

examples.examples: Spock's brain was harvested by aliens who wanted it as a computer in tos3x06 "Spock's Brain".

description: The particular social problem of large centralized enterprises that engage in criminal activity is displayed.
This is the category of themes pertaining to the doctrines and practices that tend to be features of institutional religions.
Someone grows up having no parents for all or part of their childhood.
The care of orphans in society is expolred.
An artificial intelligence goes amok and makes trouble for society.
Something goes wrong during a scientific experiment, and everyone dies. Perhaps a particle accelerator created a black hole. Stupid scientists.
The potential problem of a technology somehow getting out of hand and damaging the lives and well being of large groups of people are discussed from a society point of view.
A character experiences a feeling being outside of their own physical body.

A person experiences a persistent, extensive, and deep involvement in some fantasy or other. The involvement is beyond what can be considered normal behavior, and affects the person's day to day life to some extent.
Someone strives to overcome a limitation of theirs.
Someone struggles to overcome being addicted to a substance or activity, e.g., a drug or gambling.

examples.examples: Barclay struggled with getting his holodeck addiction under control in tng3x21 "Hollow Pursuits".

description: A character feels that they cannot function fully without a certain object or the like, but that is all in their head and they struggle to overcome this mental barrier.

examples.examples: In ds97x10 "It's Only a Paper Moon" Nog required a cane to walk even though the doctor's said there is absolutely nothing wrong with his leg. When at one point he became emotionally upset and forgot to use the cane it became apparent that this was indeed just a mental block that he should seek to overcome.

description: Someone struggles to overcome a feeling of fear or embarrassment that stops them from behaving in a natural way.

examples.examples: Barclay began his long journey towards overcoming shyness in tng3x21 "Hollow Pursuits".

description: There is a world that is stereotypically hellish due to too many people using up too much space and other resources.
People just keep on reproducing until all the planets resources are depleted and everyone dies from starvation etc.

examples.examples: The Gideans had extended their own lifespans remarkably but were completely unable to control their own reproduction and had so overpopulated their planet that people lived literally shoulder to shoulder in tos3x17 "The Mark of Gideon".

description: A parent pays unusually close attention to a child's experiences and problems, particularly at educational institutions. Figuratively, the parent hovers over the child like a helicopter.

There is a world that is severely dysfunctional because its society is overburdened by onerous and ill-considered regulations that hinder people from effectively producing the goods and services they require to be happy.

examples.examples: In the short film "Libra" (1978), life on an overregulated Earth seems bleak as the international planning commission imposes variously silly and corrupt regulations that stifle productivity. The whole planet suffers from rolling black-outs as it can no longer even produce the electricity it needs to light up its board rooms.

description: The environmental issue of human activity causing the ozone layer to weaken is featured. This leads to increased ultraviolet radiation which is thought to be harmful to life in general.

examples.examples: The Aldeans had gone sterile in tng1x17 "When The Bough Breaks" as a result of their planet's ozone layer having become depleted.

description: Someone believes that violence should never be used. In the extreme, a pacifist may feel that violence should not even be used in self-defence against violence.

examples.examples: A replica of the Vulcan philosopher Surak espoused pacifism as a way of life in tos3x22 "The Savage Curtain".

description: A belt-like device used to induce unbearable pain in its wearer without causing physical injury.

examples.examples: The Eymorg outfitted Captain Kirk, McCoy, and Scotty with pain belts in tos3x06 "Spock's Brain".

description: A collar-like device used to induce unbearable pain in its wearer without causing physical injury.

examples.examples: A trio of disembodied brains employed "collars of obedience" to maintain control over their thrall gladiators in tos2x17 "The Gamesters of Triskelion".

description: A medical device implanted in the body to induce unbearable pain in its wearer without causing physical injury.

examples.examples: Arctus Baran was not above using neural servos (i.e. pain implant devices) to keep control over his rogue crew in tng7x04 "Gambit, Part I" and tng7x05 "Gambit, Part II".

description: The art of drawing pictures is featured.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

description: The hypothesis that life exists throughout the universe and is distributed naturally by asteroids and comets or perhaps even at the direction of aliens.
A hypothetical self-contained universe co-existing with our own.

notes.notes: The word "dimension" is used in two different sense in fiction. Sometimes what is meant is no different from a parallel universe. Sometimes what is meant is a fourth spatial dimension of space as an addition to the three we know. In the latter case we use "four-dimensional space" as a theme.

description: A device used to paralyze people. The effect is typically temporary.
A being that lives as a parasite off of other life forms.

examples.examples: Bug-like neural parasites from outer space nearly took over Starfleet by attaching themselves to important officers' brainstems in tng1x25 "Conspiracy".

description: The relationship between a parent and their child is featured.
A parent and their child compete over status or some objective in a less than amicable manner.

examples.examples: Riker settled his long-standing rivalry with his father Kyle in the anbo- jtytsu dohyo tng2x14 "The Icarus Factor".

theme_name: parent's right to make decisions for their child
description: Discussed is to what extent parents should be legally able to make important decisions on their child's behalf. For example, to what extent should parents dictate that their child undergo life-altering operations, say a sex-change, or prevent their child receiving medical attention when it might be of benefit? To what extent should parents be able to indoctrinate their child in a religion or cult?

examples.examples: In bbf1x10 "Believers", we must ponder whether it was right that Shon's parents could refuse Shon receiving a life saving surgery from Babylon 5's Doctor Franklin.

description: We are asked whether and to what extent the practice of blocking children from access to different kinds of contents, sights, and experiences is beneficial for them.
A child is not all that a parent wishes them to be.
The love of a parent for their child is featured.
A parent shows pride in their offspring.

theme_name: parenting a child with special needs
description: A character struggles with bringing up a child who needs assistance for disabilities that may be medical, mental, or psychological (e.g. a learning disability, attention deficit disorder, autism.).
The struggle of a parent to raise a child that has a significant mental disability of some sort, is featured. For example, a learning disability, attention deficit disorder, autism, etc.

parents.parents: parenting a child with special needs

ancestors.ancestors: parenting a child with special needs

description: The struggle of a parent to raise a child that has a significant physical disability of some sort, is featured.

parents.parents: parenting a child with special needs

ancestors.ancestors: parenting a child with special needs

description: We are shown a highly parodical version of what life in academia might seem to be like.
A character murders a close relative of theirs.

notes.notes: This theme is also applied in cases where a close in-law relative is killed.

examples.examples: In ahp1x24 "The Perfect Murder", two greedy nephews conspire to murder their aunt in order to access an inheritance.

description: A character is excited by machines made for transporting people and things, i.e., cars, boats, planes etc. Often the character is particularly interested in speed and things that go fast.

notes.notes: This theme is also used when children are fascinated with toy vehicles, assuming they are old enough to understand the connection with the genuine article.

description: We are shown what things might seem like in the here and now if viewed from a past person's perspective.
The love of a father for his child is featured.
A character lies compulsively and disproportionately to any discernible end in view.
There is a social system in which exclusively men have political power.
A character murders their own father.

examples.examples: Kylo Ren murdered his own father Hans Solo by running him through with a light saber in "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" (2015).

description: A character believes fervently in the causes of their homeland.
An ideal state of freedom and peace within and among the nations on a world.

examples.examples: The people of Earth lived in peace and without the need for weapons in "Barbarella" (1968).

description: Two recently warring factions are talking to each other (potentially with an intermediary or mediator involved) with the aim of reaching an accord and stopping the violence.
The struggle for social dominance in the workplace is featured.

examples.examples: Chief Engineer Logan stormed to the bridge to issue a challenge Geordi's authority in the midst of a heated space battle in tng1x21 "The Arsenal of Freedom". Geordi, who had been left in command of the Enterprise-D, promptly ordered Logan back to main engineering.

description: We are made to contemplate how adults that are sexually attracted to minors affect society, and how such individuals ought to be treated.
A member of some group is pressured into making a certain choice by other members of that group.
We are asked to what extent, if any, it might be ethically acceptable to create human clones to harvest their organs.

Someone who was of a certain character proves later to have changed in a profound and, perhaps, surprising way. For example, a no-good punk, juvenile delinquent might reform their wicked ways to become a veritable saint.

examples.examples: Returning defector Stefan DeSeve had really seen the error of his ways in tng6x14 "Face of the Enemy".

theme_name: people endangering their lives in ways that don't hurt other people
description: We are asked when and to what extent people should be able to put their lives in danger, even if nobody besides themself is harmed in the process.

examples.examples: People were protesting in the streets to get a game show banned in "Le prix du danger" (1983). In the game show, willing contestants took on life threatening challenges in exchange for large cash prizes - if they lived.

theme_name: people forced to be average dystopia
description: There is a dystopian society in which people who are exceptional, in one way or another, are censored. They may for example be killed, or have some form of handicap imposed on them.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x06a "Examination Day", a 12 year old boy was lawfully disposed of after he failed his intelligence test with an above acceptable performance. His dimwitted parents were, naturally, distraught.

theme_name: people may not always live up to their reputations
description: A character anticipates what another will be based on their reputation but comes to find that the reputation was not entirely warranted.

The idea is presented that a sentient entity has more or less deliberately intervened to shape that history in a way that is not normal. This typically necessitates some form of time travel or clandestine visit by someone who is not supposed to be part of our history.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x22c "The Library", an aspiring writer discovered she could retroactively change reality by rewriting books containing descriptions of her loved ones lives.

description: There is a transportation system that enables someone to enter into one end of a tube and get shipped through to the other end.

examples.examples: Markham observed people getting around a future New York City in penumatic tubes in "A Visitor from the Twentieth Century" by Harold Donitz (1928).

description: The performing arts are arts such as music, dance, and drama which are performed for an audience. It is different from visual arts, which is when artists use paint, canvas or various materials to create physical or static art objects. Performing arts include a range of disciplines which are performed in front of a live audience, including theatre, music, and dance. It can also include circus skills, vaudeville, professional wrestling, to name a few examples of activities that some may be reluctant to consider "art" in the normal sense.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

description: We are asked to what extent, if any, drugs used to enhance performance should be tolerated. This could be in the context of sports, the military, or a university test for example.

examples.examples: Three women used beauty-enhancing drugs to get ahead in the game of love in tos1x03 "Mudd's Women".

description: Someone finds themself on a perilous voyage on the high seas.
The matter of perjury in relation to miscarriages of justice is explored.
A hypothetical machine that can do work indefinitely without an energy source.
A character is obsessed with exaggerated or irrational worries about being the object of hostility, conspiracy, etc.
A character feels strongly for a worthy cause and tries hard to further it. It sometimes turns out to be a bad cause but it is the motives that define the theme.

A character struggles with a tough decision that involves choices that are hard because they involve moral considerations. Would you, for example, let another person die if that was the only way to save your own life?
There is a wearable technological device, such as a suit or a jet pack, which allows its user to fly.
A character must decide what is more important to them: love and commitment or the freedom of being single.

examples.examples: McCoy chose to live under the domination of the Oracle of the People so that he might live out his days with his love Natira in tos3x10 "For the World is Hollow and I Have Touched the Sky".

description: A person is followed by a ghost or suchlike supernatural creature.

The tricky, as yet sci-fi:ish, question of what precisely constitutes ones "personhood" is posed: Is it DNA, the body, the brain, memories, something elusive called the "soul," or a combination of these? What happens, legally and ethically, if some of these are copied or transferred somehow?
There is technology by which a person can render their own body practically invisible.
A character must make a difficult choice regarding whether someone else lives or dies.

notes.notes: When a character is contemplating sacrificing their own life for one reason or another, the theme category "human self-sacrifice" is used.
