description: A stereotypical Irish character is featured. This typically involves heavy drinking, lots of green, and whimsical, singsongy accents.

examples.examples: The Enterprise-D transported a group of technophobic space-colonists of Irish descent, the Bringloidi, in tng2x18 "Up The Long Ladder".

description: A stereotypically Japanese character is notably featured. This may involve excessive stoicism, notions of honor, and ritual suicide.
A stereotypical Jewish character is featured in what is a sometimes prejudiced and antisemitic nature.

examples.examples: The Zeons were persecuted by Ekosians dressed in full Nazi regalia in tos2x23 "Patterns of Force".

description: We are asked to what extent, if any, it is acceptable to kill other animals for food or sport.

The Korean War was a war between North Korea, with military support from China and the Soviet Union, and South Korea, backed by personnel from the United Nations (principally the United States). The war began on 25 June 1950 when North Korea invaded South Korea following clashes along the border and insurrections in the south. The war ended unofficially on 27 July 1953 in an armistice. This historical human conflict is featured in the story.
A character working with translation, interpreting, subtitling, or the like is engaged in their chosen occupation.
A character working directly with the interpretation of law, for example a lawyer, prosecutor, or judge, is engaged in their chosen occupation.
This fabled city in South America is featured.

examples.examples: In "Aguirre the Wrath of God" (1972), we saw a band of Spanish conquistadors meat their doom on the Amazon River while obsessively pursuing the chimera of El Dorado.

description: The legend of King Arthur and his round table is featured.

theme_name: the letter of the law vs. the spirit of the law
description: The following dilemma is illustrated: Language and writing is fallible and there is always ambiguity and room for misunderstanding. So to what extent should the law be obeyed to the letter, and to what extent should we instead look to the intent of the legislators and, ultimately, our own sense of right and wring?

theme_name: the life of a loved one vs. the lives of many
description: A character must choose between the life and/or well being of a loved one on one hand, and the lives and/or well being of a group of other people on the other.

examples.examples: Captain Picard was in a crux when Natasha Yar got abducted by ebony skinned aliens who held a desperately needed vaccine in tng1x04 "Code of Honor".

description: The idea that language is not always up to the task of accurately expressing thoughts and notions on one hand, or objective reality on the other, is expressed.
The empirical limits of science in regard to limits of human ability to inquire and answer questions about phenomena.
A character wants nothing better than to acquire more money and possessions.
A character seeks ever more influence in society and the means to make people do their bidding.

theme_name: the making of a monster to society
description: The social factors involved in the development of a psychopathic criminal are explored.

examples.examples: Armus became a being of pure evil when the Titans left him behind in tng1x23 "Skin of Evil".

description: Someone working on or with a seafaring vessel is engaged in their chosen occupation. Typically this means sailors, captains, and other naval officers.

examples.examples: In "Two Lost Worlds" (1951), we saw the day-to-day lives of the crew members of an American clipper ship as they pursued pirates across the Pacific Ocean all the way to a volcanic island inhabited by dinosaurs.

description: A character working with health care, typically in a hospital or comparable institution, is engaged in their chosen occupation.
Democracy is contrasted with autocracy and the point is made that the former can be inefficient and slow in making decisions where the later can act decisively.

There is a character whose main occupation involves being part of the armed forces of a putative state, or the like. This may, for example, be because they work professionally as an officer or because they are conscripted as privates.

There is an informal alliance between a nation's military and the defense industry that supplies it, seen together as a vested interest which influences public policy, typically in a nefarious way in fiction, is featured.

We are asked when and to what extent it is acceptable to colonize another land and bring your own culture there, perhaps displacing indigenous inhabitants and surely having some impact on the environment.

examples.examples: The Federation was preparing a seemingly lifeless planet for colonization in tng1x18 "Home Soil", but it turns out that it harbored a really unusual form of life.

theme_name: the mythological figure was really an alien
description: The outlandish notion that some historical (or legendary) character from human mythology was really an alien in disguise, is put forth.
There is a stereotypical depiction of a Native American, i.e. with feather headgear, tomahawks, peace pipes, etc.

examples.examples: On the planet Amerind there were people who were just like a 20th century stereotype of pre-colonial Native Americans in tos3x03 "The Paradise Syndrome".

theme_name: the nature of animal instincts in humans
description: Those ancient instincts that are deeply rooted in the reptile core of our brains are discussed. They typically involve aggression, survival, and reproduction.

examples.examples: Suppressed animal instincts come to the surface as the crew begins to de- evolve in tng7x19 "Genesis".

description: The question of what "beauty" really is, is discussed. Why do we call some things "beautiful"?

examples.examples: McCoy pondered what it is that attracts us to cute little Tribbles in tos2x13 "The Trouble with Tribbles".

description: It is discussed what precisely human "creativity" is and from whence it comes.
Existential questions about the end of life are discussed.

examples.examples: The immortal alien being Nagilum killed Enterprise-D crew in order to understand the nature of this whole dying business in tng2x02 "Where Silence Has Lease".

description: The experience of fear and its root causes is discussed.
The complex ins and outs (no pun intended) of human mating rituals are discussed.
What emotions are and what they mean to us is discussed.

theme_name: the nature of human perception of time
description: How we sense and think of time is discussed.

examples.examples: Data put the aphorism "a watched pot never boils" to the test in tng6x25 "Timescape".

description: What it means to leave people in stitches is pondered.
The emotion of love and associated activities are pondered from a philosophical perspective.
The definition for, and workings of, human memory is discussed.

examples.examples: Telepathic aliens studied memory and the subconscious in tng5x12 "Violations".

description: The why and how of nightmares is discussed. Typically, there is a lengthy discussion about what someone's bad dreams imply about them.

examples.examples: In tz1959e2x17 "Twenty-Two", the Doctor attempted to prove that Liz's strange experience was actually a recurring nightmare, by having her conduct an experiment.

description: What our senses are and how they work is discussed.
The workings of the subconscious mind is explored.
A stereotypical Nazi character is featured. This typically involves military fatigues with Swastikas, hatred for other races, admiration for a strong leader, glorification of violence, sadism, etc.

theme_name: the need for a challenge in life
description: It is suggested that humans, in order to feel fulfilled, need some kind of long term challenge to overcome.

theme_name: the need for a purpose in life
description: It is suggested that humans, in order to feel fulfilled, need some kind of long term purpose to work toward.
A character, in order to feel fulfilled, need some kind of adventure in their life.
We see that humans tend to feel bad about past affairs being left partially unresolved or unknown. We would, e.g., dislike not knowing whether a missing family member is dead or alive.

examples.examples: Geordi found closure in accepting the death of his mother in tng7x03 "Interface" by speaking with an alien entity that had taken on her identity.

description: It is illustrated that humans need close friends or life partners etc. in order to feel fulfilled.
It is illustrated that humans often need to feel they have roots in a culture in order to feel content in life.
It is suggested that humans do not feel good about being in captivity or otherwise deprived of liberty.
It is illustrated that lack of privacy, if taken too far, will lead to unhappy and ill-functioning humans.

examples.examples: Miranda was born with the ability to hear thoughts and might have gone insane, in tos3x07 "Is There in Truth No Beauty?", had she not learned how to shut the voices out.

theme_name: the need for rest and recreation
description: It is illustrated that people, in order to function well, need to rest and unwind with amusing activities from time to time.

examples.examples: Captain Picard reluctantly took in a little R&R on Risa in tng3x19 "Captain's Holiday".

description: The human need to clear their names from perceived accusations or suspicions is featured.

examples.examples: In tos1x12 "The Conscience of the King", Kodos the Executioner justified committing genocide as governor of Tarsus IV to Captain Kirk, saying that it was a matter of life and death.

description: It is illustrated that people, in order to function well, need sleep.

theme_name: the need to be treated with respect
description: It is illustrated that humans feel bad if they are not treated with sufficient respect by their fellow humans.
The human need to be part of and accepted into a social group is demonstrated.

theme_name: the need to feel useful to society
description: It is illustrate that humans in order to be content must feel that they have a meaningful place in society.

theme_name: the need to get there on one's own merits
description: It is illustrated that humans may put high importance on achieving something by their own merits, rather than having it handed to them on a silver plate.

theme_name: the need to know one's roots
description: It suggested that people need to understand where they come from and who their nearest ancestors are in order to be content.

theme_name: the need to maintain an image
description: It is illustrated that humans, to function well in society, to some extent must maintain an outwards facade that can be quite different from their true inner selves.

examples.examples: Captain Picard took elaborate measured to prevent the crew from learning that he suffered from a heart condition in order to maintain his image in tng2x17 "Samaritan Snare".

theme_name: the need to prove one's self
description: It is illustrated that humans, in order to feel content, may feel the need to demonstrate that the skills they claim to have are true, to themselves and to others.
The urge some people have to travel the world and explore new places is featured.

aliases.aliases: wanderlust the need to see the world

description: A stereotypical nerd character is featured. This typically involves the wearing of glasses, social awkwardness, and an excessive interest in things intellectual.

examples.examples: Wily Spock ordered the computer to compute pi to the last digit in tos2x07 "Wolf in the Fold".

description: The natural process by which life is thought to have arisen from non-living matter such as simple organic compounds is featured.

examples.examples: Q brought Captain Picard back in time and showed him the bubbling pool of ooze from which the first complex organic molecules on Earth would emerge in tng7x25 "All Good Things...".

description: A stereotypical pirate is featured. This typically involves the flying of skull and crossbones flags, the wearing of eye patches, plundering, and lots of "hardy har har" talk.

examples.examples: Orion space pirates hijacked a Federation cargo freighter in tas2x01 "The Pirates of Orion". Contrary to popular belief they did not appear to wield space cutlasses.

description: The phenomena where patients given a placebo treatment have a perceived or actual improvement in a medical condition.

examples.examples: In the end the Mudd's women found that it was the confidence a drug had inspired that made them beautiful rather than the drug itself in tos1x03 "Mudd's Women".

description: A character suffers from a disease described as the plague, be it bubonic, septicemic, pneumonic, or some minor fictional variation on the genuine article.

examples.examples: In ahp1x05 "Into Thin Air", the kind of air most conducive to vanishings, it is revealed at the end that Diana's mysteriously vanished mother had in fact succumbed to the bubonic plague, and being secretly taken away by the authorities for bureaucratic reasons.

theme_name: the power of art to influence people
description: The idea is expressed that ideas expressed skillfully through art have the potential to influence and shape people and society.
The pros and cons of the presumption of innocence as a legal right are explored.

examples.examples: On Tanuga IV, by contrast with the Federation, people were presumed to be guilty until proven innocent in tng3x14 "A Matter of Perspective".

theme_name: the price of freedom is eternal vigilance
description: We are shown that freedom comes with a price and should not be taken for granted.
A professional private investigation is engaged in their chosen occupation.
Discussed is the ancient problem of how to reconcile the existence of evil with the existence of an omnipotent, omnibenevolent, and omniscient God.

examples.examples: "The Epicurian paradox" famously goes as follows: Is God willing to prevent evil, but not able? Then he is not omnipotent. Is he able, but not willing? Then he is malevolent. Is he both able and willing? Then whence cometh evil? Is he neither able nor willing? Then why call him God?

description: How torture affects the mind of victim, perpetrator, bystanders, etc. is explored.

A character working with the dissemination of literature, music, and information is engaged in their chosen occupation. For example, we may see an author work with a literary agent to find a publisher willing to print and sell a book.

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected6x10 "The Luncheon", Tony spent his last Â£37 on lunch with the wife of a famous film producer in an effort to secure a film deal for his novel.

description: This is the category of themes that are primarily about how world and the universe operates irrespective of its human inhabitants. For example, the themes may discuss scientific, religious, philosophical, artistic, and humanist views on the nature of reality.

theme_name: the qualities of a good leader
description: What it takes to lead other people effectively is discussed.

theme_name: the qualities of a good wife
description: A character is concerned with what a woman should be like in order to make a good house wife.
A character is tempted by a perceived chance to live on well beyond what is considered to be a normal lifespan.

examples.examples: Ira Graves surreptitiously transferred his consciousness into Data in an effort to gain eternal life in tng2x06 "The Schizoid Man".

description: What in our minds attract us to games of different sorts is pondered.

examples.examples: Data, Troi and Pulaski discussed why we enjoy playing games in tng2x21 "Peak Performance".

theme_name: the religious end of the world
description: A religious doctrine that predicates the end of all material things for one reason or another is featured.

examples.examples: The people of Ventax II thought the prophesied end was neigh when their devil seemed to appear in the flesh in tng4x13 "Devil's Due".

theme_name: the right to a fair trial
description: We are made to ponder what kind of legal procedures are required before action may be taken to deprive someone of their freedom or property, etc.

examples.examples: Admiral Norah Satie's investigation of Simon Tarses turned into a witch-hunt because of her racial prejudice against Romulans in tng4x21 "The Drumhead".

description: The perceived human right to receive a reasonable level of education is featured.

theme_name: the right to exist of a genocidal people
description: The following dilemma is illustrated: Suppose a peoples engages in pathological killing and genocide; do they themselves then have the right to exist? Would we be morally justified in visiting genocide on them? Is there room for doubt?

examples.examples: In tng3x03 "The Survivors", should the 50 billion strong race of aggressive conquerers known as the Husnock be permitted to run amok around the galaxy? The all-powerful Douwd didn't think so and wiped them out of existence with a thought. Then he suffered grievous pangs of conscience.

description: The putative human right to keep some affairs and doings private is discussed. I.e., the government or other institutions in society should not excessively intrude on this right using mass surveillance etc.

theme_name: the right to privacy of thoughts
description: We are made to ponder to what extent and in what way it might be acceptable to figure out what someone is thinking, or to covertly manipulate their thought processes. Is it okay to use technology (or innate ability) to read someone's mind?

examples.examples: Telepathic aliens visiting the Enterprise-D claimed to respect peoples' right to privacy of thought but one of them turns out to be a psychopath in tng5x12 "Violations".

theme_name: the road to hell is paved with good intentions
description: This old adage, usually meaning that many bad things have come about because of people who thought they were doing good, is illustrated.

theme_name: the role of the disabled in society
description: The role of disabled people in society is explored.

examples.examples: Miranda Jones hid her blindness and proved she could do just as well as a normal person in tos3x07 "Is There in Truth No Beauty?".

theme_name: the role of the elderly in society
description: The role of the elderly in society is explored.

theme_name: the role of war veterans in society
description: The role of war veterans in society is explored.

examples.examples: The Angosians tucked their genetically engineered war veterans safely away on a shabby little moon in tng3x11 "The Hunted".

description: Events popularly knowns as The Russian Revolution of 1905, are featured. This was a wave of mass political and social unrest that spread through vast areas of the Russian Empire, some of which was directed at the government. It included worker strikes, peasant unrest, and military mutinies.

examples.examples: The film "Battleship Potemkin" (1925) romanticizes a mutiny aboard the eponymous vessel and its involvement with the 1905 uprisings in Odessa.

description: The Salem witch trials were a series of hearings and prosecutions of people accused of witchcraft in colonial Massachusetts between February 1692 and May 1693. This theme is used whenever this event is featured in the story.

notes.notes: For the intents and purposes of thematic annotation we shall assume that any witch trials referenced as taking place in colonial Massachusetts, in fact the Salem Witch trials, unless otherwise is said explicitly.

description: A scientist is engaged in their chosen occupation.
A stereotypical Scottish character is featured. This typically involves kilts, haggis, and bagpipes.

examples.examples: Beverly Crusher attended her grandmother's funeral on a planet colonized by Scottish admirers in tng7x14 "Sub Rosa".

description: A character working with espionage or the like is engaged in their chosen profession.

notes.notes: This profession is naturally a gray area between legal, illegal, and war type of themes. It is included here because there are many stories that feature romanticized ideas of secret agents as heroes.

description: The idea is put forth that war is an immature and undignified way to resolve problems.
The magnificent luxury cruiser RMS Titanic that famously hit an ice berg and sank in 1912, is featured.
The doctrine that humans (and perhaps other sentient beings if they exist) have an immaterial, intangible and immortal component that will somehow continue to exist after the body dies.

examples.examples: Captain Pike balked at the notion that having free reign in an Orion den of sin was worth a man's soul in tos0x01 "The Cage".

description: This, sometimes controversial, sport wherein two people wear safety gear and try punch each other in a boxing ring, is notably featured.
This iconic story universe is featured as an object within some story that is not itself part of the franchise.

examples.examples: In futurama4x11 "Where No Fan Has Gone Before", the protagonists encounter the living heads of the main actors from the original Star Trek TV series and get wound up in a narrative that is clearly a parody on one of the iconic Star Trek stories.

description: Presented is the idea that flocks of people acting in unison often end up acting with remarkable baseness and folly.

examples.examples: In tz1959e5x07 "The Old Man in the Cave", townspeople disillusioned of the old-man-in-a-cave myth irrationally smashed to smithereens their only hope of salvation: a powerful computer.

description: Things that are traditionally thought of as not being valid targets for rational inquiry and experimentation are featured. Typically ghosts, spirits, and the like.

examples.examples: Two extradimensional aliens used their mysterious abilities to conjure up a haunted castle and other things from the dark depths of human imagination in tos2x01 "Catspaw".

description: There is a school teacher, or the like, engaged in their chosen profession.
A character working in a technology oriented company is engaged in their chosen occupation.
A character is employed to tend to the machines that other people are using.

The idea that at some point AI will become more advanced than humans. Then they will accelerate the development of even more advanced AI, and so on ad infinitum. The result will be completely unpredictable and may make humans obsolete in the wink of an eye, goes the thinking.
The art of playing out stories live is featured.

parents.parents: the fine arts and the humanities

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

description: Featured is the process of change in all forms of life over generations that is characterized by mutation, genetic drift, and natural selection.
A character wants ever more information, understanding, and knowledge.

theme_name: the thrill is in the chase
description: Featured is the idea that life is often more exciting while one tries to accomplish something, than it is once that goal has been achieved. Sometimes that excitement may seem more valuable than the utility of whatever the goal was.

examples.examples: In tz1959e4x14 "Of Late I Think of Cliffordville", the business tycoon Mr. Feathersmith had just finished diminishing his last major rival and considered that his empire was now everything it possibly could be. The satisfaction soon waned, however and he turned to the bottle while reminiscing on how much more fun it had been facing the various challenges in the early days of his career. When the Devil appeared to offer him a chance to do it over again, Mr. Feathersmith jumped on the opportunity.

description: A character experiences the feeling of exuberance that can sometimes come with a perilous situation.
This legendary figure, who collects teeth from beneath children's pillows and leaves a small remuneration in exchange, is featured.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x16c "Tooth and Consequences", the Tooth Fairy himself appears before a depressed dentist to grant him whatever he wished.

description: An idea famously suggested by Allan Turing that when AI can fool humans, they will indeed by intelligent.

theme_name: the unappreciated and unimportant at the workplace
description: The ungratifying experience of someone who is at the very bottom rung of the corporate ladder is featured.
We must ponder the possibility that reality as we know it is simply the dream of one's self, or of some other sentient entity.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x23a "Shadow Play", Adam was convinced that his execution wouldn't matter because he is only dreaming.

description: We must ponder the possibility that all we know is just a simulation within a larger reality.

notes.notes: Typically the simulation is featured as being within a computer, but this is not a requirement. The simulation might be a physical contained space within a larger reality.

examples.examples: Dr. James Moriarty was to unwittingly live out his simulated life in a simulated universe in tng6x12 "Ship in a Bottle", but who knows: maybe we all are?

theme_name: the use of personality altering medication
description: We are asked to ponder whether and when it is justified in medicine to prescribe such drugs as may alleviate symptoms, but do so at the expense of severely altering the mind and character of a patient.

examples.examples: In nightgallery3x13 "Whisper", we saw Charlie decline a doctor's suggestion that he prescribe personality altering drugs to Charlie's wife. Charlie believed his wife might loose her quirky and erratic yet charming nature.

description: Whether and to what extent our imagination is of benefit to us is discussed.
The historical event known as the Vietnam War is featured. The Vietnam War was conflict in Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia that lasted from November 1955 to the fall of Saigon on 30 April 1975.
A character working with art forms such as painting, drawing, printmaking, sculpture, ceramics, photography, video, filmmaking, design, crafts, and architecture is engaged in their occupation.
The time tested wisdom that time tested wisdom and history are generally constructed by the winners of conflicts and would possibly look quite different if such conflicts had ended differently.

The basic instinct in humans to fight for self-preservation is discussed more or less explicitly.

Note: Since many if not most stories feature some sort of struggle for survival, this theme should be used only when the psychological force is more or less explicitly made topical.
This story from 1900 is explicitly featured or parodied.
The taking of another (legal) person's (property or services or scrap money without that person's permission or consent with the intent to deprive the rightful owner of it, is featured.

notes.notes: The legal person who is deprived may be for example an individual, a company, or a state.

description: There is a society in which one or more gods are recognized as rulers and the ruling elite is essentially a priesthood (or the gods themselves).
A hypothetical all-encompassing theory of physics that fully explains and links together all physical aspects of the universe.

examples.examples: Barclay had a heated discussion with a virtual Albert Einstein about this theory on the holodeck in tng4x19 "The Nth Degree".

description: Albert Einstein's theories regarding the nature of space, time, and gravity are featured to some extent.

examples.examples: Holographic recreations of Stephen Hawking, Isaac Newton, and Albert Einstein quibbled about this and other things in tng6x26 "Descent".

description: The idea is put forth that, however bad your disadvantages are, there is always someone out there who would be a willing and suitable romantic match for you.
The time tested wisdom that we are stronger when we stand united is illustrated.

examples.examples: Kor explained that the Klingons are united and therefore strong in tos1x27 "Errand of Mercy".

description: The idea that diversity in itself may be desirable, is featured. For example, it may be noted that diversity in skills and in thinking can be very useful to a society.

That redundancy, a copy which does not add value while the original is around, can in fact be a good thing (because the original may break) is featured. As "redundancy" is often a byword for "waste", the observation is perhaps worth making.

aliases.aliases: reliance on a single point of failure is unwise

description: A being that thrives in extreme heat.

examples.examples: The Tholians of tos3x09 "The Tholian Web" were a non-humanoid, thermophilic species.

theme_name: thinking about one's accomplishments in life
description: A character reflects upon what they have done (or failed to do) with their life. This is often at the core of a midlife crisis.

theme_name: those who do not remember the past are condemned to relive it
description: This time-tested piece of wisdom is demonstrated.
A character is able to make physical objects that did not previously exist, appear as out of thin air.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to physical things

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to physical things

description: There is a vehicle that is controlled simply by thinking, without using knobs, wheels, levers, etc.
We imagine what the world would be like if certain ways of thinking could be detected and punished by the government.

Civilization as we know it is jeopardized by the activities of living beings from another planet. This may, for example, involve an invasion, colonization, infiltration, or preemptive attempt by aliens to wipe out humanity. Alternatively, it may involve some sort of alien accident.
The harnessing of tidal energy as a power source for technology is explored.

examples.examples: The dystopian city in "Logan's Run" (1976) was powered by the tides.

description: A planet one side of which always faces its parent star, like how the same side of the moon always faces the earth.

examples.examples: Captain Picard secretly met various Federation starship captains on the tidally locked planet Dytallix B in tng1x15 "Conspiracy".

description: Time itself comes to a complete stop.
A repeated period of time that is typically re-experienced by those within it.

Featured is a hypothetical device in the form of a vehicle or of a portal connecting distant points in spacetime, either to an earlier time or to a later time, without the need for the time-traveling body to experience the intervening period in the usual sense.
A doorway in time.

A character is able at will to turn back the clock, to some extent, and do things over again. Typically they retain their memories while everything else in the universe is reset to an earlier state of affairs.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to reality at large

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to reality at large

description: Time itself is observed to slow to a crawl.

notes.notes: The theme "time freeze" is used in the limiting case when time comes to a complete and utter stop.

description: A character is somehow able to slow down or even freeze time. Typically the person with the ability can still move, breathe, and even interact with otherwise frozen objects and persons.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to reality at large

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to reality at large

description: The concept of movement between past and future points in time.

There is an apparent contradiction, or logical contradiction associated with the  idea of time and time travel. Typically, temporal paradoxes fall into two broad groups: consistency paradoxes exemplified by the grandfather paradox, and causal loops.

theme_name: time traveler living secretly among us
description: A character who has traveled from a another time lives secretly among normal people.
A person travels back in time and changes history somehow.

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x20a "Profile in Silver", we saw history professor Dr. Joseph Fitzgerald travel back in time from the year 2172 to quietly observe President John F. Kennedy. Alas, when the sinister moment arrived Joseph could not stop himself but impulsively intervened to save the much admired President. This action had unexpected and dire consequences for the world.

description: The following dilemma is illustrated: What should we do if some people find a way to affect the past? They could stop Hitler, yes, but what untold damage might they also do?
A character must choose whether to satisfy their own blood thirst, lust for vengeance, etc., on one hand, or to show mercy, compassion, etc., on the other.

theme_name: to settle down vs. to keep on trekking
description: A character considers whether or not it is time to settle down at specific place instead of traveling around.

theme_name: to tell the truth vs. offering a comforting lie
description: A character must choose between telling a comforting white lie on one hand, and being honest on the other.
We are made to ponder the practice of some humans to deliberately inflict severe physical or psychological suffering on people that are in their power.
There is a society in which the ruling government aspires to complete control over all aspects of life, i.e., including what people should read, think, say, and do in their "free time".
The social problem of what to do with toxic waste, for example radioactive garbage, is brought up.
A contraption used to produce a beam of gravity to attract material objects at a distance but in a desired direction.
Someone emphasizes tradition and doing things "the good old way" as opposed to embracing new ways of going about it.
Someone espouses a return to traditional values, the need for moral order, and the like.
Love that has come to a tragic impasse, for example because the object of the feeling has died prematurely.

There is a being whose capabilities are clearly beyond what we can fathom or describe by our science. Their feats often seem like magic and their actions may be either good or evil as judged by human standards.

We are shown what things might be like from the point of view  of a being whose abilities are so far beyond us that they seem  practically omnipotent, and who therefore is not limited by our own practical concerns.
Society is supposedly made perfect by the introduction of a new breed of human, i.e., version 2.0. Out with the old, in with the new.

examples.examples: Dr. Roger Korby had a dream in tos1x09 "What Are Little Girls Made Of?" that one day mortal human boys and girls will be mind-transfered into the bodies of immortal android boys and girls.

theme_name: transnational conflict over a claimed territory
description: Two or more sovereign factions fight over territory that they all claim as theirs.

theme_name: transnational conflict over a shared resource
description: Two or more sovereign factions fight over a resource that is not under the sole control of any one faction.
Two or more sovereign entities squabble over something related to the environment. For example, one nation's damming of a river may threaten a downstream nation's economy.
An institution reminiscent of the United Nations is featured.

examples.examples: Babylon 5 in the eponymous tv show is essentially a UN in space.

description: We are asked to what extent, if any, transsexualism ought to be tolerated in society and how people who identify with a different gender than they were assigned at birth, ought to be treated. Are sex-change operations to be permitted or even subsidized?

examples.examples: Captain Kirk and Janice Lester switched genders on account of switching bodies in tos3x24 "Turnabout Intruder".

description: Someone finds themself tiny and able to move around inside a human body.

Someone travels deep into the Earth's crust and possibly beyond (much deeper than spelunking as we know it can take you). Sometimes the goal of the journey is the center of the Earth. Sometimes a drill-like vehicle is used.
A passage through space-time that would allow vast distances to be quickly traversed.
We are made to ponder how the government ought (or ought not) to treat immigrants into our society, illegal and otherwise.

examples.examples: In tz2019e1x08 "Point of Origin", we saw how suspected illegal immigrants were herded together in cold and brutal internment camps by a ruthless government agency. The cultural context makes it clear that we must think of the way ICE in the USA have been said to treat immigrants.

description: We are asked how prisons ought to be organized. Day-care center for adults, or hell-on-Earth?
We are asked how the criminally insane ought to be treated. Just like any other prisoner, or with more compassion?

theme_name: treatment of the mentally ill in society
description: The way society treats people with serious mental illnesses is discussed.

We are asked to ponder what one should do after the war with those of one's own people who choose to collaborate with the enemy for one reason or another. For example, if someone collaborated only because they would be killed otherwise, should they be punished?
The idea is posited that real beauty does not come from make-up and such mundane trappings, but is a thing of the soul.

examples.examples: Ruth, Magda and Eve found that they didn't need the Venus drug to be beautiful because their beauty stemmed from increased self-confidence and not the drug in tos1x03 "Mudd's Women".

description: The idea that beings can have true name, and that speaking said names can have some sort of supernatural effects, is featured. For example, speaking the true name of a demon might perhaps summon said demon.

A character exhibits a feeling of faith in the reliability of someone or, occasionally, something. This assumes that the character harbors a certain level of "acceptance", not necessarily "admiration" toward their object.
A character supports a friend by showing unwavering trust in their honesty.
A leader inspires trust in their team members.
A character must choose whether a potential foe is to be trusted.

theme_name: trust in intentions vs. trust in judgement
description: A character must choose whether another's judgement can be trusted even though their intentions are above reproach.
There is technology, perhaps a serum or other kind of drug, by which people can be made to speak the truth and nothing but the truth, to some extent or another.
A character endorses the ethic that we ought to refrain from retaliating when aggrieved. While this could be about physical attacks it is more often used in the context of insults.

examples.examples: The pacifist Dowd turned every cheek on his body in spite of insult and injury (then he ran out and wiped a species of 50 billions clean out existence) in tng3x03 "The Survivors".

description: The relationship between two siblings born of a single pregnancy, is featured.
A hypothetical planet that is a near duplicate of Earth.

examples.examples: Earth Two was discovered in tos1x11 "Miri" and found to be populated only by children.

description: A being that perceive only two spatial dimension, like those sentient geometrical figures occupying a two-dimensional world described in the satirical novella "Flatland: A Romance of Many Dimensions" by E. A. Abbott.

examples.examples: The Enterprise-D came into contact with a plane of 2D beings floating towards a cosmic string in tng4x10 "The Loss", and got stuck.

description: A world confined to two spatial dimensions.

examples.examples: The Enterprise-D got stuck in a plane of two-dimensional beings in tng4x10 "The Loss".

description: A character is able to do or change reality in practically any way, qualitatively limited only by imagination.

notes.notes: This theme is used when the ability appears qualitatively unbounded. That is, a character may be seen to do a few limited things, but it is clear that there are very few limits on what sort of things they can do. Typically, this theme is used when a character becomes godlike and can will reality to change in the blink of an eye.

parents.parents: speculative ability related to reality at large

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to reality at large

examples.examples: Riker was riding on his high horse upon having been granted godlike Q powers in tng1x10 "Hide and Q".

description: The relationship between an uncle and his nephew is featured.
The relationship between an uncle and his niece is featured.
There is a being that is deceased but behaves as if they were alive.
There is an as undead creature wrapped in bandages.

examples.examples: The mad scientist Dr. Krupp hatched a plot to steal a golden breastplate and a bracelet from the tomb of the centuries-old living mummy Popocain in "The Robot vs. the Aztec Mummy" (1958).

description: There is a living (typically human) skeleton.

examples.examples: A living skeleton received a lesson in elevator manners in the "Night Gallery" tale "An Act of Chivalry" (1971).

description: There is a large underground settlement that does not sprawl out onto the surface.

notes.notes: This theme does not apply when a small community of people living inside caverns or a underground complex, as is sometimes depicted in post-apocalyptic dystopian films.

examples.examples: The United Earth Government prepared approximately 10,000 underground cities for the world's population to hunker down inside while the planet was being migrated out of the Solar System to the Alpha Centauri system in "The Wandering Earth" (2019).

description: A tunnel which is partly or wholly constructed under a body of water is featured in a manner that makes it clear it is a future technological achievement.
Communicating by metaphorical language is featured.
A small, air-tankless device that fits in the mouth used to breathe underwater.

examples.examples: Obi-Wan Kenobi and Qui-Gon Jinn used just such devices to swim to the underwater city Otoh Gunga in "Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace" (1999).

description: A large settlement under water. It might be adapted for air-breathing people somehow, or it may be inhabited by water breathers.
The social problem of people being unemployed against their desire is discussed.
There is a businessman or corporation that, in their ruthless pursuit of the bottom line, engage in activities that are clearly considered unethical. The activities may or may not be legal.

examples.examples: In futurama1x13 "Fry and the Slurm Factory", the Slurm factory was an evil corporation that ruthlessly exploited its poor "Grunka-Lunka" thralls in order to produce an extraordinarily unhealthy but addictive Slurm cola which it marketed vigorously to the public.

description: We are made to ponder whether unethical practices can be justified if they are likely to further scientific progress. Would it, for example, be alright to risk the life of a convicted felon in order to test out a device that might bring us clean energy?

Medical experiments are carried out on people and we are asked question such as: Can the ends justify the means when someone tests medical procedures and drugs on patients without their informed consent? Is it right to use knowledge that was obtained through atrocities such as the Nazi experimentation in German concentration camps?
It is discussed whether a psychological experiment can be considered ethical.

examples.examples: Dr. Tristan Adams used a device to break people's minds and turn them into zombies in tos1x10 "Dagger of the Mind", all in the name of medical science.

description: There is an organization of workers who have come together to achieve common goals; such as protecting the integrity of its trade, improving safety standards, and attaining better wages, etc.
A device used to seamlessly translate speech between any languages.
For whatever reason, a character is literally impossible to kill through conventional means. Typically, this happens because fate is involved.

ancestors.ancestors: speculative ability related to own body

description: The classical "who is the father?" scenario, according to which there is a child and it is pondered who the real parent is, is featured.

The act of intentionally restricting another person's movement within any area without legal authority, justification, or the restrained person's permission, is featured as a crime. Notably, this situation tends to arise in fiction when police or similar forces overstep the bounds.
The many trials and tribulations a woman or a couple may face when the woman unexpectedly becomes pregnant are featured.

examples.examples: Worf was at a loss for words when K'Ehleyr showed up in tng4x07 "Reunion" and had with her the unexpected consequence of their impulse mating on the holodeck some years earlier.

description: A romantic love, or infatuation, in which the object of the ambition declines to reciprocate the emotions, i.e., they don't love you back.

examples.examples: Geordi was devastated to find that the real Leah Brahms didn't much fancy him in tng4x16 "Galaxy's Child".

theme_name: uptight character vs. laid back character
description: An uptight character is contrasted with a more easy going person.
There is an alien race that is native to the planet Uranus in our solar system.
A character, typically a parent or mentor, must choose in a given situation whether to be harsh with a another for their own good.

Notions about how society could be made "perfect". Note that such notions are often scatterbrained and the objects of the themes turn out to be horrible dystopia. This is all captured in the word "utopia" which literally means "no place".

theme_name: utopia based on a view of human nature
description: Society is perfect because, well, everyone behaves in a way that conforms to a particular view of human nature.

theme_name: utopia based on exploitation of a group
description: Society is great because there is a (usually contemptible) class of people who can be made to do all the unpleasant work.

theme_name: utopia on the back of android labor
description: Society is perfect thanks to an army of androids that fulfill our every wish.

parents.parents: utopia based on exploitation of a group

ancestors.ancestors: utopia based on exploitation of a group

examples.examples: An army of obedient androids stood ready to bring utopia to the galaxy but were stopped by Captain Kirk and a well aimed logical paradox in tos2x12 "I, Mudd".

theme_name: utopia on the back of slave labor
description: Society is perfect thanks to an army of slaves that just take care of every distasteful chore.

parents.parents: utopia based on exploitation of a group

ancestors.ancestors: utopia based on exploitation of a group

description: There is a being, typically undead and sentient, that subsists by feeding on the blood of the living.
The deliberately destroying or damaging to public or private property is featured as being a crime.

examples.examples: The Troglytes of Ardana were none too happy with their status as lowly miners and used vandalism to voice their displeasure in tos3x19 "The Cloud Minders".

description: A character exhibits excessive admiration of their own appearance or achievements.

examples.examples: Mudd's women took the "Venus drug" in order to maintain youthful appearances in the eponymous episode tos1x03 "Mudd's Women".

description: Someone abstains from eating meat and other animal products on moral grounds.
There is a bitter, destructive and escalating feud between two factions within one society.

examples.examples: Yuta of the vanquished clan Tralesta was genetically altered and spent 100 years tracking down members of the Lornak clan in a vendetta in tng3x09 "The Vengeance Factor".

description: Ventriloquism, or ventriloquy, is an act of stagecraft in which a person (a ventriloquist) creates the illusion that their voice is coming from elsewhere, usually a puppeteered prop, known as a "dummy". This activity is featured in the story.

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities
the fine arts and the humanities

description: Featured is a native inhabitant of the planet Venus.
Someone exhibits an addiction to a video game.
A character is enthusiastic about playing video games.

examples.examples: Alex Rogan was determined to set the high score on an arcade game, called Starfighter, in "The Last Starfighter" (1984).

description: The social consequences of our recently emerging ability to fake or manipulate video with such precision that it is hard to spot, is discussed.
A phone system with a video link is featured in such a manner that it is made clear it is still a technology to be developed in the future.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk and his crew conferred in such a way in tos2x26 "Assignment: Earth".

description: Extrajudicial punishment that is motivated by the nonexistence of law and order or dissatisfaction with justice is featured.
The social implications of violence being portrayed, often glorified, on TV, in films, in games, or in other media, is explored.

This is the category of themes that relate to prescribed actions involving violence or the threat of violence. The action must be understood in the context of the story to constitute a crime, be it against written law or unwritten customs (for example against God or other notions of morality).
A religious doctrine holding that someone, i.e., Christ, was conceived in the absence of sexual intercourse.

examples.examples: While it is unlikely that Troi was a virgin at the time, her intercourse-free pregnancy in tng2x01 "The Child" nevertheless fits the bill.

description: There is a virtual personality with which someone corporeal has a love affair.
A personality that exists only as a program within some computer. It is self- aware but may or may not be cognizent of its status as a simulation. Perhaps we all are such.
There is a programmable room that can produce virtually any imaginable setting, including tangible physical objects, like virtual reality on steroids.
There is a technology that allows users to engage in sexual relations with virtually reality simulated characters, or receive tactile sensations from remote participants.
There is a wearable suit that makes it seem as if you were somewhere else, encompassing all the senses.

examples.examples: Geordi uses a virtual reality suit to explore a wrecked spaceship in the inhospitable environment of a gas giant planet in tng7x03 "Interface".

theme_name: vision beyond the visible spectrum glasses
description: Glasses-like technology that can make the brain perceive and interpret electromagnetic waves (light) beyond what is normal, i.e., into the infrared or ultraviolet regions and possibly beyond. This is used to describe Geordi's iconic VISOR. Note: this includes X-ray glasses as a special case.
A Native American ritual used to establish contact with an ancestral spirit to ask for guidance during a difficult time.

examples.examples: The mystic Traveler posing as a space Native American mystic embarked Wesley on a vision quest to acquire arcane lore in tng7x20 "Journey's End".

description: It is discussed whether dissecting a living creature for the sake of advancing medical knowledge is justified.

examples.examples: Extradimensional aliens abducted Riker and severed his arm in tng6x05 "Schisms".

description: A device used to make your voice sound like that of another.

examples.examples: The android Ruk had a built in voice duplicator that let him impersonate Captain Kirk in tos1x09 "What Are Little Girls Made Of?"

description: A device which can identify a speaker merely from a recording of their voice and to some extent understand what is being said. This was sci-fi in the 60s. This was pure sci-fi in the 60s but is by-and-by becoming more of a reality.

examples.examples: Gary Seven's computer in tos2x26 "Assignment: Earth" recognized its owner's voice.

description: Volcanic activity increases and civilization bites the dust. Pardon the pun.

parents.parents: force of nature existential risk to civilization

ancestors.ancestors: force of nature existential risk to civilization

examples.examples: Terratin civilization on Terra Ten was threatened by volcanic activity in tas1x11 "The Terratin Incident" so Captain Kirk moved them all to Verdanis.

description: There is an effigy of a person that can mysteriously be used to affect that person in various way. A person may, for example, be subjected to various afflictions when needles are inserted into relevant parts of their effigy.
The occasional religious practice of forswearing speech is featured.
Someone goes on a journey into the depths of the sea, typically in a submarine.

examples.examples: Captain Nemo built a super high-tech submarine to explore the ocean depths in "20000 Leagues Under the Sea" (1954).

description: Dreams are interpreted in a highly metaphorical or otherwise esoteric way.
Sovereign factions, usually state-like entities but sometimes armed rebels etc., taking up arms against each other for one reason or another is featured.
An act that constitutes a serious violation of the laws of war that gives rise to individual criminal responsibility is featured.
Neither faction in a diplomatic negotiation really wants war but fluke and miscalculation threaten to pull them into a military confrontation anyway.
The idea is put forth that the deliberate waging of war, horrible as it may be, may sometimes be justified.

examples.examples: Spock argued that war against Nazi Germany was warranted in the lead up to World War II in tos1x28 "The City on the Edge of Forever".

description: People wage war on each other and (often with the help of WMDs) wipe each other out in a mutual apocalypse.
A war primarily caused or justified by differences in religion is featured.
War (typically civil war) breaks out over who is to become the new leader after the old leader dies.

A faction with the upper hand in a military conflict decides to loot and remove some of their opponents' cultural artifacts and other valuables. This theme is often featured when the war is over and calls for the return of said plunder are made.
The use of propaganda in war is featured. This can be to dehumanize and demonize the enemy, to glorify your own actions, and to heroify your allies.
There is a man who practices witchcraft.
The societal problem of how to handle all sorts of unwanted byproducts of human activity is discussed. This means rubbish and garbage form everyday life as well as from industry.
There is a planet that is almost 100% water through and through.
There is a sport which takes place either in or on liquid water.
The art and artifice of making depictions out of wax like substances, is featured. For example, a wax museum filled with wax effigies of famous people might be pointedly featured.

ancestors.ancestors: the fine arts and the humanities

theme_name: we need a balance between rationality and emotionality
description: We are shown that people use a balance of rationality and emotionality in their normal functioning.

theme_name: we need our darker side in moderation
description: The idea is posited that dark emotions such as anger, jealousy, and fear, which we usually detest, actually serve a meaningful purpose.

examples.examples: Captain Kirk was duplicated into one copy that had all his good qualities, one that had all the bad but neither of which was a very useful person in tos1x04 "The Enemy Within".

description: The use of animals in warfare and other combat related activities is featured.

examples.examples: A corporation was marketing special genetically engineered dinosaurs to be used in warfare in "Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom" (2018).

description: A weapon of mass destruction (WMD) is a nuclear, radiological, chemical, biological, or any other weapon that can kill and bring significant harm to a large number of humans or cause great damage to human-made structures (e.g., buildings), natural structures (e.g., mountains), or the biosphere. This is the category of themes that relate to the use of such weapons in war.

notes.notes: We consider that the mere existence of a WMD implies its potential use in war as these devices really have no other credible purpose.

examples.examples: Biological, chemical, and nuclear weapons are commonly found beneath the moniker "weapons of mass destruction".

description: There is a human with a transmittable condition that makes them occasionally transform in to a vicious creature, typically a wolf, or a human-creature hybrid.

theme_name: what civilian life is like in times of war
description: A more or less ordinary character who is not directly part of the war effort, nor directly becomes a victim, experiences what civilian life is like when their society goes to war.

theme_name: what if a child had power over adults
description: We are made to imagine a situation in which a child exercises notable authority over an adult. This can, for example, happen because the child has supernatural powers that enable them to enforce their will.

examples.examples: In tz2019e1x05 "The Wunderkind", young sociopath Oliver Foley cleverly manipulates public opinion and becomes elected president of the USA. Once installed in the White House, it does not take long for Oliver's despotic tendencies to bloom. Adults around him must jump to his childish whims for fear of loosing their jobs or be accused of treason.

theme_name: what if a killer was after me
description: A character experiences what it is like to know that someone is out to take their life.

parents.parents: what if someone dangerous was after me

ancestors.ancestors: what if someone dangerous was after me
what if I were in a tight spot

theme_name: what if a loved one became possessed by another being
description: We imagine what it would be like if a loved one suddenly became possessed by a demon or some other malevolent entity and started doing evil demon things, like hitting us.

parents.parents: what if someone around me changed

ancestors.ancestors: what if someone around me changed

examples.examples: Keiko O'Brien's husband Miles became possessed by a malevolent, disembodied prisoner alien in tng5x15 "Power Play".

theme_name: what if an aspect of my personality was slightly different
description: We imagine what it'd be like to be a somewhat different person than we are, in terms of character.

theme_name: what if Britain had won the American Revolutionary War
description: We are made to imagine what things might have been like had England suppressed the American Revolution of 1765-1783.

theme_name: what if criminals were after me
description: We imagine what it would be like to be chased by potentially dangerous criminals, for one reason or another.

parents.parents: what if someone dangerous was after me

ancestors.ancestors: what if someone dangerous was after me
what if I were in a tight spot

examples.examples: In futurama7x12 "Viva Mars Vegas", Dr. Zoidberg finds and spends some money belonging to the robot mafia. He is then chased by said mafia who wants their money back.

theme_name: what if every woman suddenly got pregnant at the same time
description: We imagine what the world would be like if virtually every woman of childbearing age got pregnant at the same time.

theme_name: what if everyone lost control of their inhibitions
description: We imagine what the world would be like if everyone gave in to their immediate urges without self-restraint.

parents.parents: what if the people around me changed

ancestors.ancestors: what if the people around me changed

examples.examples: In tos1x06 "The Naked Time" everyone got intoxicated on polywater and did whatever they wanted. The Enterprise would have spiraled into the atmosphere of Psi 2000 were it not for the Captain Kirk's willpower and Dr. McCoy's ingenuity.

theme_name: what if everyone suddenly started to communicate differently
description: We imagine what it would be like to find that everyone changed how they communicate, i.e., it'd be like everyone suddenly spoke a foreign language.

notes.notes: Normally, one may reasonably think, it is not everyone else that have changed but a single observer's brain that has. This theme applies if the vantage point of such an observer is featured.

parents.parents: what if the people around me changed

ancestors.ancestors: what if the people around me changed

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x02a "Wordplay", Bill found that he could no longer understand anyone else because they seemed to use the wrong words for the things they were talking about. In the end he had to re-learn English.

In the Bible story of the "Tower of Babel", Genesis 11:1-9, God made people speak different languages as a punishment for their audacious contrivance to reach the heavens by erecting an enormous tower.

theme_name: what if everyone suddenly turned stupid
description: We imagine what the world would be like if virtually everyone in it turned incredibly stupid.

theme_name: what if everyone turned into zombies
description: We imagine what the world would be like if everyone in it (except us) turned into zombies.

parents.parents: what if the people around me changed

ancestors.ancestors: what if the people around me changed

examples.examples: Wesley dropped by the Enterprise-D for a visit in tng5x06 "The Game" only to find the crew had become a bunch of video game addicted zombies.

theme_name: what if everyone vanished and I was all alone
description: We imagine what it would be like if everyone else in our world suddenly vanished.

parents.parents: what if the people around me changed

ancestors.ancestors: what if the people around me changed

examples.examples: Captain Kirk woke up aboard what appeared to be a completely empty Enterprise in tos3x17 "The Mark of Gideon".

description: We imagine what it would be like to age backwards.

parents.parents: what if I were not subject to the normal process of aging

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were not subject to the normal process of aging

examples.examples: The Enterprise was pulled into a negative universe where people started life with old bodies that became ever younger over time in tas2x06 "The Counter- Clock Incident".

theme_name: what if I became a simulation
description: We imagine what it would be like if our consciousness was moved or copied from the world of flesh to run as a simulation in some computer-like device.

parents.parents: what if my personal identity came into question

ancestors.ancestors: what if my personal identity came into question

theme_name: what if I became accessory to a friend's crime
description: We imagine what it might be like to involuntarily be drawn into crime by a less than law-abiding friend.

parents.parents: what if I were in a tight spot

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

theme_name: what if I became extremely lucky
description: We imagine what it would be like to be on a perpetual lucky streak, winning every game of chance one engaged in.

parents.parents: what if my life were different

ancestors.ancestors: what if my life were different

theme_name: what if I became separated from my parents
description: There is a child who gets separated from their parents and must try to reunite with them. This is used when the story is told from the child's point of view.

parents.parents: what if I were in a tight spot

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

examples.examples: Mace and Cindel Towani became separated from their parents after the family crash landed on the Ewok homeworldl in "Caravan of Courage: An Ewok Adventure" (1984).

theme_name: what if I became telepathically linked with someone else
description: We are made to imagine what it'd be like to become mentally linked with someone in such a way that we could talk to them telepathically or even share sensory experiences directly (i.e., see through their eyes).

notes.notes: This theme is not used, e.g., for when there is an alien race of beings that are innately linked in a hive mind or the like.

theme_name: what if I became witness to a suspected crime
description: We imagine what it would be like to see something that seems to imply a serious crime, typically murder, yet lack certainty. Should we investigate, contact the police, or drop the matter?

parents.parents: what if I were in a tight spot

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

examples.examples: In "Rear Window" (1954) Jeff thinks he has just witnessed a murder but doesn't have enough certainty to call the police. Instead he convinces his friends to sneak over and gather evidence.

theme_name: what if I caught a glimpse of the future
description: A character is shown a sight of some future happening. This might be on account that the character invoked a magical incantation, appealed to some speculative technology, or was shown a vision of the future by another entity.

notes.notes: If a character has an innate ability to see into the future, then "precognition" is the more appropriate theme.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a different time

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a different time

examples.examples: In tz1985e2x04b "Lost and Found", Jenny, an absent minded college student with a cantankerous room mate found out from a couple of time travelers hiding in her wardrobe that she was, in fact, destined to become the future leader of a united Earth.

theme_name: what if I could be young again
description: An aged character experiences what it is like to be young again, i.e., finds the proverbial fountain of youth.

parents.parents: what if I were not subject to the normal process of aging

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were not subject to the normal process of aging

theme_name: what if I could do anything I wanted without repercussions
description: We imagine what it would be like if no one stopped us or punished us for doing whatever we felt like doing.

parents.parents: what if my life were different

ancestors.ancestors: what if my life were different

examples.examples: The Children of Landru committed unspeakable acts of lawlessness at Festival, a designated period when Landru permitted anything, in tos1x22 "The Return of the Archons".

theme_name: what if I could never go home
description: We imagine what it would be like to be far away and never able to return to our home, perhaps because we've been exiled from our country.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

examples.examples: Captain Kirk and his crew found themselves trapped inside the Delta Triangle with no realistic possibility of escape in tas 1x12 "The Time Trap".

theme_name: what if I could only speak the truth
description: There is a character who is physically unable to tell intentional lies.

notes.notes: This is one of the more-or-less incoherent counterfactuals that appears in stories: A circumstance arises in which a character tries to speak a lie (maybe a white lie or omission of the truth), but their mouth ends up uttering the truth (maybe the whole truth) to the mind's general dismay. The theme notably does not apply if a character merely chooses not to tell lies, be it for moral compulsion on legal injunctions.

examples.examples: In tz1959e2x14 "The Whole Truth", the crooked, used car dealer Mr. Hunnicut came into the possession of a haunted car that somehow made him tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth. This proved disastrous for his business.

theme_name: what if I could travel around inside a human body
description: We imagine what it would be like to be tiny and move around inside a human body.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

theme_name: what if I couldn't trust the veracity of my senses
description: We imagine what it would be like if the world our senses reported on became so peculiar that we had to question our own senses and even our sanity.

parents.parents: what if I were in a tight spot

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

examples.examples: Sulu couldn't tell whether those were swirling knives out there in space while at the held or whether his eyes were tricking him in tos3x05 "And the Children Shall Lead".

theme_name: what if I discovered that I was a facsimile of someone else
description: We imagine what it would be like to discover that we are, in fact, merely a copy of someone else who by virtue of prior existence can be considered more genuine.

parents.parents: what if my personal identity came into question

ancestors.ancestors: what if my personal identity came into question

theme_name: what if I fell into the clutches of a homicidal maniac
description: We imagine what it might be like suddenly to find one's self in the captivity and at the mercy of a crazed killer.

parents.parents: what if I fell into the clutches of a person with malicious intent

ancestors.ancestors: what if I fell into the clutches of a person with malicious intent
what if I were in a tight spot

examples.examples: In talesoftheunexpected1x05 "The Landlady", young Billy comes to realize that his landlady is a serial killer but, alas, only too late: His tea has been drugged and he is in the end no longer capable of putting up effective resistance as she leads him to his prospective deathbed.

theme_name: what if I fell into the clutches of a person with malicious intent
description: We imagine what it might be like suddenly to find one's self in the captivity and at the mercy of a person who wants us no good.

parents.parents: what if I were in a tight spot

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

examples.examples: In ahp1x16 "You Got to Have Luck", Mary is home invaded by a fugitive prisoner who threatens her with a knife and plans to use her as a hostage.

theme_name: what if I found myself in a body of the opposite sex
description: We imagine what it would be like if our mind moved into a body of the opposite gender.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in the body of another person

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in the body of another person
what if my personal identity came into question

examples.examples: An old flame took revenge on Captain Kirk by using an alien device to swap bodies with him in tos3x24 "Turnabout Intruder".

theme_name: what if I found myself in a different time
description: We imagine what it would be like to suddenly find ourself in a different time than the one they are from.

theme_name: what if I found myself in a high gravity environment
description: A character experiences what it is like to be in an environment where gravity is a lot stronger than what they are used to.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

theme_name: what if I found myself in a low gravity environment
description: We are shown what it is like for a person in a low gravity environment, as compared with Earth, such as on the surface of the Moon or on that of Mars.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

theme_name: what if I found myself in a strange place
description: We imagine what it would be like to suddenly find ourself in an unfamiliar place.

theme_name: what if I found myself in a void of nothingness
description: A character is trapped in a "void" of some sort.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

theme_name: what if I found myself in a zero gravity environment
description: We are shown what it is like for a person inside a zero gravity environment, such as on a space station or in a free-falling vehicle, where our bodies appear to float in the air.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

theme_name: what if I found myself in an alternate reality
description: We imagine what it would be like to (more or less) suddenly and unexpectedly be moved into an entirely different kind of reality.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

examples.examples: Worf suddenly found himself shifting between strangely different alternate realities in tng7x11 "Parallels".

theme_name: what if I found myself in the body of a child
description: We imagine what it would be like if our mind moved into a the body of a child.

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in the body of another person

examples.examples: A transporter malfunction turned Captain Picard and some of his crew back into children physically but not mentally in tng6x07 "Rascals".

theme_name: what if I found myself in the body of another person
description: We imagine what it would be like to suddenly find ourselves inhabiting the body another person.

parents.parents: what if my personal identity came into question

ancestors.ancestors: what if my personal identity came into question

theme_name: what if I found myself in the future
description: We imagine what it would be like to more or less suddenly and unexpectedly move into the future.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a different time

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a different time

examples.examples: Riker woke up sixteen years in the future as captain of the Enterprise-D, or so it seemed, in tng4x08 "Future Imperfect".

theme_name: what if I found myself in the past
description: We imagine what it would be like to (more or less) suddenly and unexpectedly be moved into the past.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a different time

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a different time

examples.examples: Captain Kirk, Spock, and McCoy were tossed right back into the Great Depression of the 1930s in tos1x28 "The City on the Edge of Forever".

theme_name: what if I found myself with a superabundance of potential lovers and no competition
description: A character experiences the fantastical situation of finding themself with access to a virtually unlimited supply of romantic partners with little to no competition to boot.

parents.parents: what if I found myself in a strange place

ancestors.ancestors: what if I found myself in a strange place

theme_name: what if I found out I was a different person than I thought I was
description: It is revealed to someone that their background is very different from what they believed it was.

parents.parents: what if my personal identity came into question

ancestors.ancestors: what if my personal identity came into question

examples.examples: In ds93x05 "Second Skin", Kira was told that she is in fact a Cardassian spy who has been mentally conditioned to think herself Bajoran in order to make infiltration more believable.

theme_name: what if I found out I was a simulation
description: We imagine what it would be like to suddenly discover that we are merely a simulated personality within some program in a computer, or the like.

parents.parents: what if my personal identity came into question

ancestors.ancestors: what if my personal identity came into question

theme_name: what if I found out that a loved one was not the person I thought they were
description: A character finds that a person they care about has a highly problematic or troubling side of themself.

parents.parents: what if someone around me changed

theme_name: what if I got a limb stuck in rock in the middle of nowhere

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

theme_name: what if I got accidentally locked in somewhere
description: We are made to imagine what it would be like to get accidentally locked in a room or some other relatively limited space, with no immediate way of escaping.

parents.parents: what if I were in a tight spot

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

theme_name: what if I got into trouble in a foreign country
description: A character is in a country that is foreign to them and gets into some sort of trouble that is compounded by international bureaucracy and the foreignness of the country's institutions and language.

parents.parents: what if I were in a tight spot

ancestors.ancestors: what if I were in a tight spot

examples.examples: In ahp3x10 "The Diplomatic Corpse", Evan and Janet find themselves in a spot of trouble with the authorities in Tijuana, Mexico, when their car containing Janet's late aunt's corpse is stolen.

theme_name: what if I grew in size
description: A character experiences what it is like to grow in size to potentially enormous proportions.

ancestors.ancestors: what if I underwent a physical metamorphosis

theme_name: what if I had a life-changing stroke of good fortune
description: Someone has a stroke of good luck so significant that it changes their life notably. For example when someone wins the lottery or inherits a fortune enough to be set for life.

parents.parents: what if my life were different

ancestors.ancestors: what if my life were different

theme_name: what if I had a near-death experience
description: A character is on the brink of death and has peculiar experience as a consequence.

parents.parents: what if my life were different

ancestors.ancestors: what if my life were different

theme_name: what if I had a second chance at life
description: We imagine what it would be like if we were given the chance to go back and relive our life from some earlier point but with our later memories and experiences intact.

description: We imagine what it would be like if we were given the chance to go back and relive our childhood.

parents.parents: what if my life were different

examples.examples: Ro and Guinan, to their delight, got the chance to be children again in tng6x07 "Rascals".

theme_name: what if I had a secret guardian

examples.examples: In tz1985e1x10a "The Shadow Man", a mysterious shadowy person lived under Danny's bed and appeared from nowhere to chase down bullies that dared prey on Danny.

description: We are shown an idea of what it might be like to suffer from extreme memory loss.

ancestors.ancestors: what if my personal identity came into question

examples.examples: John Doe struggled with a bad case of amnesia in tng3x25 "Transfigurations", not even remembering his own name.

theme_name: what if I had multiple personalities
description: We are made to imagine what it would be like to have more than one personality in our head, presumably vying for control.

notes.notes: This theme is typically used in fantastical scenarios where the clinical condition of multiple personality (aka. dissociative identity) disorder is not sincerely featured but distinct personalities nevertheless inhabit the same body.

aliases.aliases: what if I had a split personality

parents.parents: what if my personal identity came into question

ancestors.ancestors: what if my personal identity came into question

examples.examples: Norman Osborn struggled with his deranged alter ago the Green Goblin in "Spider-Man" (2002).

description: Someone is confronted with a deadly device that has to be defused carefully, and soon, lest it kill everyone around it.

theme_name: what if I had to have sex in order to save someone

description: We imagine what it would be like to have to perform surgery or the like on ourself.

description: We imagine what it would be like to spend an eternity in the nothingness of, say, Dante's Limbo.

theme_name: what if I heard all the thoughts around me
